item.name: 1655: Habemus Papam
item.comment: There are different things were you can focus on, which is good

item.name: 1830: Railways & Robber Barons
item.comment:
Wow, this is one heck of a burnbrainer. Much more vicious then those other 18XX-based games I already played (Baltimore & Ohio and Poseidon) as you can really screw someone by robbing a company and then selling all your shares so that the new president is stuck with a worthless company.
Gaming time is really long, so better start this in an afternoon :s

item.name: 1984: Animal Farm
item.comment:
Very nice artwork. Only played an incomplete game and they explained the game while playing (and don't like that way of explanation). I like the mechanics, but I think there might be a problem with 'pick-on-the-leader' as you have to make a coallition with your right and left neighbour. So if you score too much points in the beginning, players won't ally themselves with you anymore (I think).
Update 30/12/2012: Played a full game, but the short variant, so only 6 rounds. And that was more then long enough. Can't imagine you wanna play the full 9 rounds. There are some nice mechanics in this game, but the glue that should keep everything together, just doesn't seem to work at all.

item.name: 1984: Animal Farm – Spiel 2012 promo cards
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: 20th Century
item.comment: Good, but not 'Die Werft'-good; But still better then most games: Increased my rating after 2nd play

item.name: 20th Century Limited
item.comment:
Surprisingly good. It seemed a bit dull in the beginning as everybody was going for the short and easy regional cards, but when you start to be short in track, things become more interesting as you have to start focussing on completing company cards.
Also a plus is the playing time: 60 minutes for a train game is good.

Good filler, where you have to live with the fact that you can have a 'bad' hand. Therefore the 'pass'-action for 1 minus point is a nice feature; the pass-action for 2 minus points where your opponent has to play a card is just nasty :D

item.name: 4 Monkeys
item.comment: A game on time that I can win, this must be good :); Nice idea to include a real timer, then you don't have to worry about the sandtimer; Just quick fun!

item.name: 51st State
item.comment: Very good impression after one play!

item.name: 7 Steps
item.comment: (Very) good impression after 1 play. Had no high expectation seen the low rating, but this was good fun playing. Off course there is a certain luck involved as the player before you can create a good opportunity for you, but normally that will level out and if it doesn't, just play an other game, as it had a nice short playing time :-)

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: If you want a fast, good game, that plays excellent with a lot of players (even 7), this is your game

item.name: 7 Wonders: Babel
item.comment: Finally an expansion for 7 Wonders that is worth owning. The law cards aren't that great (and way overproduced), but the Tower of Babel is a new great action that makes you can interact with all players, instead of only your direct neighbours.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Catan
item.comment: Nice gimmick

item.name: 7 Wonders: Cities
item.comment: Same feeling as with '7 Wonders: Leaders', OK to add if you have it, but not necessary at all.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Duel
item.comment: Heard some good things about this one by other players and I must say I can confirm them. It has off course a high 7 Wonders-feeling, but the twists are significant enough to keep this one interesting.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Duel – The Messe Essen
item.comment: Nice effect :-)

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.comment: OK, but not that great addition. It results in higher scores

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders – Louis
item.comment: I guess you can take it if you're planning on ignoring the red cards and so compensating the minus points you'll get, but otherwise this seems like a lame card to play

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders – Stevie
item.comment: Same rating as 7 Wonders - Leaders

item.name: 7 Wonders: Manneken Pis
item.comment: Nice to have

item.name: 7 Wonders: Wonder Pack
item.comment: I think al the good wonders are gone: there is no wonder in this package that screams for 'that's the one I wanna have!'.

It's simply a sort of double Black Jack (or 21 like we call it) were if you're out for 8 still can go for 28. The only thing that annoys me a bit is that there are actual 8's into the deck, so you can be Lucky and stop with one card. Imho it would be better to have no 8's, then nobody can have that luck.

item.name: A la carte
item.comment: Very funny and something quite different; Excellent when in the right mood

item.name: A la carte: Dessert
item.comment: The new coffee cups are nice and also the idea to have salt in your dish; If the 4 spice bottles are nearly empty, this is harder then you think.

item.name: Ab in die Tonne
item.comment: Very, very light game. I'm very curious to see if it's really possible to fill the bin with all the garbish, so that you get + instead of minuspoints?

item.name: Abandon Ship
item.comment: Fun and easy

item.name: Abluxxen
item.comment: Bought this game because it's Kramer & Kiesling and because Eric Martin thought this is THE game of 2014 already. And I must say it's indeed fun to play :D

item.name: Abluxxen: Sonderkarten / Duell
item.comment: This sucks as the player who can finish the round will always have an extra reward of 5 points as you normally finish with a big series.

item.name: Abyss
item.comment: Plays fast and is easy to explain. One of the nicest artwork I've ever seen!

item.name: Abyss: Key Monster Tokens
item.comment: Nice extra

item.name: Abyss: Kraken
item.comment: I heared that the treasure is a pure luck-fest, so only played with the Nebulis, which is clearly a copy of the corruption from the Lords of Waterdeep - expansion, but it just doesn't work that good and is more random, while in Lords of Waterdeep is a clear choice you make.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: the holy grail

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: 1999 edition

item.name: Ad Astra
item.comment: Too long, too repetitive near the end

item.name: Adventurers (The): The Temple of Chac
item.originalname: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: Had seen a great video of this game on The Dice Tower; And it's all true, this is really a great fun game. I've never been killed with so much pleasure before. If it stays fun after some more plays, this will probably will become a 10.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Pyramid of Horus
item.comment: It's harder to estimate the risk as in 'the Temple of Chac' with the falling blocs, but still fun to play

item.name: Aeroplanes: Aviation Ascendant
item.comment:
First let me start by saying that when I first explained this game to everybody, we all agreed that the rolling dice for starting player was just timeconsuming and didn't add anything to the game. So we just determined a random start player for the first round, kept on taking turns in clockwise order and the new starting player for the next round was the one who took the black token (according to the rules). Off course my thoughts and rating or based on playing the game this way.
I hadn't heard or read anything good about this game. But as I like most or Martin Wallace's games, I gave it a try anyway. And I'm very glad I did! This ain't no Brass of Age of Steam off course, it's indeed easier then those, but it still requires some good thinking and planning to get those precious and hard to get victory points. Especially if you're aiming for points from profit (which is 1 of the 3 ways (the other are majorities and VP from aeroplanes/passengers), you really have to stay focussed on what you're doing and don't have to be to greedy!
Therefore I enjoyed my 1 play a lot so far and I'm looking forward to an other gameplay of this!

item.name: Aeroplanes: PWS-24
item.comment: It's just another card with an aeroplane on. Nothing more, nothing less, no need to own this.

item.name: African Park
item.comment: OK game, but quick and not difficult to explain

item.name: Africana
item.comment: 1 play with 4 players and then downtime is a bit too much. Probably at best with 3 players. Good family game.

item.name: Africana: Die Farbwechsler
item.comment: It's a nice idea, and it's an good choice you have to make: changing a color is great, but it's a card that counts for your handlimit. However the cutted cards from the catalogue are not ideal, as you can tell by far where they are in the books :s

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: Nothing new, but good implementation of known mechanics

item.name: Age of Industry
item.comment: Still don't see all the possibilities, but it's certainly more accessible then Brass

item.name: Age of Industry Expansion #1: Japan and Minnesota
Age of Industry Expansion: Belgium & USSR
item.comment: Only played the Belgium map so far and that's a very good one with some nice twists.

item.name: Age of Industry Expansion: Great Lakes & South Africa
item.comment:
Getting to those mines on the South African map is some heavy shit :s
Updated 18/06/2014: The 2-player map is excellent. Increased rating by a half for that.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment: A bit too heavy for me; I'd prefer Steam or Railroad Tycoon (depending on how long I wanna play)

item.name: Agora
item.comment: It's the determination of the judge that screws this game. Why couldn't they have found a more tactical way then 3 random draws?

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: This is one great game

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
item.comment: This game is all it promises: fast, simplified Agricola that also very ideal if you wanna take a game with you when you travel. However, as everything is fixed, I'm wondering about the replayability?

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small – Even More Buildings Big and Small
Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small – More Buildings Big and Small
item.comment: This game needed more variety and was crying for an expansion!

item.name: Agricola: De Lage Landen
item.comment: I already had the veggie-meeples and 'Through the Seasons', so for me the only thing new are the different decks. I guess they are a nice extra to have, but absolutely not necessary to have.

item.name: Agricola: Through the Seasons
item.comment: For being a free postcard, this is a very nice addition!

item.name: Airlines Europe
item.comment: Similar to Union Pacific, but better with 3 & 4 players and nicer components

item.name: Airlines Europe: Flugverbot
item.comment: Doens't add anything valuable to the game.

item.name: Airlines Europe: The Presidents
item.comment: Ok expansion, as if you can't use them because you don't get those colours, they are still worth 2 points.

item.name: Akaba
item.comment: Well, this is harder then it looks :-)

item.name: Akrotiri
item.comment: With the 2D-insight not totally my cup of tea, but a good 2-player game I would happily play when asked for.

item.name: Al Rashid
item.comment:
This is one very unforgiving game. One mistake can cost you 1 or 2 dishonor which can really make the difference in this game. And as there only 5 turns, there is very little room to put things right again.
When we play a game with different sort of tiles (in this case titles), we don't explain all the different tiles, but invite everybody to read/discover them during the game and just start playing. For this game however I would recommend that everybody takes a look at the politics-titles before you start. They can give you many points, but are hard to meet the requirements. If you want to take for instance the 1 that requires 6 Sages, you have to take 1 Sage every round, so it's important to know that!
The hard part for me is that you can also activate an area which doens't contain any of your pawns. You should really keep that in mind before putting yourself in a palace without already having the necessary goods or in a geographical area with mercenary's without having the necessary mercenarry tiles!
All that aside, I really enjoyed my 1 play with 5 players. It took us 150 minutes as predicted on the box (30 minutes/player), but it was tense all the time and didn't become boring for a second. It was only in the 5th round that you could predict on who made a chance on winning this game, so no runaway leader problem for this game!

item.name: Aladdin's Dragons
item.comment: The boardgame is better and there is almost no difference. So unless you are looking for a version that's easier to take with you if you travel, there is no reason to have this

item.name: Alarm!
item.comment: This is an easy to explain fun, fast cardgame, ideal to open or close a gaming night. You'll probably want to play another game right after your first one :D

item.name: Alba Longa
item.comment: Rating based on variant where conflict is minimized by the neutral player.

item.name: Alba Longa: The Sentinels
item.comment: Extra defense, I like it :)

item.name: Alcazar
item.comment: Played a few rules wrong; rating may change when playing by the correct rules

item.name: Alchemists
item.comment: MAG-NI-FI-CENT artwork!! And also a very good game. The app is just a gimmick, just like the wheels in Tzolk'in, but it works and it is just a part of a great game. Deduction is only a small part of this game and it is what you do with your findings that really matters.

item.name: Alchemists: Ring of Favor Promo Card
Alhambra
item.comment: A real classic and great gateway game

item.name: Alhambra: Power of the Sultan
item.comment: The new scoring cards are a nice addition

item.name: Alhambra: The Falconers
item.comment: Only played the 'exchange certificates', which feels very similar to the money exchange - module. 'The Falconers' however looks very nice as it gives extra scoring possibilities.

item.name: Alhambra: The Magical Buildings
item.comment: Neat idea as it can really help you to close a gap, but it prolongs the playing time as there are 6 extra tiles. Therefore it would be a good idea to randomly discard 1 tile for each color.

item.name: Alhambra: The Thief's Turn
item.comment: 'Change' is a nice idea

item.name: Ali
item.comment: As it had a very low rating, I didn't had high expectations of this one. However I enjoyed playing it a lot. It's a good filler. Off course memory & push-your-luck are right up my ally :D

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment: Very nice game that use dice in a clever way and is tight during the game considering points, which changing leaders all the time.

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Expansion Pack #1
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Expansion Pack #2
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Expansion Pack #3
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Expansion Pack #4
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Expansion Pack #5
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Expansion Pack #6
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Faction Pack #1
item.comment: Same rating as Faction Pack.

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Faction Pack #2
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Faction Pack #3
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Faction Pack #4
item.comment: Unnecessary expansion

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Factions
item.comment: The agenda's our nice, the factions however make a less tense board as you can place a die on each faction.

item.name: Alien Frontiers: Outer Belt
item.comment: + Extra possibilities - The main board is less 'crowded' with dice

item.name: Alien Frontiers: The Mind Control Helmet
Alles Käse!
item.comment: Play this game as what it's ment to be, a light fillergame with a dose of luck, but some statistics behind it, and you will have a short, good time playing this.

item.name: Alles of Niets
item.comment:
If you would translate the Dutch title to English, you would get something as 'Everything or Nothing'; Never found a title of a game being so spot on, as that's the feeling you have while playing this game.
It's certainly an interesting twist on the trick-taking - mechanism

item.name: Amber
item.comment: Tile Placement, it will probably never be my favorite game mechanism and Amber certainly didn't help improve that :( Found it to be a very dull game.

item.name: American Rails
item.comment: I like this kind of games. However, here there's not really something new. But it has the clear advantage that it doens't have a lot of rules, so it's fast to explain, but is quite strategic to play and playing time is 'normal'.

item.name: Amerigo
item.comment: nothing new, no fun

item.name: Amerigo
item.comment:
What Stefan Feld did with the dice tower is typically him: do something different with a known gaming mechanism/element. The disadvantage of his clever use of the dice tower is that there is quite a bit of manipulation needed with the cubes, which creates a certain downtime.
Big minus for me: I find the artwork really dull. By far the worst I've seen from Lieske en Stefan.
The game itself: not convinced after 1 play. Gaming time was a bit too long for me and I didn't get a wow-feeling after this 1 play. Then again, I didn't had a wow-feeling after my first play of Bora Bora either, while now I like it a lot. So hopefully Amerigo will evolve in the same way :D

item.name: Amerigo Mini- Expansion 1
item.comment: During set-up: volcano cuts off the 4 islands, make sure there is a harbor connecting to each of those 4 islands.

item.name: Amerigo Mini- Expansion 2
item.originalname: Amerigo Queenie 2: Cove Island, Bay Island & New Progress Tokens
item.comment: Some extra variety, which is nice.

item.name: Amerigo Mini- Expansion 3
item.originalname: Amerigo Queenie 3: Special Production Buildings and Tokens
item.comment: Can give you some extra points from the free production tile, but if it's really worth going for, I doubt it. It's more something that's nice if you can take it.

item.name: Among the Stars
item.comment: It's clear where they got there idea from, they played 7 Wonders, but this is a very good implementation of the idea that feels different enough of 7 Wonders to have also this one.

item.name: Among the Stars: Ambassadorial Shuttle
item.comment: For those who like anoying others

item.name: Among the Stars: Hythian
item.comment: Very handy to have 3 power on a reactor: when you put 2 reactors, other players have to put 3, to have the same amount of power. Also very handy in combination with the card by whom you can score an additional 2 points by giving up extra power.

item.name: Among the Stars: Indiegogo Promos
item.comment: I always like extra variation :D

item.name: Among the Stars: Section Seal
item.comment: Nice idea, but only interesting if you have him in year 1 or 2

item.name: Among the Stars: The Ambassadors
item.comment: The Ambassadors are a nice extra feature, but basically it's in essence more new locations, races, objectives,...

item.name: Among the Stars: The Promos
item.originalname: Among the Stars: Expanding the Alliance
item.comment: Certainly not a must have

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: Played it once with 5 and liked it very much. Probably not so good with less players

item.name: Amyitis
item.comment: Is there only one way to victory?

item.name: The Ancient World
item.comment: + This plays very fast + everything is clear + there seems to be more then 1 strategy possible, after 1 play I didn't had the feeling that figthing Titans was the only way to score points - it's a pity the designer (already) recycled some of his concepts from City of Iron like the districts and paying science. It gives a new game a certain déjà-vu - feeling

item.name: The Ancient World: The Frog God Statue Promo
item.comment: 1 play with 3 players and nobody used it. Maybe only usefull with 4 players?

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment:
I can understand why this is currently (08/03/2013) at number 6 on BGG. It's very hard to play, which makes it tense and you have lots of different strategies to try out. Also thematically it all makes sense.
However: the learning curve is definitely steep. This is a typical game you have to love AND you have to have a gaming partner who equally loves the game and with whom you can play this game a lot. Given the hard to explain rules, you don't wanna explain this over and over again to different people. Thats' why this probably won't stay in my collection :s

item.name: Andromeda
item.comment: Very good family game

item.name: Animalia
item.comment: light, but nice

item.name: Antartik
item.comment: Lot of luck and not so interesting to play.

item.name: Antics!
item.comment: Not too difficult rules, easy to play, nice components and a short playing time. What more do you want :)

item.name: Antike
item.comment: Rating is based on 1 play with 3: with 3 this is a very boring game; However I can see the potential with more players

item.name: Antike II
item.comment:
1 play but with 1 'little' detail we forgot: "The conqueror removes as many military units from the city’s region as the defense strength of the city, and returns them to their supply."
Makes an all different game off course if you don't have to remove your armies!
Edit: played a 2nd time by the correct rules and then indeed it's quite harder to go for military!

item.name: Apenjungle
item.comment: Just another, however nicely produced, twist of the memory-mechanic. The placing of the monkey onto the empy space seems to be a difficult issue for the child.

item.name: Aquaretto
item.comment: If playing with newbies, Zooloretto is easier to teach them; But they are equally fun

item.name: Aquaretto: The Trains
item.comment: Part of a special package II by Rio Grande Games

item.name: Aquarium
item.comment: Very good game that can please as well families as more experienced players

item.name: Aquarium: Rainbowfish
item.comment: Nice litte addition

item.name: AquaSphere
item.comment: Definitly a harder Feld with a steaper learning curve. As often lots of possibilities. Getting those ability-cards that give you points for certain actions seems a good way to go.

item.name: Aquileia
item.comment: Good game that uses the same mechanic as Tribune, but Tribune is better

item.name: Archipelago
item.comment:
Well, let me start by congratulating all those who struggled through the rulebook, it's far from obvious to get it all from 1 lecture. This is a hard game to explain also as there are quite a lot of rules.
Our first game ended prematurely after only 2 rounds, making me win as I had the separatist. I understand why the card is in it (otherwise people who have the feeling they can't win anymore, can make everybody lose), but I can also understand why people would exclude it from gameplay.
The game itself has some interesting (new) mechanics. The everybody loses if there would be more revolutionaries as inhabitants is 1 of them (after CO2 this is the 2nd 2012 Essen-release that has a 'you-can-all-lose' - mechanic without being a coöperative game) and I also liked what they did with the insert(s) to keep information hidden.
Nice artwork also, only the huts that give a surplus of workers could have been clearer (or at least bigger :s).

item.name: Archipelago: Solo Expansion
item.comment: My feeling is that according the scenario, it will be more luck that true skill that will determine your rank. For instance with 'Tom Hat', where you want as many pineapples as possible, if you would be lucky to find the tile with 4 pineapples on your first exploration, winning would be a walk in the park. If you would however find any pineapples at all in the beginning, you'll have a hard time to even get into rank 2.

item.name: Archon: Glory & Machination
item.comment:
I think I must be an exception: I had heard some bad things about this game before playing (Fré totally demolished this game in his review and for Ellen it was also only OK) and after our 1 play I was the only player who had a good feeling about this game.
That there is nothing really new concerning game mechanics in this game, that I can agree with (mini-deckbuilding was clearly THE mechanic of Essen 2013, as after Rokoko and Concordia, this already the 3rd game that uses this). The critic that turn order is really important and it's stupid to sacrifice an action (= a card) for it, I completely don't agree with. I did it a few times when I felt I was too high in turn order and by becoming first I could grab the best spots first, so by renouncing 1 action in 1 round, my actions in the next ones were far more efficient, so it was well worth sacrificing that 1 card.
I like how everything works together and how you can personalize your deck by going for certain colours of Magisters. It's a game where you have to play in an opportunistic way (something I like doing), by whom I mean: If you have the resources for taking by example science, and the spot is available, then just buy science, as your certain it will give you points at the end of the season. If you have the plan in your head to take all the necessary resources for gatekeepers and converting those resources into gatekeepers all in the same round, then you'll probably end up frustrated, as especially with 4 there's bound to be someone getting into your way on at least 1 spot you need (but off course The Clerics (= blue Magister) can help you with that :)).
So for me a game I'm glad having in my collection. Now have to find some players who also like this game :s

item.name: Archon: Glory & Machination – BGG Mini Expansion
item.comment: This is expansion is a sort of split-off from the Kickstarter stretch - rewards. Rather lame this!

item.name: Archon: Glory & Machination – Kickstarter Stretch Rewards
Arena: Roma II
item.comment: Played it 2 times, and 2 times we had the same problem: one of the players couldn't get a card that gave him victory points, so he just run out; 3 time was more balanced with more 'battle', but still, not a lot of challenge

item.name: Argent: The Consortium
item.comment: Not bad. Big plus is the original criteria to win the game: you need the most votes, but don't know what will give you a vote. There seems also to be a lot of variety possible in this game with all those different rooms who are double-sided

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment: Very good medium game

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment: I'll only play this on a saturday or sunday afternoon!

item.name: Arkwright
item.comment: Only played 2 out of 3 rounds of the base game at the Essen-fair. It's certainly a good game, based on the base game, but not so good that I want to spent 70+ euro's on it. And the best will probably be the full game, but that takes apperantly 4 hours. Which means I will be lucky if I get this once a year on the gaming table (and have to reread the rules every time :s)

item.name: Armadöra
item.comment: Very quick and simple area influence game.

item.name: Arriala: Canal de Garonne
item.comment: Quick and good

item.name: Artifact
item.comment: Played wrong (concerning the number of actions you can take), so have to play once more by the correct rules, but it seems all a bit dull and repetitive.

item.name: Artificium
item.comment: I had only 1 play of this game, but it was enough to see a flow in this game: round 1. I didn't get any basic resources and there weren't any cards in the market. No problem, I just buy grain for 2 gold with the 5 starting gold I had and convert it into food. I plan to upgrade the food, but hey, someone plays an action card and as they come first, they steel my food and my card is wasted. No problem, I use an other 2 gold to buy wood and convert that into bear. I want to upgrade the bear, but hey guess what, someone played an other action card by whom he could steal my bear before I could convert it. So after round 1 I had no resources and 1 gold. STUPID game!!

item.name: Artus
item.comment: With 4 it's a bit too hard as you only have 4 knights and often need 3 for certain scoring cards. With 2 and 3 players you have 5 knights which gives you more control.

item.name: Asante
item.comment: This is the same, really the same as Jambo. This could easily have been 'Jambo: expansion 3', which would have been a more honest choice, because really, who is waiting for exactly the same game with just other cards? The people who will by this are the Jambo-fans, who wanna use the cards to have more variety.

item.name: Asara
item.comment: Totally my kind of game: a harder family game. Not difficult to explain, lots of interesting choices you have to make and a little bit of luck

item.name: Asara: Das Haus des Flaschengeistes
item.comment: Nothing special

item.name: Asara: Die Gaben des Kalifen
item.comment: Nice addition, certainly if you play it like we did, where spaces have to be filled from left to right (so you just can't put a card there).

item.name: Ascending Empires
item.comment: When I saw it was dexterity in combination with devolping technoligies, I had some serious doubts about this game (because I'm very bad at dexterity :s). But I must admit that it works very good together and I had a lot of fun playing this game.

item.name: Ascension: Apprentice Edition
item.comment:
This is total commercial crap. There is absolutely no need for this 'introductionary edition'. If you wanna learn the game, there is no better way then with simply the first game 'Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer';
The artwork on this one is very ugly, they raped there own game!

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer
item.comment: A bit like Dominion, but easier and you have to find a balance between runes and power.

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Control Room Promo
item.comment: How good this card is really depends on how many Mechana Constructs come into play. But of course, it's always 5 honor!

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Deep Drone Promo
item.comment: Ok to have

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Journeyman Sage Promo
Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Leprechaun and Pot of Gold Promos
item.comment: I really like this kind of creative expansions with that extra stack of cards beside the center board. Great addition!

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Nethersnare Promo
item.comment: Nice to have your personal monster that you can defeat if you have enough fighting power. Prevents the disappointment having high fighting power and no monster in the center row to use it on.

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Pathwarden Promo
item.comment: Nice card

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – The Rat King Promo
item.comment: Nice idea, putting the Giant Rats on top of the other cards when the Rat King comes into play

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Vedah, Sage of Swords Promo
item.comment: Can be very powerfull if you draw the right cards.

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Void Mesmer Promo
item.comment: Too powerfull card I think

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Vortex Promo
item.comment: Don't like those flipping/luck cards

item.name: Ascension: Darkness Unleashed
item.comment: The transforming is a nice idea, but as you need energy to do so, I have the same problem with this game as with 'Ascension: Rise of Vigil' (see comments at that game).

item.name: Ascension: Immortal Heroes
item.comment: After the 'Fait' from Return of the Fallen and the 'Unite' from Storm of Souls, again a very good addition with the 'Soul Gem'-cards. Hopefully they can keep adding good new principles to future additions :D

item.name: Ascension: Return of the Fallen
item.comment: In fact this is, with exception for the 'Fate'-concept the same game as the base game. But you have some nice cards in there.

item.name: Ascension: Return of the Fallen – Kythis, the Gatekeeper Promo
item.comment: I think this one is too powerfull: if you're lucky that there was one with big points underneath it, you get a lot of points at once

item.name: Ascension: Rise of Vigil
item.comment: In their eager of adding something new, something more, the energy is for me the bridge to far. It slows the game down a lot as you will have some crapy energy on your hand at the wrong moments, which kills one of the big advantages of 'Ascension': it plays fast.

item.name: Ascension: Samael Claus
item.comment: I like the idea beneath it a lot: you can anoy your opponents with 'Samael's Little Helpers', but if that opponent can slay Samael Claus himselve, the suddenly become a big help. Great idea!

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls
item.comment: The nice (little) extra's in comparison with 'Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer' are nice. However there is no need to have both of them (unless you want extra cards). If you have neither definitely choose for 'Ascension: Storm of Souls'.

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Askara of Fortune Promo
Ascension: Storm of Souls – Assimilation Plant Promo
item.comment: It's 9 points, so always wanna have this :D

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Cetra, Guide of Ogo Promo
item.comment: This card can be way too powerfull!

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Cobra, the Sordid Promo
item.comment: The Bully - card. No wonder Jan bought this in our 1 play so far :D

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Ender of Days Promo
item.comment: It seems horribly powerfull, but 10 is really a lot, so you won't be able to slay this in the beginning of the game as your deck will be to weak.

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Hedron Flare Promo
item.comment: Good card to have, but they don't seems to be that much Mechana Hero's :s

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Rat Queen Promo
item.comment: It's just a rip-off of the Rat King; a bit disappointing

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Ring of Life Promo
item.comment: How good it is really depends on how many Lifebound heros you have

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls – Soul Collector Promo
item.comment: Great if you go for a fighting monster strategy

item.name: Asgard
item.comment: Totally my type of game, but heavy and a game you have to play at least once to see the flow going.

item.name: Assyria
item.comment: Good game, almost no luck, but not too difficult; It's like Sylla, you have to play it a few times to understand all the possibilities/strategies

item.name: Atlantis
item.comment: It's quick & easy, but you have to accept that you need some luck drawing the right cards

item.name: Atlantis: Ikarus Expansion
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Atlantis: Variante "Schiffe"
item.comment: Very simple addition, but one that offers some excellent extra choices during the game.

item.name: Aton
item.comment: Aton is a game that has been dumped by Queen Games, which made the expactations were low. On the other hand, the average rating is 7.00 (01/09/2013), which is rather good. I think 7 is indeed the perfect score for this game. It's a good game, but won't overwhelm you with excitement.

item.name: Auf Teufel komm raus
item.comment: Light, amusing game where you have to press-your-luck

item.name: Augustus
item.comment: It's a sort of sofisticated bingo. But it doesn't take long to play and stays fun while you're playing and you can control things a bit by investing in the right cards.

item.name: Augustus: Maximus Promo Card
item.comment: Ok Feature

item.name: Automobile
item.comment: Very good mechanics, but never play this with people who like to think for a long time!!!!

item.name: Avanti
item.comment: Light game where you wanna outguess your opponents and land on them so you move very fast. I'm afraid that in certain cases it can take too long to play for what it is.

item.name: Aztlán
item.comment: Play this only with 4!

item.name: Babel
item.comment: Not sure about this one. It felt to me that it had the same problem as Arena - Roma II: if one player has a bad hand of cards (a lot of different colors), he can't do almost anything usefull

item.name: Bakong
item.comment: Not bad, but not great either

item.name: Baltimore & Ohio
item.comment:
One play and liked it a lot. But it's the kind of game you'll play only once or twice a year, because:
1) If you plan to play this game, it will be the only one you'll be playing, because of the very long playing time 2) The entire group needs to consist of people who are willing to calculate every move they make
But I most say that it doesn't become boring for the whole 4 hours I've played it and there are some very neat mechanics in this game.;
Second play was with 6 players and liked it more: the shares of 1 company were more divided over different players.

item.name: Baltimore & Ohio Expansion Set
item.comment: I like this kind of mini-expansions :D

item.name: Baltimore & Ohio: Maine Lumber Expansion
item.comment: In the 1 game so far it just stayed in Augusta, without someone taking it.

item.name: Baltimore & Ohio: Norfolk & Western Railroad Expansion
item.comment: It's a good company to the end of the game, as you can jump to 250 in only 2 turns (if the tech level is 5 and you have enough money in your treasury), but not to take early I think.

item.name: Bamboleo
item.comment: Like it

item.name: Banana Matcho
item.comment:
It's with dice, so when playing this, you have to be able that you or your opponent can have a luckt dice roll. However, for the player rolling the fruit dice, it also about controlling your greed: go for that combination that gives you more points or be sure and squize that banana?
Fun kids game, that's also very fun to play as an adult!

item.name: Banana Party
item.comment: Ok to play from time to time, but the problem is that if you're an adult, you kind of see where someone is hanging up his monkey, which of course ain't the intention :s

item.name: Bangkok Klongs
item.comment: Good game, with possible a lot of more dept into it then one might think after 1 play

item.name: Banjooli Cross
item.comment: Maybe a bit better with less, but with 5 it's pure chaos :s

item.name: Baobab
item.comment: A bit too easy for adults.

item.name: Bargain Hunter
item.comment: good card game, but nothing special

item.name: Barony
item.comment:
From the designer of Splendor. Big plus is that turns are also quick. Rules are easy to explain, gaming time is in comparison with the game you get and this game has one of the best player aids ever, as while I was explaining the rules, some other players could already predict the different actions based on the icons.
However, while this is certainly not a bad game, it also doesn't light my fire. It's most of the times quite obvious what to do and it feels more like a race then a game where you are building some kind of engine to gather resources.

item.name: Basari
item.comment: Good cardgame that feels similar to 'Edel, Stein & Reich', so if you like that one, you'll probably like this one also

item.name: Basilica
item.comment: Pure abstract game (you never have the feeling of building a Basilica), which can be a very frustrating one if you're looking for a certain order tile to unblock a situation and it just doesn't come out :s

item.name: Basilica: Festum Fatuorum
item.comment: The Altar-tiles are a good addition as it gives you some defense, the jester I'm not so sure about.

item.name: BasketBoss
item.comment: Not bad, but no wow at all

item.name: Batman: Gotham City Strategy Game
item.comment: Rating based on the original ruleset. However I wanna play it again, using the recommandations of the designer for a shorter game (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/12126698#12126698). Because I liked the game main mechanics and the short ruleset, but disliked the long playing time (2 hours with 3 all new players).

item.name: Battle Sheep
item.comment: Pinguin with sheep. Plays nice and quick.

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition)
item.comment: 1 play against a rather weak opponent. Have to play against a strong one before I can make a final judgement. First impression: you need a certain luck with the dice rolls and certain cards just seem better then others.

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition): Terrors of the Mists Army Pack
item.comment: An extra faction is nice, but I'm wondering if those Undead aren't too strong? Especially the Graveyard is very nice

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition): Great Dragon Reinforcement Pack
item.comment: An extra half point for having the common scenario which seems nice.

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition): Heralds of Dreadfall Army Pack
item.comment: Same thoughts as for 'BattleLore (Second Edition): Terrors of the Mists Army Pack'

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition): Hernfar Guardians Army Pack
item.comment: Extra possibilities for blue...

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition): Warband of Scorn Army Pack
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Bausack
item.comment: Something different

item.name: Bears!
item.comment: This game doesn't get me. It's quick, but I don't find it fun to play.

item.name: Beasty Bar
item.comment: Nice, very enjoyable cardgame with nice artwork and you have to figure out the best move with the cards you have at the current situation.

item.name: Beasty Bar: New Beasts in Town
item.comment: It's basically the same as Beasty Bar, but combined together you can create a lot of replayability.

item.name: Beasty Bar: The Tasmanian Devil
item.comment: You need some luck with the order the animals come out :s

item.name: Beep! Beep!
item.comment: Not my type of game, but in his genre a great one

item.name: Beer & Pretzels
item.comment: Fun to close a gaming evening

item.name: Beer & Pretzels: Purple Coaster Expansion
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Belfort
item.comment: 2 plays and after second play (both with 3 players) I have the impression that this game doesn't seem to work with 3 players. You have 1 player who is behind and when he has to place buildings in a district or has to recruit, he has to screw one of the 2 players that can win. So he is always the kingmaker.

item.name: Belfort: The Expansion Expansion
item.comment:
Assistants as an expansion, we've seen it before in for example 'Manhattan Project - The Second Stage'. But it's a feature I like, so I don't mind that.
A nice idea is that you can use them into 2 ways: for there special power or to get an expansion permit. Those expansion permits can give you some nice points, but you certainly need to work for them and are preferably built before the summer-scoring.
My overall feeling after 1 play is that this is a good expansion, but certainly not a must have that lifts the base game to a higher level.

item.name: Between Two Cities
item.comment: 7 Wonders: The City Building Game. There, all said :-)

item.name: Biblios
item.comment: Rating based on 4-player games. Will it be so good with 3 or 2 players?

item.name: Big Five
item.comment: Nice filler. Ideal if you like Qwirkle and wanna play that kind of game with children.

item.name: Birds on a Wire
item.comment: Not bad, but maybe a bit too simple and a bit overpriced (in Europe) for what it is

item.name: Bison: Thunder on the Prairie
item.comment: Only one play, but liked it a lot

item.name: Black Fleet
item.comment: For me it's a big 2/2 for Space Cowboys. After Splendor they made again a fun game with short ruleset that's easy to explain and with short turns.

item.name: Black Friday
item.comment: After my 1 play so far I was confused. I have an idea of how the mechanism works, but don't know how to 'use' it. I think that once you're stuck, as a short of money, you're out of the race, as the silverprice only continues to rise, it's almost impossible to catch up.

item.name: Black Gold
item.comment:
Rating based on 1 play with 5, which is a bit too much. 4 is probably ideal. I think I'll use the 'faster game' - option next time. I think rating will go up.
Second play: with 4 and the option to end the game after the black train passes the 3-line. It's a descent family game. You'll have to accept that luck is a basic part of this game and you can't controll anything.

item.name: Black Spy
item.comment: Classic trick-taking - game, but it takes too long for my taste (90 mintues with 4 (all new) players :s)

item.name: Black Stories
item.comment: I don't really like this kind of 'games'

item.name: Blackrock City
item.comment:
Sometimes you wonder why a game has such a low average rating and sometimes it's quite clear. In the case of Blackrock City it's quite clear why the average rating is less the 6 (03/08/2013) :s
This game is just never exciting at any point.

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: OK Quick filler.

item.name: The Bloody Inn
item.comment:
This game gave me the same feeling after my first play of Deus: how the hell do you manage this? You have to play this a couple of times to know which cards are in the deck and fully understand what there capable off.
A special note on the artwork: normally I'm more into traditional artwork like that of Klemens Franz, Franz Vohwinkel or Mariano Iannelli, but for this game I must admit that these 'Picasso'-figures really fit with the theme.

item.name: Blox
item.comment: Very nice game, but you have to love abstract

item.name: Blue Moon City: Expansion Tile Sets 1 & 2
Blueprints
item.comment: OK Dice game, but nothing to get really excited about.

item.name: La Boca
item.comment: Normally I'm not into this kind of games, but this is one I really can enjoy. Maybe because you at least have a partner with whom you can suffer trying to solve the puzzle :D?

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Rating after 1 play; definitely wanna play it again, but I think it's not my type of game; Played it a second time (with more players) which was more fun

item.name: Bohnanza Erweiterungs-Set (Revised Edition)
item.comment: Still have to test the 'Order Cards'

item.name: Le Bois des Couadsous
item.comment: This is memory+ or better double memory as you have to remember the shape AND colour of both sides of the card. The flipping of your squirrel which makes that you have to switch from colours to shapes is a nice twist though.

item.name: Bokken Schieten
item.comment: The creation of the island which decides what the point scoring will be at the end of the round really add something different to a for the remainder classic trick-taking game.

item.name: Bonbons
item.comment: Nice little memory-game with a twist

item.name: Booh Booh Castle
item.comment: Light 'outguess-your-opponents'-game for children.

item.name: Boon to be Wild!
item.comment: To put it simple: this is Boonanza+. The only extra is the Wild Beans (and some minor rules changes). Imho not worth buying if you already own Boonanza, but buy this if you don't own it yet and like Boonanza.

item.name: Boonanza: Al Caboon
item.comment: It's a bit disappointing that they recycled beans (like blue bean) from the original game and didn't make the effort to create 7 new beans; How do you beat the Bean Mafia?

item.name: Boonanza: Het Dobbelspel
item.comment: The basic idea is very neat: you can also score in the turns of other players, which makes that there is no downtime. For me it personally takes too long: for me a dice game is something short that you play in 15 - 20 mintues, our game took 40 minutes, which is the time you need for the card game. Therefore only a 6 instead of a 7.

item.name: Bora Bora
item.comment:
1) Ik like games of Stefan Feld really a lot 2) I sold 6 copies of this game on 1 day, I've never done this in the past 4 years! 3) The average rating is > 8.5 at this moment (17/02/2013)
All this made I played this game with very high expectations. And I must admit that I was somewhat disappointed after my first play. What I missed, and for me is typical for Feld, is that 1 original gameplay-element that makes the game really others then others. For me Bora Bora is a sort of Trajan (for example Status track Senate; hyperfocus on only a few of different possilities to score points) with a flavor of The Casltles of Burgundy (dice to activate actions; the earlier you built your buildings, the more points you get). Off course Trajan and Castles of Burgundy are some (very) good games, so there is nothing wrong with recylcing some of those principles. But it somewhat bothers me that an author recycles (so soon) his game principles, it reminds me of what Reiner Knizia is doing lately and I think we can all agree that it went downhill very fast with the quality of the games he releases lately by doing that.
Maybe just my expectations were too high. My guess is that my rating can still go up, but certainly won't decrease :D

item.name: Bora Bora: Orange God Tiles
item.comment: They are usefull, very usefull, but the way to get them is pure luck, which makes it a rather bad expansion.

item.name: The Boss
item.comment: Good card-deduction game

item.name: Boss Kito
item.comment: Just OK. A bit too light for me

item.name: Botswana
item.comment: One of the better filler games, ideal for closing a gaming night

item.name: Brass
item.comment: Only one play and no 'wow'-feeling;

item.name: BraveRats
item.comment: Only played the basic game. I think the drafting variant will be far more challenging, so rating might go up.

item.name: Bremerhaven
item.comment:
I'm a bit surprised by the very low score of this game. If I read the comments, lots of people are turned off by the blind bidding (a concept I personally don't mind at all as it creates some tension while playing), which can't be a big deal: just agree to play your bidding cards openly.
I enjoyed my 1 play so far. It took us 2 hours+, but wasn't boring for a second. It's a real brainburner and in the beginning you have to get used to the special approach of this game with the time markers, especially with the contracts, that only give you a pay-out when the last time marker has been removed.

item.name: Brettspiel Adventskalender 2015
item.comment: Very nice idea, especially for a fan of mini-expansions like myself :-)

item.name: Bridge Troll
item.comment: Light game, not bad, but a bit too repetitive for my taste. Liked his Trollhalla and certainly Road to Canterbury a lot more.

item.name: Briefcase
item.comment:
Is it a deck-building game? Certainley yes. Is it a resource management game? A little bit: you need resources but instead of naming them paper, concrete,...they could just put A, B,... on them. It's not that steel is harder to get then concrete or so, or that you need certain buildings to produce certain resources. You just take the cards/resources you need or can take if they or blocked and you can't move the block.
So for me it's a deck-building game. Is it a good one? Yes. Should you buy this if you like/own Dominion and like the deck-building genre? Sure. Should you own this if you own already Dominion, Ascension, Thunderstone and other Core Worlds? Imho, I don't think so. I like it as a game (otherwise I wouldn't rate it a 7), the playing time is good and if someone would ask me to play it, I'll happily do so, but it just doens't feel that refreshing, that new anymore.

item.name: Briefcase: Board Game Factory
item.comment: You need a good deal of luck to get the extra Buy cards, especially in the beginning of the game. It's also more interesting with 4 players then with 2 as you can get at most respectively 3 or just 1 Buy Card

item.name: Briefcase: Bonus Companies
item.comment: We always like extra variety :)

item.name: Briefcase: City Hall
item.comment: I like the City Hall cards as they give you the possibility to do something useful with your Obstacle - cards, but I'm not fond of the Tax Collectors

item.name: Briefcase: Government Bonus
item.comment: I like those where you need 4 times the same resource as it is really something you have to aim for. I don't like the one that gives an extra point to the first player who buys the important resource as you have little control when does are available and it's pure luck who is the first who can buy them. The same for the first 1 to build a red building.

item.name: Brieven uit Whitechapel
item.comment: One play and I'm not really convinced: sure there where the tense moments, where you find clues and feel like you're catching him, but when you you've lost track it's just random moves and calling out numbers in the hoop you'll find something and that's quite repetitive/dull.

item.name: Broom Service
item.comment:
I like Wie Verhext! a lot, so I had high expectations of this one, which is always dangerous :-) But this boardgame version of Wie verhext! was completely able to forfill them. The board also changes the game so that it has a diffenrent playing expierence then Wie Verhext!, which is off course a good thing, but keeps the fun part of selecting the roles and chosing for brave or cowardly when it's your turn (but I also like the fact that the starting player ain't forced anymore to chose brave). Also a plus about this version is that it's better with less players as there are fewer roles to select from and a certain number of roles give minus points for chosing them in a particular round.
Conclusion: A job well done!

item.name: Brug naar de Hemel
item.comment: Much better then 'The Pillars of the Earth'. Has the potential of becoming an 8

item.name: Bruges
item.comment:
After Bora Bora and Rialto not being the 'great' games I expected them to be, this one is again 'bingo' for me. It's also totally in the style of HiG with short rules, easy to explain, but just enough options to keep this game interesting all the time. Very nice mechanism with the threat-markers you'll receive being from the dice who will give you lots of money and a clever idea that every card is a person who does something you would like to have, but you wanna/must use the card for all other kind of things. Great game concept!
The language dependancy is however a bit too much for me (it's the same level as with Macao), some I'm going to wait for the English release, or, who knows, maybe even the Dutch release (common 999 Games, WGG,...).
Edit: Thank you White Goblin Games :-)

item.name: Bruges: The City on the Zwin
item.comment: The rivers is by far the best module as it makes building canal far most interesting

item.name: Brügge: Die Haustiere
item.comment: OK add-on

item.name: Bruxelles 1893
item.comment:
Apparently this is the first game this designer has made. I don't now how much he has worked on this or if he had a lot of help from the design team of Pearl Games, but I all can say is: congratulations!
This is totally my kind of game: worker placement, tight action spots (at least with 4 players, probably less tight with 2 or 3) and different ways to score points.
The only minus for me is the really ugly art from Alexandre Roche. He's never been my favourite graphic artist, but this is really the ugliest of all the work I've seen from him.

item.name: Buckaroo!
item.comment: At level 3, you have to be very carefull :s

item.name: The Builders: Middle Ages
item.comment: Nice card game with just enough depth and playing time

item.name: Bullfrog Goldfield
item.comment: For me this game didn't work. They took the idea of an 18XX-game and wanted to add some 'things of there own', which makes that the game is too stiff & unnecessary complex for my taste. I couldn't play this game just on intuition and that rarely happens to me, even with an 18XX - game where you also have to do (a lot of) math.

item.name: Die Burgen von Burgund
item.comment: It's like Macao: less players is better

item.name: Die Burgen von Burgund: Die 5. Erweiterung
item.originalname: The Castles of Burgundy: 5th Expansion – Pleasure Garden
item.comment: The idea is nice, but they have a different shade of colour, so you can by far which tiles are from this expansion :s

item.name: Burgenland
item.comment: If you're looking for a good family game that's easy to explain and fast-paced to play, then this is your game.

item.name: Buster Balloon
item.comment: I can't understand why this game was nominated for 'toy of the year 2012'. There is no strategy, no educational element at all. It's just trowing dice and waiting for the balloon to burst. I personally didn't see the fun of this.

item.name: C3K: Creatures Crossover Cyclades/Kemet
item.comment: Is this a well thought commercial tric to make people by 2 base games? Well tried anyway :D

item.name: Cacao
item.comment: Good tile-laying game, seen the game length even a sort of filler game with enough interesting decisions to be made

item.name: Cacao: Volcanoes
item.comment: Not that spectaculair.

item.name: Cadwallon: City of Thieves
item.comment: My one play was exciting, you have tension in the game, but there is not so much control and one good or bad dice roll can make a hell of a difference especially at the end when you wanna get your thieves of the board; What I find a minus about this game is that you can't choose to play defensive: the board is so small that if they wanna attack you, they will attack you.

item.name: Café Melange
item.comment: I like this kind of games. It's quite simple to explain and easy to play, but it does really matter which guest you put on what table. Also by the end you have to look for opportunities, because sometimes 1 card can be enough to put down a guest. Only minus is that you need a certain luck to get the right cards when an opportunity comes by.

item.name: Call to Glory
item.comment: The rules are so simple, but work extremely well and make you have to consider carefully when (= at which number) you should put out your cards and which card you discarded when you have to!

item.name: Camel Up
item.comment: Betting on races, I always spontaneously have to think at Long Shot, but I have to realise I'll probably never encounter such a great fun game again. However if you see this as a fun, fast family game, you'll probably have a good time playing this

item.name: Camel Up: Supercup
item.comment: Only played modules 1 & 2 so far. I'm not sure if the Photographer can't break the game too much. The extra dice for the camel that is last in the race is great however, as it makes sure no camel is eliminated too soon in the race and it makes early bets more tricky.

item.name: Canal Mania
item.comment: It's a good game in the sence that everything works, but there is no wow-factor with this game. It's a sort of combination of elements from Railroad Tycoon and Ticket to Ride, so really nothing new here if you played these before.

item.name: Canalis
item.comment:
Tile placement games aren't exactly my cup of tea, so a 7 for this kind of game is quite good :-)
I think this game is also best with 2 and possible with 3, but I can't imagine you wanna play this with 4, as for my taste it was already to crowded with 3 :s

item.name: Canterbury
item.comment: To understand why this game has such a high average rating, you simply have to play it. After reading the rules, I also had the feeling 'is that it, why are people rating this so high?'. Until you start playing: you only have the choice out of 3 possible actions, but which to chose when and to see the opportunities on the board depicting 25 districts is really crucial in this game and will give you a tense feeling while playing.

item.name: The Capitals
item.comment: If I would rate the gaming mechanism itself, I would rate this game with a 7.5. But my lower score is the result of the AP that comes with this game, resulting in a (much) too long gaming time.

item.name: El Capitán
item.comment:
Had some high expectations about this one, but it didn't meet those high expectations; The fortresses seem absolutely necessary to be build (quick and on the big scoring places) if you wanna have a chance to win this game; It's a dry game, but that doesn't bother me.
Wanna play it again and that play probably will decide if this is a keeper or not.

item.name: Cappuccino
item.comment: Ok abstract game which has the clear advantage that it plays quick, even with 4 players.

item.name: Captain Cool
item.comment: Easy rules, but damn hard to play. You don't wanna be first in the 4th round!

item.name: Captain Jack's Gold
item.comment: Played by the basic rules and then it's something between an OK and a Good game. It's a bit too easy, too repetitive; I'm curious about the expanded rules though, maybe they can provide this game that little extra it needs to be a good game

item.name: Captains of Industry
item.comment:
Good economics game.
Gaming time can be a bit long however, due to the uncertain timing of the end of an age. A fixed timing mechanism would have been better, or one that you can estimate better (like X buildings built or so).

item.name: Caravelas
item.comment: This game has one big problem: there is one optimal route, so if you know this one, it becomes boring and pure luck (will you lose a ship or not when crossing the Ocean border?)

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: A real gateway game, but as a gateway game I prefer settlers of Catan or Ticket to Ride

item.name: Carcassonne: Abbey & Mayor
item.comment: the mayor, the abbey and the big farm are some nice additions

item.name: Carcassonne: Over Hill and Dale
item.comment: You can't say this is bad, but it's just again yet another Carcassonne with a little twist (which feels Very similar to the Builders & Traders expansion).

item.name: Carcassonne: Stille Zuidzee
item.comment: Carcassonne revisited. Not bad, not great either.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Castle
item.comment: It really requires another way of 'Carcassonne-thinking'

item.name: Carcassonne: The Cult
item.comment: The one who has to initiate 'the fight' has usually a disadvantage, so he won't initiate the challenge

item.name: Carcassonne: The Plague
item.comment: Those who love the 'destructive' expansions "The Tower" & "The Princess & The Dragon", will also enjoy this mini-expansion; I personally don't

item.name: Cardcassonne
item.comment: With 2 I give it a 7; with 3 or 4 the game will be more tense I guess, so it will be probably an 8; Therefore a 7.5 :)

item.name: Cargo Noir
item.comment: Good family game, which I still liked a lot after 3 plays, so increased rating (7.5->8)

item.name: Caro
item.comment: Well, it's abstract, that's for sure :-) But it's no Blox I'm afraid.

item.name: Carson City
item.comment: OK game, but I don't understand the hype

item.name: Carson City: Gold & Guns
item.comment: Gives more variation in scoring points.

item.name: Carson City: The Indian
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Cartagena 2. The Pirate's Nest
item.comment: Plays kind of different then the original, which is good, but the original is somewhat better

item.name: Castaways of Deadmans Bay
item.comment: They are some neat ideas in this game: the fact that you have to defend on 3 different fronts, the powering up and the theme (pushing someone of the plank :D) are some nice items. What it ruins it for me is the luck factor. I won my 1 play, but I didn't get the feeling I won because I had some great strategy, I won because I was lucky that I could block my opponent more then he could me. It's a pity, but this ruined it for me.

item.name: Castellan
item.comment: 100% abstract 2-player. Normally I like abstract, but this one requires some spatial insight, a quality I don't posses. So not a bad game, just not my cup of tea.

item.name: Castelli
item.comment: I think this is the kind of game you have to play a few times to understand the mechanics a little bit. Placing a heraldic tile determines who can get which resources, but if it is a rock area, you should also consider who will be able to build there and if he can take majority for some cities/villages. That makes it a bit more complicated then just flipping a tile and putting it down.

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Only one play but really liked it; quite refreshing

item.name: Castle Panic: Any Color Hero Promo
item.comment: Handy

item.name: Castle Panic: The Dark Titan
item.comment: Seems to be make the game less difficult then the Wizard's Tower, but only played with Agnarok at level 1.

item.name: Castle Panic: The Wizard's Tower
item.comment: The Wizard Cards are very powerfull, but the monsters are also much tougher. So if you lose the Wizard's Tower quite early, it's almost impossible to win imho

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 1st Expansion – New Player Boards
item.comment: Makes it a bit harder to play (and castles more precious) with the extra rule you have to have a direct connection with a castle

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 2nd Expansion – New Hex Tiles
item.comment: Some nice extra tiles (especially the goat and the park).

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 4th Expansion – Monastery Boards
item.comment: It's a nice extra feature, but I doubt it's worth playing for.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: The Cloisters
Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: Probably not my kind of game.

item.name: Category 5: Luggage Promo Card
item.comment: OK feature

item.name: The Cave
item.comment: Good game, but you have to really count all your steps with all the food available, because missing 1 will costs you 1 or more entire turns :s

item.name: The Cave: Additional Cave Tiles
item.comment: The double feature is nice, but hard sometimes :s

item.name: Caverna: Christmas Chamber
item.comment:
PnP;
It's more a gimmick then an expansion :-)

item.name: Caverna: LARP and Cosplay Postcard
item.comment:
PnP;
I guess they can be usefull is some circumstances (like the LARP chamber if you are going for all armed dwarves).

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment:
Don't know what to think about this game after 1 play. I certainly like it. It's definitely a sort of Agricola+. However getting food for your dwarves, doens't seem to be so cut-throat as in Agricola, at least that's the feeling I had. I never got a real food engine, but you can get it on a lot of places and the fact that you can convert your animals into food without the need of a cooking place, seems to facilitate things a lot.
The lack of cards is for me a bit of a bummer, as for me there were the salt & pepper of Agricola. Here you have more common buildings to chose from.
The biggest plus of Caverna is that you have even more strategies to go for to score points.

item.name: Cavum
item.comment: It's hard to give this game a rating: I like the mechanics, but if I would enjoy this game strongly depends of whom I'm playing with. Never play this game with people who like to think for a long time before making their move!!

item.name: Caylus Expansion: The Jeweller
item.comment: Printed en glued from the Ystari-website

item.name: Celestia
item.comment: Nice, quick family game with some push-your-luck - element in it.

item.name: Charly
item.comment: Just light and fun

item.name: Cherokee
item.comment: OK card game; Increased rating after two 4-player games (7 -> 7.5); Not good with 2

item.name: Chicago Express: Narrow Gauge & Erie Railroad Company
Chicken Caesar
item.comment:
Don't know why, but the game didn't get me. While playing, it felt like the game was playing itself, rather then I was playing the game.
I mean, for the Aediles in most cases they just want a high tax rate, because it gives them more money (excuse me, I mean Frumenti), and most money is the goal of the game. The Praetors will place all Vigil-cards on locations where they have roosters and the traditors where they have none. The Censor simply choses the rooster of a player who is doing well at the moment and the Consuls, why shouldn't they approve the proposed monument if the pile of money underneath is big enough, after all, again, the goal is to have the most money, and maybe 1 player would have a greater return, but you also win against the other players.
In some odd cases an other choice can be more logic, but for 90 - 95% of the time that is what every rooster in every office will do.
I guess the flavor of this game should come from negotiations, but even there, there is little margin to convince a player from doing something at a reasonable price.

item.name: Chicken Caesar: Fowl Play Expansion
item.comment: No added value at all

item.name: China
item.comment: It's the same game as 'Kardinaal & Koning', but with nicer components

item.name: China: The Embassies
item.comment: Ok expansion, doens't add that much

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: Original Alea; new and shrinkwrapped

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment:
Reprint from QWG;
I had some high expectations of this one, but was a bit disapointed after my one play. The game is JUST trading, there is really nothing also to it. Then I prefer a game like Genoa a lot more, where you also have to trade, but there is a lot more going on.

item.name: Chocolatl
item.comment: Not a lot of strategy, just a light bidding game

item.name: Chosŏn
item.comment:
Like King of New York is the better version of King of Tokyo, this feels like the better version of Koryo, as it has more bells attatched to it. I wished designers would make 'the best'-version right from the start :s
The only thing this game needs is 4 overview-cards which is handy when you play the game for the first time.

item.name: CIA
item.comment:
A game by Kramer + winner of the Spiel des Jahres 1986 + deduction, CIA was a game I just added to my collection because of that, but strayed unopened for 4 years in my collection. Finally got to play this, immediately with both variants, as all players are experienced players. Were I thought it had a deduction element in it, I seemed to be wrong. It's more an outguessing game, were it's helpful to know who has which secret colour.
It's not a bad game, but you sort of feel that this is an 'old' game of almost 20 years old. Those games have some advantages though: easy rules and a thin rulebook and quite straightforward play.

item.name: Cinque Terre
item.comment: Basically the harder pick-up-and-delivery - game.

item.name: Circus Grandioso
item.comment: The starting hand is very determinating, especially with 2

item.name: Citrus
item.comment: Typical DLP-games: only a limited number of actions to chose from and timing of what to do when is crucial. For me the best DLP-game I've played so far (being Bangkok Klongs and Siberia (board- and cardgame) the others)).

item.name: City Hall
item.comment:
MSRP of Scoville is $ 59,95. For City Hall it's also $ 59,95. I can't imagine why, as most of the box is filled with air and you only get a board, 4 sets of meeples and some cards.
The game itself is OK. But with 2 it will be extremely boring I think (haven't tested it yet), with 3 it's OK and 4 seems to be the true shining number for this game. But again, like Scoville, there is nothing new here: buildings that increase or decrease in value according to the types that are put next to each other: seen that that. The bidding system: nothing new, seen it before. Scoring system: multiplier, so increase each factor of your product, seen that.
Not that it doesn't work, you can't say that, but it becomes a bit too repetitive near the end to stay interesting.
I hope that Captains of Industry will provide me with a different feeling, because otherwise Tasty Minstrel Games seems to become the publisher who puts out mediocre games that don't add anything new to the games who are already out there.

item.name: City of Horror
item.comment: This is a really inventive game with some gorgious artwork. I like to play this kind of games from time to time, but you have to have to right group to play this sort of game. Not everybody like negotiation as a game mechanic and not everybody can take it when they would get outvoted. That is why I rate it 7.5 instead of 8, because I won't be able to play this with everybody in my gaming group.

item.name: City of Horror: Lawn Mower
item.comment: Nice action card to have! Same rating as base game.

item.name: City of Iron
item.comment: This game is totally up my alley. Also finally a Kickstarter-game that is above mediocre level. It's a sort of deckbuilding-game (but you are responsible for the order of your cards yourself, as well as how fast/slow you will cycle through your deck), where you want majority's in certain (but the most as possible :D) goods? therefore you need mostly money, but sometimes also science. Very nice artwork also!

item.name: City Tycoon
item.comment:
One play with 5 and that was a bit too much for my taste. Probably best with 3 or 4.
Good combination of tile laying and resource management.

item.name: Click Clack Lumberjack
item.comment: Fun to play when in the right mood

item.name: The Climbers
item.comment: It looked nice and as a friend of mine talked me about this was, I was in doubt to buy this at essen, but it was rather expensive. Glad I didn't buy it, as it is not my style of game.

item.name: Clocks
item.comment: Played what has to be the almost final version. Again a good game from the guys of Sandtimer that will appeal to as well family as 'real' gamers. Good mix of strategy and luck.

item.name: Coconuts
item.comment: Just simple fun

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: I'm not a fan of word games, but it has the same power as Star Realms: it's very short, so you'll probably just play an other game right after your first one. We even played 4 the first time we played this :-)

item.name: Colonia
item.comment: For me the playing time is a bit too long, otherwise I would give it an 8

item.name: Colonialism
item.comment: Nothing new here: an area control/majority game. But the chaos factor and certainly the gaming time are too long.

item.name: Coloretto: The Extra Cards
item.comment: I only like the card that makes the first one who passes draw an extra blind card from the deck. It can make the difference near the end where a player who has a good chance to win, just can't pass after 1 good card to maintain his position.

item.name: Colorful Serengeti
item.comment: Reaction game for kids. Was OK to play. In fact it's 'Vlotte Geesten', but with cards.

item.name: Colossal Arena
item.comment: Somehow I find the mechanics 'refreshing'. It's an old game, but like the combination of betting & elimination. Probably only good with 4 or 5 though. Also don't like the rule that the game end if the card deck is empty.

item.name: Colt Express
item.comment: 1 play, but didn't find this game refreshing enough to keep in the collection.

item.name: Compounded
item.comment:
As a civil engineer in chemistry, I like the fact that there is a game with a Chemistry-theme.
The exploding of compounds is also a nice twist, but for the rest I'm afraid we've seen it all before: evolve to take more elements, store more elements, put more elements on cards or being able to claim more cards and even the upgrades are classic as a pipet who gives you a better trade ratio or a book that gives you the ability to take 1 element back when you finish a compound.
It's also a bit long, as it becomes somehow repetitive near the end, for what it is, but with experienced players you can probably bring playing time down somewhat.
Plus is that it's easy to explain and all mechanics are logic.

item.name: Compounded: Chemical Chaos
item.comment: I love the 9 positive cards (always hooray for more variety) , but not the ones that let you steal finished compounds for example

item.name: Concordia
item.comment: A game of Mac Gerdts without a rondel? The designer has gone crazy :-) But he has done an excellent job. Only 4 pages of rules, but so hard to master and get things going the way you want them to. I like this a lot.

item.name: Concordia: Britannia & Germania
item.comment:
Brittania: excellent map, very tight and excellent for 3 players. 8/10
Germania: hated it. Far too large which makes that you won't get that many resources from other players with the Prefect-cards as everybody has the tendency to create his 'own' provinces. You should only consider playing this map when being with 5 players. 6/10

item.name: Concordia: Salsa
item.comment: The salt and forum-tiles are very nice additions that smoothly integrate with the base game without adding game length.

item.name: Coney Island
item.comment: Michael Schacht at his best: fast, fun, not too difficult but with enough depth. One minus point that you can also have with his other designs as Zooloretto: If players aren't equally skilled, the mistakes of the unexperienced players (for instance let one player buy all the newspapers)can make the decission who will win.

item.name: Coney Island: Giant Wheel
item.comment: No added value at all

item.name: Constantinopolis
item.comment: Good, but a bit too repetitive near the end

item.name: Container
item.comment: Great Game!

item.name: Continental Express
item.comment: You need some luck with the timing of the cards, but as a quick filler this is more then OK.

item.name: The Convoy
item.comment: Typical game of 'Ignacy Trzewiczek': TONS of icons, with lots of single shots, which makes that you'll have to look up a lot what every card does and creates lots of downtime. For that reason I decreased my rating by 1. For the rest it's like Revolver, set in the world of Neuroshima Hex.

item.name: Core Worlds
item.comment:
When I saw the Dicetower video review of this game, I thought, yet another deck building game, I don't need to own this. But as I won it with the BGG-contest, I owned it anyway :).
After 1 play I must say it surprised me in a positive way. Energy & actions are really tight, which requires carefull planning. There is however no real interaction in this game, except that they can buy the card you were going for from the Central Zone. It's also hard to get an idea of who is winning, so even if you have a Tactics that can give minus -1 energy to another player, who to pick?

item.name: Core Worlds: Galactic Orders
item.comment: Very good expansion, especially the Galactic Orders themselves. Before you just bought the card from the Central Zone that seems to be the most powerfull, now you'll consider a 'weaker' one that has the icon that you are collecting. Also nice that you have to maintain the balance between keeping majority and use them to advance in the game.

item.name: Core Worlds: Galactic Orders Promo Pack
item.comment: Only 1 new Core World, that's very lame as an expansion (because who the hell cares about flavor text?)

item.name: Core Worlds: Revolution
item.comment: This expansion adds more possibilities to the game, more ways to score points, so all things I love. However it creates also extra text every player should read and thus more downtime. Therefore in the further I will only use those cards that expand the Galactic Order - expansion and not the adjustments or other stuff.

item.name: Cornish Smuggler
item.comment: The core mechanism seems nice, but what really, for a 1000%, ruins it for this game are the cards. They make this an Ameritrash-game where you can't built up something nice and secure as 1 single card can ruin in all. For instance: I was ready to sell in Penzance (where I also had a secret storehouse) and I really needed the money as I had only 1 gold left, when Surya played a card by whom he could replace my agent with 1 of his and there was absolutely nothing I could do about it. What a terrible playing experience, for me NEVER again!

item.name: Cornucopia
item.comment: Only one play, but that was really dull. If people understand what risk management is, they just take the bidding card that allows then to take one more card as you only lose one point (yellow token). And then the only thing you do is flipping cards for 45 minutes...

item.name: Cornwall
