item.comment: A tile-laying game that I like, this must be added to the collection :-)

item.name: Corto
item.comment: This game is chaos with markers getting on and off all the time and characters getting killed. You also need some luck, because if you don't have any characters in your hand, you probably do so much. But it plays fast and is enjoyable for the 40 minutes it last.

item.name: Council of Four
item.comment: Quite light (especially in comparison with Tzolk'in :D), but turns are quite straightforward and therefore fast. Chaining is imho clearly the way to go and the random set-up of the bonus tokens will determine what the best position(s) are to start.

item.name: Courtier
item.comment:
After the pleasant acquaintance with Mercante, I looked forward to play another game from the 'Tempest'-line. This is OK, but certainly not as good as Mercante. This is more an 'elbow'-game: if you need the same courtier as an other player (and can't take the Minister or have a card that lets you skip him for an influence cube), you can keep on screwing eachother :s
Plus for this game is the playing time: less then an hour with 4 unexperienced players is just the right amount of screwing time :D

item.name: CO₂
item.comment:
Let there be no doubt about it: this is a pure gamers' game for those who love strategy and no luck. And in it's genre it is 1 very great game!
I already liked Vinhos from this designer, but I like this one even more as it is more streamlined (you don't have the complex Fair-part here), but with still some little rules here and there you have to remember not to forget to apply them. It's really cuththroat to get things done in CO2 and you have to be willing to give something to someone else or the planet will be screwed (a very nice feature this part).

item.name: CO₂: The Arctic Expansion
item.comment: Only 3 cards, but it makes the game harder as your CO2-level will increase more rapidely

item.name: Craftsmen
item.comment:
It works, it's not annoying, but takes far too long for what it is.
I think it would be a far better rule that if you can look at the top 3 buildings of a deck, you would have the choice to put the 2 unchosen buildings on top or at the bottom of the deck. Now it's pure luck when looking for a certain type of building to claim a bonus.
And why not provide every player an overview of what you need to claim the bonus tiles, or put extra markers in, just like in Helvetia were this concept was first used ;-)

item.name: Crazy Creatures of Dr. Doom
item.comment: For me the best of the 5 tins WGG released. Probably because it's the most tactical of the 5.

item.name: Crazy Lab
item.comment: It's a sort of Sticheln, but a little bit more complex, as in worst case you have to consider 3 colors (trump, your plus and your minus color). However rounds seems to be faster then in Sticheln and this is also better with less players I think.

item.name: Crôa!
item.comment: I'm wondering why this is consindered as a children's game? Off corse, in the beginning there is some luck involved as the tiles are still face down. But if the tiles remain open, you need some clever gameplay to make smart use of the different elements in order to eliminate your opponents playing pieces. I almost felt like chess, but where each square does something different instead of every piece that makes a different move.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: It's nice to play this kind of games (flicking games) from time to time, but this one is rather expensive :s

item.name: Crooks
item.comment: OK filler

item.name: Crows
item.comment: Good, quick game; Nice design & game material; Don't think this is good with 2

item.name: Crude: The Oil Game
item.comment:
The first part of the game is rather fun, where you built out your consortium of refineries, gasstations and oil wells in an economic interesting period to invest in especially refineries and gasstations.
But then it's a sort of dice fest and you just wait until you arrive at an economic period where your asset's value is high enough to sell everything so you can get past the 750 million. This last part takes too long imho and hopefully the events don't screw things up too much for you as there is for example a 'high taxes'-event by whom you have to pay $ 20 for each refinery and $ 15 for each gasstation.

item.name: Cuba
item.comment: Good game with good mechanics, but nothing new if you played games like Puerto Rico before

item.name: Cuba: El Presidente
item.comment: Extra laws add extra randomness, which is nice; Would never play 8 rounds as the base game already takes 2+ hours

item.name: Cuba: Hazienda
item.comment:
Totally didn't have to buy this as it is already included in the El Presidente - expansion.
9 points is a lot, but I think it's too much effort (you need and cigars and rhum) too get this engine started.

item.name: Cuba: Spielecafé
item.comment: Only one play, but I'm wondering if this tile ain't to powerfull

item.name: Cubist
item.comment: It does it job as a fast filler game, but in our region (Europe) it's too high in price for what you get.

item.name: Cubo
item.comment: Throw your dice and see as fast as possible the best combinations concerning same numbers are straights. that's it, and that for 6 rounds, which became boring for me after already 4 rounds.

item.name: La Cucaracha
item.comment: Nice, silly fun

item.name: Cup King
item.comment: See this game as a mix of some strategy with a good dose of luck and you will have a good time playing this.

item.name: CV
item.comment: Lighter, OK family game

item.name: CV: Gossip
item.comment: Add's more gaming time and that's not good for this kind of lighter game. Also brings more negative gameplay with the gossip-cards. The Fate - cards however are a nice alternative for the misfortune.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment:
See the potential, but as in my one game I had no opposition, it wasn't an exciting feeling.
2nd gameplay in april 2012: way too long (> 3 hours), but very tense and was never bored. Increased rating (7.5->8)

item.name: Cyclades: Hades
item.comment: Great expansion as it adds some very nice things as the extra creatures, the heroes and the extra god Hades (which is very powerfull), making last god before Apollo often very interesting!

item.name: Cyclades: Hecate
item.comment: Ok extra

item.name: Cyclades: The Manticore
item.comment: Ok extra

item.name: D-Day Dice
item.comment: Rating based on 1 play on the 'Exercise Tiger'-board. For me this was a bit too easy. It's also a bit solitaire co-operative: You do your thing, you make sure to stay alive and sometimes you have a combo where you give your fellow players extra soldiers, but for the main part everybody is focusing on his thing.

item.name: Danger 13
item.comment: Nice game to end the evening

item.name: Darjeeling
item.comment: I like this kind of games

item.name: Dark Matter
item.comment: The flipping of the action cards is what should make this game different from other ones, because for the rest you just are trying to collect resources for conquering planets who will give you points and special actions. But that 'special' part is a bit of a fuzz as you can flip in 2 directions and it's not quite obvious when to flip in which direction.

item.name: Darwinci
item.comment: The mechanics look great on paper, but they don't seem to work: everybody just puts his stones on one tile, often his own so that he gets his stones back.

item.name: Daxu
item.comment: I like outguessing my opponents :-)

item.name: Dead Man's Draw
item.comment: Pure push-your-luck - game whit some nice bells and extra's

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment:
The game mechanic 'co-oprative play', I came in touch through 'Pandmic' (like many others I pressume); I liked it and played lots of games in the same genre from the tons of co-operative games that came out in the slipstream of Pandemic. But after a while I became bored with this mechanic, as in there core, they were clones of Pandemic with some other some and twists that weren't exciting for me. Even the praised 'Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on The Cursed Island' couldn't excite me.
For the first time since long, I had a positive feeling after playing dead of Winter, a co-operative game. I think what does it for is the simple addition of the secret missions. It makes that while in the core it stays a co-operative game, it's not that sure you/everybody will win when you complete the common objective.

item.name: Deadwood
item.comment: It's with dice, so you have to be lucky from times to times. One play so far and I amused myself a lot :D; The only thing that bothers me is that is the Saloon & Sheriff Office are blocked (with the Sheriff protecting the Saloon), the game rather seems stucked

item.name: Defenders of the Realm
item.comment: This one is indeed though to win;

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Additional Darkness Spreads Cards
Defenders of the Realm: Battlefields
item.comment:
I love Defenders of the Realm. So when I saw this appearing on Kickstarter, this was a no brainer for me. However DOTR: Battlefields has as much to do with DOTR, as Dominant Species with Dominant Species - The Card Game. That means: nothing! OK, the artwork and setting are the same, but the mechanics are totally different. You won't feel for a single moment that you are playing DOTR, when playing DOTR: Battlefields. The theme here could as well been the Wild West, the gaming expierence would be the same.
What also bothers me is that I ordered the miniatures for the generals, but they have 0% added value to the game. They are totally worthless.
The game itself: you play a card (most of the time) and then you need pure luck. And while in DOTR there are ways to improve your odds to be succesfull when dice rolling, there are none (unless that just 1 special card that says you can reroll your dice) in DOTR: Battlefields. And that bothers me a lot in this game. I didn't have the feeling I had much control over the game and that the winner is mainly determined by having the luck of drawing the necessary cards and having good dice rolls.
This game is one big disappointment!

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Battlefields – Greenleaf Village and Fire River
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Battlefields – Scorpion Canyon and Karmak Sands
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Dragon Expansion
Defenders of the Realm: Generals Expansion
Defenders of the Realm: Hero Expansion #1
item.comment: Extra variety is always nice, but this expansion is no must have

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Hero Expansion #2
item.comment: If you buy 1 of those character expansion packs, you have more then enough characters.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Hero Expansion #3
item.comment: If you buy 1 of those character expansion packs, you have more then enough characters.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Legends Deck
item.comment: An extra feature is more then welcome when playing solo!

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Minions Expansion – Demons
item.comment: Very, very nice figures, only a bit big = unhandy on the board.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Minions Expansion – Undead
item.comment: These figurines are not as nice as the others

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Orc Expansion
Defenders of the Realm: Quest Deck
item.comment: Seems a bit more of the same

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: Relics
item.comment: It's already hard enough :s

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: The Barbarian
item.comment: Same rating as the base game

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: The Dragon Expansion
item.comment: Those dragon generals is the module why you should buy this.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm: The Noble Dwarf
Demetra
item.comment:
Had read some bad stuff about this one, but enjoyed my one play (with 3) so far;
It's a brainburner though, don't play this when you feel tired; With 4 it's probably a bit too much as you have to look at 3 different boards.

item.name: Desperados of Dice Town
item.comment:
I hate it when they do this: they call it Desperados of DICE TOWN and they use the same artwork as Dice Town. So will you get a 'new' Dice Town? Absolutely NOT!! But off couse by putting the name Dice Town on the box, they'll know they will sell more copies.
The game itself: only 1 play, but I didn't got a wow- feeling of it. It's with dice, so sure, you'll need some luck. In this game however you seem to be really at the mercy of the dice, as you really want action-stars (you can't free your desperados without them). But with only 1 star on each die, you have only a chance of 1/6 on each die to get them. Also a minus is the player elimination. In my game 2 players went bankrupt quite fast, while the other 2 played a long for an other 15 minutes: that was nu fun for them.

item.name: Deus
item.comment:
Not sure yet about this one: I love games were you have to look for combo's between different cards (I adore Seasons). However in this game I have the impression that only 1 type of cards really matters and that are cards that give you victory points (the points from Barberian villages seem to be only peanuts). Other cards are just used to 'feed' those cards. That means that if you can't get these, you simply won't win.
Have to see if this is conformed with repeated play.

item.name: Diamonds
item.comment: OK trick-taking game. Nice idea of how each suit has a different ability, but it makes then in some cases some suits are better for you then others and is therefore increases the luck. For example: in our game all my diamonds were in my vault. I had tons of spades, but they were useless for me.

item.name: Diamonds Club
item.comment: A bit more difficult then a family game.

item.name: Diamonsters
item.comment: A filler has to be short, but this game seems to be ultrashort, a bit too short for my taste. Maybe the end of game conditions should be a bit more severe?

item.name: Dice City
item.comment: Not so bad as I expected it to be (because of the low rating (6.78 on 20/11/2015) and the fact that Artipia and producing any quality games lately), but it was quite nice. But then again, it didn't feel like a must have.

item.name: Dice Town
item.comment: Fun!

item.name: Dice Town Extension
item.comment: Positive: it brings more strategy into the game as there is a second option on every location; Negative: as there are a lot of ties for 1st AND 2nd place, there are a lot of negotiations with the sheriff, which upgrades the role of the sheriff as he can get more during a round, BUT makes this game a lot longer to play.

item.name: Dice Town: The Indians
item.comment: I have this as a part of the 'Dice Town Extension'; It's a nice alternative if the only thing you get is a lousy 1

item.name: Dieven!
item.comment: Very chaotic game, but we had fun playing this (made also due to the fact that we were all tired :-)

item.name: Dig Mars
item.comment:
There is nothing really wrong with this game and when Nico explained it seemed OK, but during play I found it rather boring. There is nothing refreshing in this game and the game rather played itself: if you can take a tile all by yourself you take it (because then you don't have to share points), otherwise you do something else.
In our game it also seemed that the one who was lucky enough to find the most tiles with free actions on it simply won.

item.name: Dilluvia Project
item.comment: By far the best game I played at Essen 2015; it's are all known mechanics als gathering resources, reserving building spots and using those to get the buildings were you have to chose between getting money and points. But everything is very well implemented!

item.name: Dimension
item.comment: I think the way Dieter describes it, sums it up: "nice to do once";

item.name: Discoveries
item.comment: It really feels like a dice version of Lewis & Clark, which has the big advantage that it's faster, but off course the disadvantage that it involves more luck. Luckily you have enough possibilities for dice manipulation.

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment: If I would play this game without knowing the designer, I would never guess Martin Wallace. This game is fairly light with a rather great chaos-factor. Somehow I could live with it in this game.

item.name: Dive! Diver! Die!
item.comment: A pure push-your-luck - game

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: This is ABSOLUTELY not my kind of game

item.name: Dixit Quest
item.comment: Still not my kind of game, but if costumers wanna play it, I'll play it :D

item.name: Dobble
item.comment: Not quite my style of game :s

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment: This is a strange game: in one round the board can completely change because of the Dominance cards. It's a long game, but it never gets boring as it is a very tense game the whole time and a real struggle between animals.

item.name: Dominant Species: The Card Game
item.comment:
If you play this, you have to be prepared that there is gonna be some randomness. I can totally live with that, what bothers me more is that some cards seem to be completely overpowered. In our first game I had tons of water-elements saved up for the 10th and final round, when Surya played a card saying 'everybody MUST pass immediately' :s. That card will never be in one of my future games again :D
One thing is for sure: it's like in Taj Mahal: if you are going for winning the round, you'ld better win because if you play a lot of cards and get nothing, you're screwed!

item.name: Dominant Species: The Card Game (Promo Card Set)
item.comment: Nice additional Action Cards which aren't overpowered like some cards in the base game are :s

item.name: Dominare
item.comment:
Last game (so far) from the Tempest - Line and this is clearly the most heavy one and also the one who takes most time to play. And there it goes wrong for me in this game. This is really a game where PA will be an issue as you have to figure out which agent to place in which round, which ability to use when,...
It's also a 'screw-you' - game as you want to gain majority in most of the districts. However the value of a district is something you have less control over. Some agent-abilities let you increase our decrease those VP, but if you use your action to increase the VP of a certain district, it will attract the attention of the other players, who will use there actions to take it away from you. So that's something to do for the last round if you're almost certain that you'll controll it at the end of the game. So the most variation of the VP comes from the event cards, who can also be very drastic. I guess that's together with the playing time (which is an issue that can be resolved by playing it enough with the same players) my main issue with this game, that the swings can be too drastic, that the chaos factor is just too high for my personal taste.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Never commented this it seems. Well, after 4 years I still enjoy playing this one a lot!

item.name: Dominion: Avonturen
item.comment: It contains a lot of my favourite duration-cards, so I'm a fan of this extra expansion :-)

item.name: Dominion: De Donkere Middeleeuwen
item.comment: Only 1 play so far in combination with Seaside and I only bought cards from Seaside :D Maybe I must play a only 'Dark Ages'-set to discover the potential of this set a bit more?

item.name: Dominion: De Gilden
item.comment: The overpayment-mechanism ain't that spectacular. No 'need-to-have - set'

item.name: Dominion: Geldbuidel
item.comment: Have to play it more to see the possibilities

item.name: Dominion: Het Achterland
item.comment: More cards, but not really refreshing.

item.name: Dominion: Hijs de Zeilen
item.comment: There are some really nasty cards in this one :s

item.name: Dominion: Intrigue
item.comment: Like the kingdom cards more

item.name: Dominion: Overvloed
item.comment: While I found Dominion: Hinterlands were just some new cards, but nothing really extra, this expansion I like again as I like you get rewards for variety. Certainly as I normally am a player of buying a combo of 2 or 3 of the same action cards, this creates new challenges for me.

item.name: Dominion: Welvaart
item.comment: I thought that the Platina & Colonies would make for a longer game, but so far this doesn't seem to be true

item.name: Dominoes
item.comment: Bought a set in Cuba in 2005

item.name: Doodle City
item.comment: OK filler with a certain luck factor.

item.name: Het Dorp: De Haven
item.comment: While Village Inn gives you an extra possibility to score points, this expansion just replaces travelling, makes it harder to perform, but also more rewarding.

item.name: Het Dorp: De Herberg
item.comment: This is for me what every expansion should be: giving you something extra (in this case extra choices with the Inn), without messing up the base game (in the case this is already solid, which is the case for Village) and without being something 'you-have-to-do-if-you-wanna-win'. This is for me one of the best expansions in years.

item.name: Dos Rios
item.comment: If all players understand the game and use their dams at the right time, I can see the potential of this game; the problem is: with so many games out there, how you gonna create that player group?

item.name: Dragon Valley
item.comment: Graphically very nice, with very nice looking components, but in fact 2 wooden sticks and a wooden block would give you the same feeling

item.name: Dragon's Gold
item.comment: It's the kind of game you have to play with the 'right group' of people. I certainly enjoy this kind of games.

item.name: Dragonscroll
item.comment: Well, this is light, very light and a lot of luck dependence :s

item.name: Drako
item.comment: Good. A lot of tension while you are playing.

item.name: Draw Out
item.comment: A bit too long for what it is. Yellow is really almost impossible if you have a real person like Demi Moore or Michael Owen.

item.name: DRCongo
item.comment: Only played the basic game, according to the owner that's only half of the rulebook. The basic game is OK, but it's not that I had a wow-feeling after playing it or felt a need to own this game. Scores were extremely close together, which is a bit logic as you by/built point after point. Only cities are double points, so you certainly want those!

item.name: Dream Factory
item.comment: Great auction game

item.name: Drum Roll
item.comment: Great worker placement game. maybe not something spectacular refreshing, but very solid and timing of flipping your performers is crucial!

item.name: Drum Roll: Dragon Dancers
item.comment: Makes the wagons more intersting to go for, so good expansion!

item.name: Drum Roll: Fire Dancer
item.comment: Like the card explains: nice to buy when there are some discount tokens on it, not so nice to get as a starting card when you have to pay the full price :s

item.name: Drum Roll: Kickstarter Promos
item.comment: Some extra investments card (especially the Bargain-cards are very handy to get) and performers with a new ability (getting discount tokens), what more do you want (you even get some extra personnel) :)

item.name: Drum Roll: Mini Expansion
item.comment: The extra performers are nice, but I welcome especially the extra personnel as we now have enough so that the deck doesn't get depleted.

item.name: Drum Roll: Ringmaster
item.comment: The ringmaster is good, but also a bit a poisened gift: the cubes you put on your ringmaster is 1 artist less you can bring into play.

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment: I totally understand the hype. Also good with 3

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Dungeon-Setup Tiles
item.comment: Nive and simple addition which gives an other perspective for everybody.

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Festival Season
item.comment: I always like things who give extra variation. For the moment I just only added the extra monsters and rooms. I'm afraid the 5th Festival-season will prolongate the game too much.

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Kickstarter Expansion Pack
item.comment: Wow, I thought you couldn't make this game more beautiful, but apperantly you can!

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Minions Bearing Gifts
item.comment: Not so great

item.name: Dungeon Petz
item.comment: Dungeon Lords is complex, but this seems even more complex: you have exhibitions AND buyers to take into account and for those buyers you have to start planning 3 rounds in advance. Some heavy shit this one, but VERY GOOD heavy shit!

item.name: Dungeon Petz: Bob the Blob Promo Pet
Dungeon Petz: Bonus Kuschelmonster
item.comment: Always nice to have something extra :)

item.name: Dungeon Petz: Dark Alleys
item.comment: I like new stuff to add to the game, but I feel no need to make this already-not-so-short - game have a longer playing time :s This expansion has a bit the same problem as the one for Dungeon Lords

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: OK because of the short playing time if there ain't to many players, but you have only very little control and less choices to make.

item.name: Dungeon Twister 2: Prison
item.comment: We played immediately by the full rules and know I understand why there is a tutorial :s; Diserves it's high rating, lots of room for analysis paralysis though

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment:
Rating based on 1 solo-play; For solo play this really sucks. Big time! Very boring!;
Hopefully the group play will be more fun :s

item.name: The Dutch Golden Age
item.comment: Didn't have a good first impression of this game; The players who had played it before, said the game we played wasn't representative (lots of money available, almost no auctions), so I'll have to give it another try and maybe rerate

item.name: Dweebies
item.comment: Very light card game, but after some heavier games, this is excellent to end the gaming event

item.name: Eat Me If You Can!
item.comment: This is more a gimmick then an actual game

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment: At first there seems nothing new about it, but the fact that you use your influence markers as well as to mark your actions as the planets you controll make this a very hard game to manage.

item.name: Eclipse: Pulsar
item.comment: I'm wondering if this can't be too powerfull if someone finds it in the beginning of the game in a 'secure' place? OK, you can only do 1 thing at a time and not everything, but you can always do a useless upgrade to keep on circling between move and built, which can spare you an action disc or 2 - 3, which is quite a lot of money you can save, certainly in the beginning of the game!

item.name: Eclipse: Rise of the Ancients
item.comment: They are some good modules in here, but I can't imagine you wanna play this with 9 :s (but off course you have more races to chose from).

item.name: Eclipse: Rise of the Ancients – The Tractor Beam
item.comment: Ok I guess

item.name: Eclipse: Supernova
item.comment: OK, he gives no points, but it's a great tile to have at the beginning of the game as you can put 2 money on it and you have only a minor chance of losing it. It that sence maybe too good?

item.name: Edo
item.comment: One of the more strategic games of Queen. Good worker placement. I like the square planning cards where you have to pick one.

item.name: Edo Promo #1: Special Authorization Cards
item.comment: First I didn't see the use of the 'charter', but as Myriam used it in our game, I must admit it can be handy :D

item.name: Edo Promo #2: Profit Tiles
item.comment: Gives some variety, but doesn't changes anything to the feel of the gameplay

item.name: Edo: Expansion #1
item.comment: Gives extra scoring possibilities, but all modules only change the game lightly (which is a good thing)

item.name: Egizia
item.comment: Nothing really new, but everything works great together

item.name: Eight-Minute Empire
item.comment: OK fillergame

item.name: Eight-Minute Empire: Legends
item.comment:
This is indeed the better version of Eight Minute Empire:
+ Higher replayability because of the modular board and the extra 'twists' that are added + Nicer components/artwork - It's now more of 'eight minute/player empire', which makes it loses 1 of his advantages: the very short playing time

item.name: Eketorp
item.comment: Not a great game, but quite good: diserves better then a ranking outside top 1000

item.name: El Gaucho: Fodder for the Cattle
item.comment: Gives a possible use to a die that would otherwise be useless, so good mini-expansion.

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment: By using elements/graphics from the Catan-series I had a strong 'seen this before'-feeling; it takes too long for what it is

item.name: Electronic Whac-a-Mole
item.comment: Funny from time to time, but better not if you're tired and play in hard (= only sounds) mode :s

item.name: Elfengold
item.comment: Nice addition of mechanics, but it multiplies the gaming time by at least 2, probably more 2,5 - 3

item.name: Elk Fest
item.comment: Not my type of game...

item.name: Elysium
item.comment: ++ 8 gods makes for a lot of variety and therefore a high replayability + nice artwork en nice components + rules are straightforward and easy to explain - text on the card is in a very small print -- There will be, no matter how experienced you are, a lot of AP in this game as you have to figure out which columns to keep and you have to take into account which other possibilities your opponents still have, especially concerning the quests. I would therefore never play this with 4.

item.name: Eminent Domain
item.comment: Good deckbuilding game

item.name: Eminent Domain: Bonus Planets
item.comment: Same rating as base game

item.name: Eminent Domain: Escalation
item.comment: On 1 hand you seem to be even more driven to Warfare by this expansion, on the other hand your opponents can score big points if they have a Peace treaty. To be played more :-)

item.name: Eminent Domain: Microcosm
item.comment: The game has become to Micro, by whom I mean that the rules are to condense or the text on the cards is not clear enough

item.name: Emira
item.comment: After playing this, we all had a bit the same feeling: why play a bad version of 'The Princes of Florence' when you can play the original which is excellent? The randomness of the princesses screws things up and with 5 the problem seems to be that 1 player goes strong in palaces, on other in status points and a 3rd in appearance. And it's very hard to catch up and impossible to attract a princess. And our gaming group doesn't love event cards!

item.name: Empires: Builder Expansion
item.comment: It's good to have randomisation of the buildings and the builder is also a good extra specialist. Haven't yet tested the nations-module.

item.name: Empty Erlenmeyer Experiment Expansion
item.comment: I like experiment better with this expansion, adds some nice, but easy things

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: Not so great with 3; maybe rating will go up after a few games with more players?

item.name: Entdecker: Im Reich der Jadegöttin
item.comment: Tile-laying will probably never become my favorite game-mechanism. And here you'll need a good dose of luck also, as well in finding tiles with Jade statues on, as well as drawing artefacts pieces that you need. Luckely the market provides a certain correction factor on the luck. It's the kind of game I wouldn't mind playing again, both I certainly don't need to own.

item.name: Era of Inventions
item.comment: I like this game, but only with 3, then the first player can start with extra factories and the 3rd with inventions (or vice versa of course :-).

item.name: Era Of Inventions: The Golden Goal
item.comment: Just OK

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment: Well, it's certainly original, but only 10 minutes, well, that's stressy I must say, even for me :D! Don't know if it's inexperience, but I seemed that everybody is more doing things on itself shouting he needs a gold dice sometimes and just at that moment you'll have a look where he is. But off course the short playing time is a big plus, you'll start over right away.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple – Doomed
item.comment: Don't like those curses that make you stand right or put an arm on your head, the treasure is neat though

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple – The Pit
item.comment: The Pit is a nice idea and worth considering to go for :)

item.name: ESSEN The Game: SPIEL'13
item.comment: Lighter then I expected it to be (maybe I had some wrong expectations because the author of Bruxelles 1893 is 1 of the designers). Actions are very limited and most of the time you just move and grab what's usefull :-)

item.name: Eufraat & Tigris
item.comment: It really sucks as a 2-player: if one player has a strong kingdom, there is absolutely nothing you can do

item.name: Euphoria: Build a Better Dystopia
item.comment: Second game of Stonemaier Games I play (with Viticulture being the first) and second game I like. You could easily think this is a game where you have to built an engine, but it is not, it's a race for the available slots and just grab what you can :D

item.name: Evo
item.comment: Fun build-your-own - dino game

item.name: Evolution
item.comment: The only thing that I remembered from the Russian Evolution is that I had a situation were my animals were too strong to fight for my opponent. This version seems a bit more streamlined (and the artwork is much better), but seems still possible to create hard to beat combo's.

item.name: Evolution: The Origin of Species
item.comment: Rating base on one uncompleted, but almost finished, play. I like the mechanism and how well the cards interact. However as you get as many cards as you have survived animals + 1, I had the feeling that the rich get ritcher as there is also no hand limit. I had a strong combo of 4 animals with strong powers who were almost impossible for my opponent to kill, while I could kill his animals easily or prevent him to get enough food. When we stopped he had 2 (basic) animals and no cards, while I had already saved up to 15 cards, just waiting to strike in the last round :D

item.name: Excape
item.comment: It's a fact that those dice can haunt you, but I enjoyed my 1 play so far

item.name: Expedition Sumatra
item.comment: I really sucked at my 1 play so far, but really enjoyed playing this short family game who requires the necessary thinking

item.name: Expedition: Famous Explorers
item.comment:
This is light, very very light, even with the so called 'advanced' rules. It's a bit Transamerica/Transeurope revisited.
Also a minus: way over produced. There are hardly any components in the box. Don't love the artwork neither.

item.name: Expedition: Famous Explorers Promo Card – Christopher Columbus
Expedition: Famous Explorers – Travel Tickets and Hazard Cards
item.comment: Hazards, a typical idea from an American of what an expansion should contain :s

item.name: Express 01
item.comment:
2 plays, to different game experiences. This seems to be the kind of game that looks easier then it is. It's really more then just building some stations or tracks.
What is for sure that this is an uberdry game for only the hardcore strategy player.

item.name: Express 01: Benelux Expansion
item.comment: In combination with the mountain expansion it prolongates the 'cheaper area';

item.name: Express 01: Mountains Expansion
item.comment: It makes the north more attractive in the beginning

item.name: Face 2 Face
item.comment: Good kids game where you can mix reaction & memory. Not so challenging as an adult to play.

item.name: Factory Fun
item.comment: Fun game to play from time to time, but not something that screems for being played game after game

item.name: Famiglia
item.comment: Easy to explain, nice to play, great!

item.name: Familienbande
item.comment: One play and found it quite boring. As I couldn't find the appropriate cards, most of the time I was just taking cards or had to put out cards that were only good for my opponents as I reached my hand limit. Almost no controll at all.

item.name: Fantastiqa: A Wild Goose Chase, Espresso Dragons, & Exclusive Artifact Expansion
item.comment: Not so keen of the goose, but the rest is OK

item.name: Fantastiqa: Audacious Artifacts Expansion
item.comment: Lowered the score as I think is kind of lame to only give 12 out of 18 cards for those who bought it at the BGG Store

item.name: Fantastiqa: Curious Companions and Rarest Relics Expansion
item.comment: Extra variety, especially for the beasts this is nice.

item.name: Fantastiqa: Enchanted Edition
item.comment:
Have to reread the rules and play again before making a final judgement. Some strange mechanics, that's for sure :s
Edit 17/04/2013: Played it 3 times now, 2 times with 4 (in teams) and one 3-player. I like this game more and more. I'm especially fond of the team-play variant with 4, it gives an extra dimension to the game. With 3 you will however have more competition for the open quests.

item.name: Fantastiqa: Fantastic Events Expansion
item.comment: Way TOO MUCH events if you add them all. Only add a few is my suggestion.

item.name: Fantastiqa: Fantastiqal Landscapes Expansion
item.comment: I understand why you need a full game before you can paint all the landscapes :s That's a minus for this expansion, but the exchange into cloud crystals by themselves is a nice addition by itself as it gives a meaning to the colours of the gems.

item.name: Fantastiqa: Special Delivery Expansion
item.comment: Nice addition. helps you set a goal in the beginning of the game.

item.name: Fantastiqa: The Abandoned Abbey Adventure Expansion
item.comment: The playing time becomes longer for no extra excitement. This is an expansion that can stay into the box.

item.name: Fantastiqa: Treasure Hunt Expansion
item.comment: It makes the dog a bit more useful, but I won't travel to a location just to dig up a treasure, it's more something you'ld do if you're around or would pass through anyway.

item.name: Fantasy Frontier
item.comment:
What is good: the artwork
What is bad: 1) lots of AP (= downtime) as everybody has to puzzle to find a matching pattern 2) The airships are too big or in fact the tiles too small, which make they block a part of the map, which makes it even harder to find a matching pattern 3) The winner will be for 95% decided by pure luck (right dice roll, right tiles, already laid out patterns) 4) Why does an American publisher always have to include a combat-system? If you to make a Eurostylish-game DON'T include combat!!! 5) no fun or excitement while playing

item.name: Le Fantôme de l'Opéra
item.comment:
Mr. Jack in NY was a great re-implementation of Mr. Jack as the characters could do different stuff and Mr. Jack had a better chance of winning. Here the characters can be linked to a character from Mr. Jack or his expansion, nothing new here. The 'innovating' should come from the end goal. For the inspector everything stays the same: eliminate all but 1 suspects. Now he has to do it as fast as possible, because there more suspects there remain, the faster La Carlotta will move to the exit, which is the new goal for 'Mr. Jack'.
But all together it doens't feel that refreshing to justify a purchase. It's even less tense as often a lot of characters are useless as they are located too far away (you now move from room to room on a very ugly board) or you already know they aren't the Phantom. This seems to be one spin-off too many.

item.name: Farmerama
item.comment:
This is a typical Rosenberg, by which I mean that you have a little bit interaction in competing for the garden objects, but for the rest this is a multiplayer solitaire where everybody is doing his thing in his personal garden. For ('hardcore') gamers this is something that most of them fancy, but I don't know if that is a good thing for a more family style of game where Ravensburger stands for?
However, I enjoyed playing it (as I do with most of Rosenberg games). Only pity for the imho very ugly artwork (I understood it's taken from the computer game).

item.name: Fast Flowing Forest Fellers
item.comment: we played the starting game and that was rather boring

item.name: Favor of the Pharaoh
item.comment: It is indeed To Court the King with more replayability.

item.name: Felinia
item.comment: Played directly with the advanced rules: the mystic places don't add that much, but the food you need to reach the spaces more then 3 steps away add an extra tactical aspect

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
Feudality
item.comment: Only to play if you can live with some randomness and chaos (by the event cards who can be quite drastic :s)

item.name: Fictionaire
item.comment: If you could enjoy this game are not is 100% dependant of the players whom you're playing with and even then...

item.name: Fields of Arle
item.comment: As I like most of Uwe Rosenberg's games a lot I had some (too?) high expectations of this one. Don't have the feeling those are quite met after 1 play. You certainly have a lot of options, that's for sure. And in our 1 play we went for different things and scores were quite close, so that's very good. My highest concern is the replayability. Ok, the buildings can be different each time, but I'm wondering of that's enough as the set-up is predetermined and you could stick to that same engine each game.

item.name: Fields of Arle: Advent Calendar Expansion
item.comment: We're always in for some extra variety :-)

item.name: Finca
item.comment: Easy to play, hard to win! Great game

item.name: Finca: El Razul
item.comment: Adds some nice twists to this already excellent game

item.name: Firenze
item.comment:
If Steding keeps making games like this, he will go up a lot in my favorit desinger ranking. This is the 3rd game of him I play (other are Hansa Teutonia and Norenberc) and this one is smoother and faster, maybe a bit more a family game;
However, I won't buy this as long as it only exists in German, as it's a strong language dependent, which is a pity :(

item.name: First Train to Nuremberg
item.comment: One play on the Nuremberg-map: it requires another way to play this game then the Wenselydale - map, as you can counter the point-loss from the profit-track by laying most of your tracks in the connection between Fürth and Nuremberg.

item.name: A Fistful of Penguins
item.comment: OK filler, but a real shame that those beautiful penguins are just used as an extra dice/reroll token!

item.name: FITS
item.comment: This is in fact a solo-game that you play with more then one

item.name: FITS Expansion #1: MOTS – More Of The Same
item.comment: Same rating as the base game.

item.name: Five Points: Gangs of New York
item.comment: Have to play again to give final judgement. 1 thing is 100% sure: very ugly artwork!

item.name: Five Points: Gangs of New York – Flophouse
Five Tribes
item.comment: I was a bit surprised by the high rating of this game, but after 1 play I totally understand why: this is a school example of a game with not so many rules (typical DoW-rulebook of 8 pages with 2 pages set-up and lots of examples), many things you can focus on to score points and more then depth that you can imagine after reading the rules. Best DoW-release since Small World.

item.name: Five Tribes: Dhenim
item.comment: An extra card, nothing more, nothing less

item.name: Five Tribes: The Artisans of Naqala
item.comment: A good expansion in the sense that it adds a viable alternative to score points. But it's big minus is the classic one: it prolongs the gaming time :s

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: For me there was absolutely nothing new (OK, you can save an action, woohoo) compering with Pandemic

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Urban Structures
item.comment: Same rating as base game

item.name: Fleet
item.comment: Good fast paced cardgame where you have to look for some good combo's

item.name: Fleet: Arctic Bounty
item.comment: Only tried out the 'Gone Fish'in'-kaarten as I firstly wanted to try out all the extra's :-) However, it provides me of with I like the most in an expansion: giving a lot of variety!

item.name: Fleet: Crab Meeples
item.comment: This sort of automatically happens and is not really something you can play for as you can't launch a boat from whom you don't have a license.

item.name: Fleet: First Mate
item.comment: Offers an interesting choice, but is only do-able if you have early on a 'card-engine' as it costs you an extra card which is hard in the beginning of the game.

item.name: Fleet: House Boat
item.comment: If you can't launch a boat and still have 3 money left I guess it can be a good investment for future turns. But in our game, people preferred to launch a boat if they could.

item.name: Fleet: Inuit Fisherman
item.comment: Good if you would start with a processing license, otherwise rather expnsive for what it is (as he is 0 VP)

item.name: Fleet: Nunavut Weather Authority
item.comment: For those who want to bully their opponents

item.name: Fleet: Salmon License
item.comment: This is a really nice license to have as it doubles the capacity of your boats!

item.name: Fleet: Salty Captains
item.comment: Can be a very nice combo if you have a lot of processing licenses. Gives you at least 8 points from fish (probably) so for me a better buy then the Inuit Fishermen

item.name: Fleet: Salvage Yard Licenses
item.comment: This is great in combination with a Cod License as it costs you a launch

item.name: Fleet: Trophy Cards
item.comment: Classic extra goal-rewards, something I personally like

item.name: Fleet: Wharfside Casino
item.comment:
In my first game I played with these I bought 1 and rolled a 'Fleet' on my very first gamble. Off course then I felt the need to keep on gambling, but lost more then I won. A real casino :D
It's more a gimmick imho, but off course a gimmick that is worth 7 VP!

item.name: Flick 'em Up!
item.comment: More amusement then really an actual game.

item.name: Flinke Stinker
item.comment: It's a combination of push-your-luck and memory (where are the puma's)

item.name: Flip City
item.comment: What a horrible, ultra boring game this is. A waste of trees!

item.name: Flizz & Miez
item.comment: Simply not my type of game

item.name: Flying Kiwis
item.comment: Not as much fun as Crazy Coconuts, but much quicker (and therefore chaotic) as you all shoot simultaneously. Still one that I'm glad to have and to keep in the collection.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: It's quick, easy and fun

item.name: Fortuna
item.comment: The mechanism of taking an action card from an other (neutral) player is nice. It makes having the Fortuna - card (= Start Player) quite important

item.name: Eine Frage der Ähre
item.comment: A pity for the really dreadfull artwork, because this is a good, short game

item.name: Francis Drake
item.comment:
Second game I play from Kayal Games and it's sort of the same feeling as I had on Triassic Terror: There is absolutely nothing wrong with this game, everything works excellent together. But there is also nothing new about this game. So if you like the genre (area majority in Triassic Terror and gathering resources in Francis Drake), you will certainly enjoy playing these games.
A big plus in both games is that they are tense while playing and thematically everything feels right, not just a theme-paste-on.

item.name: Francis Drake: Montezuma's Legacy Expansion
item.comment: Makes the admiral more interesting.

item.name: Francis Drake: Spain's Revenge Expansion
item.comment: Makes the governor and admiral more interesting.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: If you add the 3 modules you have an excellent game that isn't that difficult to teach or play (but more then fun enough for the experienced player), where everything works excellent together

item.name: Fresco: Expansion Modules 4, 5 and 6
item.comment: I really like module 6 - The Glaziers as it adds extra depth

item.name: Fresco: Expansion Modules 8, 9 and 10
item.comment:
I'm glad I own this, as I always like to add 3 modules and with now in total 10 available modules (which I don't all like; for instance 'the whiwhing well' will probably never be added), I have lots of choice.
But now I also have the feeling that it's enough, that there is enough variety and feel no need to have some more.

item.name: Fresco: The Bishop's Favor
item.comment: I think this expansion adds too much: if you get the bishop on the tile you already get + 3 points and now you get an extra award. Also 5 coins is a very big reward in comparison with the others.

item.name: Fresco: The Scrolls
item.comment: OK Module to add, but a lot of money for 10 tiles :s

item.name: Freya's Folly
item.comment: OK Game, everthing works, but quite dry; I think 4 is more fun to play this game

item.name: Friese's Landlord
item.comment:
Game with a very high 'take-that'-aspect. Definitely not to play with Surya & Myriam, but got to try it with Jan :D
Minus: there is already text on the card, so why not put everything on the cards so that you don't have to look up things all the time?? :s

item.name: Fuchs & fertig
item.comment: Something light and fun to close your gaming evening. As an adult you should really only play this for having fun.

item.name: Fünf Gurken
item.comment: This game seems to be playing itself. However we had some good laughs while playing it, and that's probably the only thing this game is aiming for?

item.name: Funkenschlag (Second Edition)
item.comment: True classic!

item.name: Funkenschlag – Erweiterung Zentraleuropa/Benelux
item.comment: Only played with Benelux-map, which is excellent if you want a fast game

item.name: Funkenschlag: Der Liefervertrag
item.comment: Can be quite important

item.name: Funkenschlag: Die Neuen Kraftwerkskarten
item.originalname: Power Grid: The New Power Plant Cards
item.comment: Perfect if you want a quicker game

item.name: Funkenschlag: Erweiterung Russland/Japan
item.comment: Only played on Japan-map

item.name: Funkenschlag: Lagerhalle
item.comment: Not so great this expansion

item.name: Funkenschlag: Orakel & Industriespionage
item.comment: This seems to be creating a promo-card just to have a promo-card. Probably won't add it again in future plays.

item.name: Funkenschlag: Québec/Baden-Württemberg
item.comment: Only played the Québec-side, but it seems to be just another map.

item.name: Fürstenfeld
item.comment: Not too heavy, quick and easy to explain

item.name: Galapagos
item.comment: Not too bad as a game as long as you accept that it is a game of taking opportunities; a pity of the screaming artwork though :s

item.name: Galapagos
item.comment: The demo-guy of Amigo immediately explained us a house rule of him for Galapagos: if you can't move at all, you can set aside 3 dice to flip 1 of the 2 remaining dice on a colour of your choice. While playing we discovered why he made this house rule: sometimes you're just stuck and can't move a single hex. So if you play this game, I encourage you to use this rule, as otherwise the're is too much luck involved.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: Very original!

item.name: Galaxy Trucker: Another Big Expansion
item.comment: This expansion makes it too difficult for me. Base + Big expansion is enough for me.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker: Latest Models
item.comment: Same feeling as with 'Another Big Expansion': this is only for pro-players.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker: The Big Expansion
item.comment: Same rating as the base game; Only used the 'New ship building components' so far

item.name: The Gallerist
item.comment: The flow is easier to see in this game, but I think - but only after 1 play - that there is a certain 'fixed' gameplay: 1) first acquire more workers as you can leave them and get benefits from the kick-off actions 2) work on your influence income (aka pink meeples) to make sure you can take the kick-off actions 3) Get some end point bonus tiles as they will boost your influence at the end of the game 4) Do some other stuff that will give you money

item.name: Game of Goose
item.comment: It's throwing dice and hoping you'll land on the right spot

item.name: Game of Trains
item.comment: It's more a passing-by-time thing then an actual game. Chaos and luck rule this 'game'. But it only takes 10 minutes, so I won't refuse to play it again if Nico would ask for it.

item.name: The Game: Speel...zolang je kunt!
item.originalname: The Game: Spiel...so lange du kannst!
item.comment: OK cooperative game that amazes me in the sense that you can make a good cardgame with so simple rules and just 98 numbered cards.

item.name: Ganzenpas
item.comment: If you know a couple with small children who in fact you can't stand: give them this game! This is pure horror to play along with children!!!

item.name: Garden Dice
item.comment: Not bad, but a bit too long in gaming time for what it is.

item.name: El Gaucho
item.comment: This would be an excellent family game, but the steeling part ruines it for me a bit. This should be a simple nice built-up game, but as they can steal a cow from you, it simply ain't

item.name: Der geheimnisvolle Spiegel
item.comment: Clearly not the best release of DMS. This is the kind of game that is fun to do once, but will have a very low replay ability. Once you know which drawings are into the game, you can already start to guess as soon 1 line is drawn, as there is no penalty for guessing wrong. A game that doesn't have to be in my collection.

item.name: Die geheimnisvolle Sternschnuppe
item.comment: Can be fun to play from time to time

item.name: Geisterei
item.comment:
It's very Original as concept. The big trick is to have a good catch of the egg with your ghost. It hardly fell out when we played it when you had a good catch.
Just 1 remark: if you wanna play a long as an adult, make sure to be with 2 adults, or you will have a hard time if you roll 'under the legs' :D

item.name: Geistermühle
item.comment: This is fun! But I'm wondering if kids can handle the 'frustration' of being kicked out?

item.name: Gem Dealer
item.comment: Well, you need some luck with the cards, but you have to try to bid at least once so that you'll have an extra card.

item.name: Gemblo
item.comment: Like Blokus, but more difficult

item.name: Genoa
item.comment: Liked the (original) mechanics a lot, but disliked the long playing time.

item.name: German Railways
item.comment:
One play: Liked the first 2/3 of the game, the last 1/3 it was obvious who would win and the game seemed to drag on a little bit. But I must say this was also due to the fact that the leading player WANTED the game to last longer then it should;
Major mistakes in Dutch rulebook, read the English one!!

item.name: Get Nuts
item.comment:
Rating after one play - with 3 times a hand that I couldn't do anything with :( - will see after more plays if rating will go up or down;
Second play: enjoyed this game more, so increased rating (7 -> 7.5); I start to see the use of trees of 1 now (quick way up to get to the nuts in the same turn and excellent to break down).

item.name: Get Nuts Bonus Action Cards
item.comment: Nice to have some extra variation

item.name: Gheos
item.comment: Couldn't find any fun in this game

item.name: Ghooost!
item.comment: Weaker version of Bugs as you have less control (don't know which cards you'll be getting)

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment: Heard some good and some bad stuff about this one, but after one play, the good one seems to be true :)

item.name: Ghost Stories: Chuck No-Rice
item.comment: OK goodie

item.name: Ghost Stories: The Guardhouse Expansion
item.comment: Not so great Village tile. In our 1 game with this tile it was used only once. The good thing about it is that you have some randomisation of the village.

item.name: Giants
item.comment: OK game, but nothing more

item.name: Giggle Wiggle
item.comment: Dexterity games are not my cup of tea :s

item.name: Ginkgopolis
item.comment: The first time you play this, you have to get used to the rather unique game mechanism as it is not that obvious to grasp. Great work!

item.name: Ginkgopolis: The Experts
item.comment: More stuff, but not any necessary stuff

item.name: GIPF
item.comment: 3rd game I play of the Gipf-series, liked Tzaar and Yinsh a lot more

item.name: Gipfelstürmer
item.comment: Try to make a chain and have some luck with the dice and you will do fine in this game :-)

item.name: Gipsy King
item.comment: Not bad, pure abstract, no wow-feeling

item.name: Giro d'Italia: The Game
item.comment: Rating after one play: more then 2 hours for what should have been a medium play is too long for me; like the mecanics though!

item.name: Giro Galoppo
item.comment: Quite hard for kids to see the manipulation, but easy for adults to understand. Makes a mixing group of adults and children playing together quite unbalanced

item.name: Giza: The Great Pyramid
item.comment:
They urgently have to hire someone at Mayfair who is able to write rules who are clear when you read them (or fire the person who does it for the moment if they already have one!). They are not as bad as Nuns on the Run, but still lack of clearness. It made the first couple of rounds very frustating to play as not everything was clear at all.
One thing is for sure: this is an unforgiving game. If you have no food at a certain moment, it's very hard to recover as your opponents let your people starve :s.

item.name: De Glasstraat
item.comment: Only 1 play, but this is for me by far for the moment the best game from Essen 2013. It's easy to explain, playing time is (with the right players :D) quite short (65 minutes for 4 players in our first game) and there is a lot of strategy involved. As there are quite a lot of buildings, I assume replayability will be high.

item.name: Glastonbury
item.comment:
It has memory, what's not to like :-))
Excellent, very easy to explain filler game.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: Very nice game

item.name: Glenn Drover's Empires: Age of Discovery – Plague Promo
item.comment: OK expansion that add some extra confict into the game.

item.name: Global Mogul
item.comment: Classic game of where everything works excellent together, but there is really nothing new to discover here

item.name: Gloria Mundi
item.comment: This game can only work if EVERYBODY is willing to pay the resources preventing the Visigoth to invade Rome

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment: You really have to play this a couple of times to master it :s

item.name: Glück Auf
item.comment: Lighter Kramer - Kiesling where things can get very tight/expensive (in workers). Good game!

item.name: Die Gnome von Zavandor
item.comment: One play so far: For me everything worked fine, but my fellow players had a hard time working things out. I had the jewels from 5 & 6 points and then it's hard to catch up. Unbalanced? Future plays will tell.

item.name: Goa
item.comment: Good game, which probably would have gotten a higher rating if I hadn't played games like Puerto Rico or Age of Empires III before. Now it felt like just another (good) game in that category

item.name: Goblins, Inc.
item.comment: Very original gameconcept that is harder to explain then it really is to play. However, the only shining number for this game is 4, as it is the only number the introduces full semi-cooperative gameplay (at least for 1 round :D).

item.name: Gold Ahoy!
item.comment:
It's tile laying, so if you see my other ratings for games that use this game mechanism, you won't be surprised I don't give it a high rating, is I'm not a fan of that mechanism :-)
What's in plus for this game is the very short playing time (even with the house rule that you have 2 tiles to pick from) and according short ruleset and that it is compact, so easy to take along when travelling.

item.name: Gold Nuggets
item.comment: Pure, boring brainless game were you throw dice and try to make the best of it, as we've seen so many times before.

item.name: Gold!
item.comment: Nice! Like it better with 3 then with 2

item.name: GOLD! Promotional Scoring Card
item.comment: In fact this ain't an expansion at all, it's just a - very lame - variant of the rules for scoring

item.name: The Golden Ages
item.comment:
My final day at the Essen-fair, 1,5 hour before closing time. There is a table available at the Quined-booth. So I plant myself down. Golden Ages was there new release from whom I expected not a lot (in contradiction with AquaSphere and Massilia), probably also because of the very ugly artwork of Alexander Roche. We were also with only 2 players and it seemed to be better with more. But I must say that I was totally wrong!
This turned to be a fast civilisation game that also plays excellent with 2 and seems to have enough in it to have a good replayability.

item.name: The Golden City
item.comment: Typical Schacht game: family game with enough strategy in it.

item.name: Gonzaga
item.comment: Don't know about this one yet. Have to give it a second try: from our first game, I learned that there are at least 2 ways that can make you win, which is good.

item.name: GOSU 2: Tactics
item.comment: I like the game-system a lot, but however sometimes you just don't get the 'right' goblins, therefore it is a card-game with a certain luck-factor.

item.name: Grand Austria Hotel
item.comment:
The end of our 1 play fucked up the good feeling I had after 5 rounds.
But even if that wouldn't have happened, this game suffers of severe AP. If an AP-player has the 4/5-tile it takes ages until you can do your move. It's certainly a general feeling you have when you have the 1/8-tile. It easily takes 15 minutes before you can take your second die. An as customers change and dies are taken, there's no point in figuring out your next move until it's actually your turn.

item.name: Grand Cru
item.comment: Nice game!

item.name: Grand Cru: Heuriger und gemischter Satz
item.comment: It's good that you have some randomisation, but not necessary to have

item.name: Grand Cru: Innovation Tiles
item.comment: It's nice in a sense that if you have one and you miss out on a development tile you needed, you can still use him, however I don't see people playing with an aim to get one, you just happen to get them.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: Only play this with 4 or 5, then it is at his best

item.name: El Grande: König & Intrigant
item.comment: Nice variant as you save some time as you don't have to read and chose an action card each round. Still not as good as the original.

item.name: La Granja
item.comment:
Only played once, but this game indeed deserves a high rating. I think that the rating will only go up instead of down with more plays.
Nothing really new however: like the authors - honestly - mention in the rulebook: the kicking out of pawns in the market we've seen before in Luna and the different use of cards in Glory to Rome. But this game re-implements these game mechanics in an excellent way!

item.name: La Granja: 2nd Edition Promo Cards
item.comment: These cards aren't compatible with the first edition as they are slightly bigger and have a different (Chinese :'() finish

item.name: The Great Fire of London 1666
item.comment: Original Game-mechanism

item.name: The Great Heartland Hauling Co.
item.comment: Good pick-up-and-deliver - game in a small box.

item.name: The Great Zimbabwe
item.comment:
I discovered Splotter Spellen at Essen, where they have a whitebox-game every year that sells very well, even sells out most of the time, but also is very expensive. Some of there games have became legend and if you want a 'Roads & Boats' for instance, you'll have to be willing to pay really a lot of money to get a copy.
There 'The Great Zimbabwe' got some great comments, but paying more then 70 euro from a company and a designerduo I hadn't play a single game before, that was a bridge too far for me. So when I was able to buy one at acceptable retailerprice, I didn't doubt for a moment and got myself a copy and played it yesterday (13/04/2013).
I was the one who read the rules. It was only 8 pages, something I'm gratefull for, after reading rulebooks as 'Space Cadets' or 'Android: Netrunner' before :s But after reading the rules I couldn't grasp the game. That is because this is a very mechanic game. This is in fact a pure abstract, with zero feeling of theme and are a bunch of mechanics who are glued together. Some of them are really nice, I in particular liked the 'drop-out bidding and divide cattle - mechanism' and the whole idea of taking powerfull cards will increase you VR (= how much points you have to score before your score becomes positive). The whole 'hub'-thing however is very hard to grasp and would have suited much better in a space-theme then in an African Kingdom. This is also what makes this game very, very abstract as all intuition disappears with that.
So the gameplay itself. It was surprisingly short (85 minutes with 3 all new players). That's probably also due to the fact that I made the big mistake of putting a Diamond craftsman on the map (I had a good cattle engine thanks to 'The Heard') too early, giving the others the opportunity to built level 5 of there monuments and to finish the game, while I still had a big gap to close on my VR, who was very high. I like games where I can play most of the times on intuition and where a look at the boards gives me a good 'feeling' of the situation. The Great Zimbabwe is just the opposite of that. You have to do math all the time and make sure every single cattle is taken into account and looking at the gameboard is far from obvious as the hub-system makes that things can be reached in a very unnatural, totaly not logic way. Therefore this will never be my favorite game, but I can imagine that players who like to calculate every move they make (and even those from others), will become very wet from this game.
On a final notice: there is some wood in this game, but imho you don't get good value for your big money. The playersheets are very, very flimsy, which I personally would find a bit harsh if you have payed 70 euro or more for a game. So this game didn't convince me to pay the money Splotter is asking for there games, but I can see why others would do that.

item.name: Greed
item.comment: Drafting and making the best of your cards in an enjoyable playing time

item.name: Grimoire
item.comment: It's short and it's something different (like most Japanese games). Fun to play from time to time

item.name: Grog Island
item.comment: See this as a light family game, and you will have a nice time playing this

item.name: Ground Floor
item.comment:
If you like playing a hard, very cutthroat game, this is what you are looking for. If you're not short on money, you'll probably miss information and even if you have both, you still need that damn supply-cube if you wanna produce something at the factory. And if you have all, you can score some points and start all over again :D
Besides that, it's a good thing to invest in popularity as it will give you a bonus (maybe small, but can be very important difference to have or not), which off course will cost you some money and info :s
I like this kind of hard games, even the fact that it's as dry as the Sahara doesn't bother me. But I would never play this with more then 3, because gaming time is a tad too long, 2 hours would be perfect, but if you're beginners you'll probably need 2,5.
If you're beginners I can also strongly recommend to use the predetermined economic forecast, otherwise it can really be too hard.
Edit: played it a second time with the same players and gaming time was beneath 2 hours this time.

item.name: Guatemala Café
item.comment: Good with 3, probably better (more balanced) with 4?

item.name: GUBS: A Game of Wit and Luck
item.comment: This game is pure chaos. Normally I would dislike this, but because of the short playing time - and keeping in mind it is chaos - I really enjoy playing this one.

item.name: Guess Who?
item.comment: Game from my childhood which plays on automatic if you're an adult. I played the travel version of my sister in law and there are more men the women, which doesn't seems logic as it is a basic question to start with and you have a disadvantage if you're a women.

item.name: Guildhall
item.comment: One play, which was frustrating at some point if you have cards by whom you can do nothing really good. A bit to chaotic with 4 also, probably better with 3.

item.name: Guildhall: Job Faire
item.comment:
Sometimes I wonder: did they split up a game in 2, so they'll be able to sell 2 different games, who where in fact just one?
With 'Core Worlds' for instance it's very clear that the expansion 'Galactic Orders' already existed when they brought out the base game, as the cards of the base game already had the symbols of the factions of the expansion on them. When playing Core Worlds + Galactic Orders, the game also feels "finished", like now you finally have all the components and before you just had a stripped off version.
That same feeling I had when I combined 'Guildhall: Old World Economy' with 'Guildhall: Job Faire'. OK, you can indeed play each set on it's own, but it will always be the 6 same occupations you'll use. It makes much more sense to have 12 occupations, from whom you'll chose 6 each time, giving you a totally different draw deck aka playing experience each time. So I'm wondering: did the original design had more occupations and did they just split things up? The boxes are certainly made to hold more cards then just those 6 occupations you get in each box!

item.name: Guilds of London
item.comment:
Played the prototype according to the rules version 8.1.
I like this game: turns are fast and everything is straightforward. But I hope they do invest in some nice artwork like Snowdonia, that the game will need, or it will look to dull.

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment: Very nice little game, perfect to end a gaming evening

item.name: Die GulliPiratten: Der Schrecken der Kanalisation
item.comment: Very fast paced game with a little bit of strategy in (use of different abilities of your crew). More of a filler game in fact to play when in the right mood.

item.name: Gulo Gulo
item.comment: One play with 3 and it seemed a bit too easy. Probably better with more as it's more likely you'll make a miss. In this games kids seem to have an advantage over adults as there fingers are smaller and that's easier to grab the eggs.

item.name: Habitat
item.comment: Seems like a game with more exceptions then basic rules; the niche-card is to powerfull

item.name: Hacienda
item.comment: You need to superfocus on the markets; the other things you can score points with are like crumbs compared with that

item.name: Haithabu
item.comment:
The low rating (6.31 on 27/12/2015), the negative comments here on BGG about too much luck and randomness and the not so exciting rules, made my expectations were very, very low. But after playing it, it turned out to be a more then OK game. The only thing that bothers me a bit is the fact that when someone choses for the night and throws a 6 the others lose a good (or 2 VP if they have none). So my advice is (and tell it to everybody): always keep a 'spare' good like some cheap meat apart simply for cases like this. Or simply change the rule that you can voluntary chose to give up 2 VP instead of the good, as it often will provide you more VP's and especially fresh money.
Some of the negative comments concern about the randomness of the vehicles, but I don't see a problem with that. I chose a combo of vehicle and order card first before transporting something and I never had the feeling there was absolutely no match, neither that there was only 1 possible combo. And in the worst case scenario there is a character that lets you chose from the top 3.
But it's a fact that you have to play opportunistically in this game, you can't start this game and plan to go for orange goods for example or something like that, you have to see what the market gives and try to make the best deals in the current situation. I especially like how hard it is to realise a simple order, which makes the game stays interesting and provides enough challenge. It's not a top game, but I'll happily play it if someone wants to try it.

item.name: Hameln
item.comment:
This is one of the strangest games I've ever played. The thing is that you are playing without really knowing what you are doing as you play 3 rounds, but they are all just a prelude to 1 final scoring. My advice if you try this game or play with beginners is to play 1 round, do a virtual scoring and then just rebegin your game.;
I think this can be 1 of those games who's full potential can come alive by playing it a couple of times with the same people. But with all those new games coming out, I don't think that this will occur in my gaming group :s

item.name: Hamsteren
item.comment: I'm wondering how much control you actually have?

item.name: Hamsterrolle
item.comment: Quick balancing game, clearly a genre Zoch likes with already Bamboleo and Riff Raff in their assortment :-)

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: It's harder that you would imagine after reading the rules. But a lot depends on how good everybody is on giving/understanding information to your fellow players. Good filler though.

item.name: Hanging Gardens, The
item.comment: In the genre, I think Bloom is better

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment: Lots of ways to score points, you really have to focus!

item.name: Hansa Teutonica: Britannia
item.comment: Some nice tweaks

item.name: Hansa Teutonica: Die Ost Erweiterung
item.comment: The permanent bonus markers are a nice addition an yet an other thing you can focus on, but it's not a 'must have' - expansion

item.name: Hanze
item.comment: Good medium game.

item.name: Harbour
item.comment:
Seen the not so great rating (6.73 at 17/02/2015) I was pleasantly surpised by my first play. Scores were very close together and plays are fast enough.
As only 3 characters were used and about 1/5 or 1/6 of the buildings, I think replayability of this game will also be good.

item.name: Harbour: Launch Promo Characters
item.comment: Even more replayability :-)

item.name: Hare & Tortoise
item.comment: Because of the artwork, this looks like a silly, easy game, but it is certainly not! On the contrary, it requires some good planning and calculation to finish at the right moment. This game has been designed in 1973 already, but really withstood the test of time.

item.name: Haus der Sonne
item.comment:
I don't understand the low scores of this one. There is clearly a lot more going on then just putting down some numbered disks. It's not as easy as the rules - or the theme - let you think, you'll probably have to play this a couple of times to fully understand how you can manipulate things in your favour.
Edit 08/11/2015: increased rating after second play. Now I knew which cards that are in each deck - and I also explained this to my opponent - it's far from easy to put the right disk on the right beach.

item.name: Havana
item.comment: Not too long, not too difficult with enough challanging choices. Great.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: Like the mechanics more then from Agricola, but the theme is really paste on (harvest phase in a harbour??);Also: Agricola is better solo then Le Havre. What is the minus of this game however that is that while playing time decreases with the number of players in Agricola, here it says almost the same (and it will take you a while :s). So in the Harvest-trilogy, I like Agricola the most, then At the Gates of Loyang and Le Havre comes 3rd because of it's long playing time.

item.name: Le Havre: Le Grand Hameau
item.comment: It's nice to have some variation, but not really necessary as you already have a lot of special buildings in the base game

item.name: Le Havre: The Inland Port
item.comment: one play, and not really convinced. It feels different then Le Havre (the boardgame), which is good, but it just seems like pushing cubes forward and up to put them down again. And that didn't put me on fire as they say...

item.name: Hawaï
item.comment: Very good game

item.name: Hawaii: The Grace of Kamapua'a
item.comment: OK addition, but a lot of handeling when preparing each round

item.name: De Hazelnootridders
item.comment: Memory with a twist, but nicely done and appealing components and artwork.

item.name: The Heavens of Olympus
item.comment:
The artwork and overall quality of the components are really bad. The artwork ain't functional either, it's hard to see who is in which sector and in which orbit.
It's the kind of game I wouldn't mind playing if someone asked me for it, but I don't think I would chose it myself if I had to pick a game out of my collection

item.name: De Heersers van de Nijl
item.comment: I like the principle of the scoring mechanism, but maybe a bit too random as that crop you need just doensn't get harvested if you have a field of it. But it's a very quick game, so there is always time for a rematch :D

item.name: Helios
item.comment:
First of all: alone for artwork and the very high (German) quality of the components: big thumbs up, this is an example for all publishers for how to make an appealing boardgame. Also the rules are written very clearly, in literature, we would call this a pageturner.
The game itself: chose a path and try to stick to it as you don't have that many actions during an entire game. For a HiG-game it's quite heavy, but for being such a strategic game, it plays very fast.
Already looking forward to playing this again!

item.name: Hellweg westfalicus
item.comment: It's a light medium weight game, as you can expect from Michael Schacht. If you're willing to count (how much each city has already became into play), you can plan strategically, as you can really plan if it's still worth to invest in a certain connection/type of good. But then again, that's not something you expect as something you should do from a light medium game. So I'm not convinced after 1 play (with only 2, which probably ain't the best number to play this game).

item.name: Hellweg westfalicus: Freie Wahl
item.comment: Quite handy to get the building of the other colour in the same city.

item.name: Helvetia
item.comment: One play so far, very impressed by this game. Very original game mechanic with the marrige and making children - concept. I think it shines the most with 4. To score big points: Aim for chains (example: deliver last good of a chain, taking +2 and chainbonustile).

item.name: Helvetia: Wanderarbeiter aus Österreich
item.comment: Rather weak character. Maybe usefull if you wanna occupy a building that you just built, but in our 1 game with this migrant he was only used twice.

item.name: Hengist
item.comment:
Well, this ain't no Patchwork. And that is probably the reason why the rating (5.50 on 08/11/2015) is so extremely low. It's no Patchwork for the main reason this is much, much lighter. Here you simply grab what your cards allow you to grab.
I guess Uwe Rosenberg experiences here what Martin Wallace did when he designed a series of lighter games like Ankh-Morpork or Witches: his fans of his harder games just bashed the game with low scores. And this is what is happening to this game, it doesn't have the same scale of complexity, but is more a light filler genre Lost Cities, and that's not what people are expecting from a Uwe Rosenberg these days.
Edit: an extra reason for the low rating is people playing it by the wrong rules (as the English ones contains mistake :s). You should first read this: https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1451338/what-are-we-doing-wrong-rules-dont-make-sense-me

item.name: Hermagor
