item.comment: Good tense game, that's easy to explain

item.name: HeroQuest: Return of the Witch Lord
Hexenflug
item.comment: Pure push-your-luck, fast card game

item.name: Hexenhochhaus
item.comment: For an adult it is very easy to remember who is flipped and who ain't, but still I enjoyed my 1 play so far very much and so did the child who played along

item.name: Hey Froggy!
item.comment:
I'm a bit puzzled about this one. I like the game concept, but basically there are not so many things that you really 'control: You can decide to add an extra die, which increases your chances of having 1 of the numbers you need. And when you have the possibility to score 3 cards at a time, you just have to use all the flies you have, otherwise you're not playing good. The other thing is: instead of scoring, getting rid of cards from whom you presume you won't score them in a near future in place of scoring just that 1.
The question is: is this enough or ain't the luck too big in this game? Future plays will point out.

item.name: High Frontier
item.comment: Maybe I missed something, but this game is too long, too hard; It's the kind of game where after an hour you'll see who will win, but you will still play another 2 hours :s

item.name: High Society
item.comment: Nice short auction game

item.name: Hippe kippen
item.comment: OK to play from time to time

item.name: Historia
item.comment: Civ game were you have the classic war/technology on whom you can develop. I like the action card mechanism they selected and the end of a round with the revolution action. But playing time seems a bit too long.

item.name: Historia: Civilization Goals
item.comment: You can get some nice bonuspoints from this, but it's not that evident to aim for those bonustokens and for fill your leader.

item.name: Hive Carbon: The Pillbug
item.comment: I think this piece is great to unblock a certain situation, otherwise it's quite useless.

item.name: Hive: The Ladybug
item.comment: Quite powerfull this one

item.name: De Hobbit
item.comment: It's OK to play, but you have so little control over the course of the game, that I don't need to replay it again. The Ring also seems a bit too powerfull and with only 1 chance to get it during a travel to a certain location, also on this point is luck that will decide who will get it.

item.name: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey – Das Kartenspiel
item.comment: What to say about this game.?Is it bad, no, that you can't say. But it certainly won't set you on fire while playing this. It is - yet again - a filler game from Knizia, but I think I already own enough of his recent filler games. It's about time he earns some credits again and makes a descent game!

item.name: De Hobbit: Het Kaartspel
item.comment: The way Thorin has the distribute cards completely ruins this game imho. In our 1 play, Smaug won, because Thorin killed himself and Bilbo by winning the last trick :s

item.name: Hollywood
item.comment:
I guess you can describe this game the best as Dream Factory from Knizia with only 1 auction (for special cards) and with cards you get using the drafting mechanism from 7 Wonders. Nevertheless you get a family stylish game that works and plays fast enough.
The only thing that worries me a bit is that there is no safety net for if you have no director (as you have the worthless script for a script), because if you can't make a movie in 1 of the just 3 rounds, I think you're screwed for the rest of the game. It luckily didn't happen in our game and then you have a nice, lighter game.

item.name: Hollywood: Stretch Goal Cards
item.comment: An absolute must have add-on as it introduces the Second Unit Director, which was imho a flaw in the base game (having no director made you lose an entire round, which is too painfull when there are only3 rounds).

item.name: Hollywood: The Other Side of Hollywood
item.comment: Only negative cards, nothing for my taste

item.name: Homesteaders
item.comment: Everything works great together; probably better with 4

item.name: HomeStretch
item.comment: Not that hilariours/fun as Long Shot, but still very enjoyable and fun to play for the nice playing time of 45 minutes. The races during the game can be exciting though. But if you play this, you'll have to except that you'll need some (calculated) luck to win!

item.name: Hoogspanning: Australië & India
item.comment: Only played the India-map, but that's not a good one. The new system for buying your resources just slows down the game too much and that's not exactly what I'm looking for: a slower Power Grid :s

item.name: Hoogspanning: De eerste vonken
item.comment: Plus: it's a more streamlined version of Power Grid. Certainly easier for people who aren't familiar with the principle. Minus: the auction-system is certainly fasther, but maybe a bit too easy. If you're first to auction af a card, it's even more important you can estimate what your opponents want.

item.name: Hoogspanning: De Robots
item.comment: Very good addition if you're only with 2 or 3 players. You can manipulate the robot, but hey, everybody can do that ;)

item.name: Hoogspanning: Noord-Europa
item.originalname: Power Grid: Northern Europe/United Kingdom & Ireland
item.comment: Seems to be a map creating strange effects :D In Northern Europe, you definitely wanna go for nuclear!

item.name: Hornet
item.comment: Don't know what really to think about this game yet. One thing is for sure: it's quite aggressive as you are direct competing for each hive and I don't know if I like such a high aggression factor

item.name: Horse Fever
item.comment: This game has some potential, but has a lot of beginners mistake. Just a few of them: the art work is very special, something you either like or dislike, there is no inbetween. Everybody has a character, but they didn't print the starting capital or special ability on it, so you have to look it up in the rules and remember your special ability. Too much stuff going on: we almost had to look up every action card, this is bad. Rules in English or French or not well translated and unclear.

item.name: Hospital Rush
item.comment:
The 'RUSH' in Hospital Rush is very well chosen, as you really have to rush to give your patients the medicins they need.
However, the 'take-that' - factor is too high for my taste (or my playing group).

item.name: Hot Tin Roof
item.comment: Typical Colovini: pure abstract with cat-theme pasted on it, not a lot of rules and a short enough playing time.

item.name: Hotel Samoa
item.comment: Rating based on one incomplete game; During the game I never had any fun-feeling at all

item.name: How to Host a Murder: The Duke's Descent
item.comment: The dressing up part is too much for me

item.name: Hungry Hungry Hippos
item.comment: Just a fun kids game (rated as a kids game)

item.name: Hyperborea
item.comment:
Bag building was definitely THE mechanism at Essen 2014 :-)
Surprising good feeling after a first game. I already liked their first design (Al Rashid, which is totally different), but like Al Rashid I'm afraid this (not so cheap) game will stay under the radar of a lot of people. A shame!

item.name: Hyperborea: Promo Set
item.comment: a little bit more stuff.

item.name: Identik
item.comment: OK Game to play from time to time

item.name: Identik Extension Bleu
item.comment: These pictures are sometimes really hard to describe and some of the criteria concern really tiny details on the pictures.

item.name: Identik Extension Rouge
item.comment: Same rating as the base game. The images seems to be more complicated with this expansion.

item.name: Iglu Pop
item.comment: If you're looking for something different (to play with your kids), this is your game

item.name: Im großen Zauberwald
item.comment: Mmmh, not so exciting game. If you're playing mixed (adult - children), it will be very hard for a child to win. It's the kind of game where 1 player can dominate all the others as he has more reaction skills.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment: This game takes way too long; nothing for me

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: Feels very, very similar to 51st State (especially with the 'ruine'-concept from the Winter-expansion). But it's smoother to play and with graphics that are far more appealing.

item.name: Imperial Settlers: Atlanteans
item.comment: What a horrible expansion. If a player gets a good start in the first round (= has a lot of production), that starting bonus is only magnified if he has also wheels as the double the production. Very bad extra mechanism those production wheels!!

item.name: Imperial Settlers: Why Can't We Be Friends
item.comment: + for open production, - for destruction cards

item.name: In de voetsporen van Marco Polo
item.comment: It's the designer-duo of Tzolk'in, but don't expect a Tzolk'in. Expect a HiG-game, a medium+ - game, with well written rules, nice components and a more then enough challenging gameplay.

item.name: In Flanders Field
item.comment: Can't Stop but different (enough) :-)

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: By far the most heavy game of Stefan Feld, in which you just have to except that your people will die :s

item.name: Inca Empire
item.comment: Just good with 3, probably better with 4

item.name: Inca Empire: Bonus Sun Event Cards
item.comment: OK if you have it, but not something you must have

item.name: Indigo
item.comment: Typical Knizia from the last years: nothing really new (mechanism from Tsuro or Metro), but with a twist so that it still feels that little different. Good, but not great.

item.name: Industrial Waste
item.comment: OK game, but nothing spectacular.

item.name: Industry
item.comment: When I first read the rules, I thought 'that's it?'. But there is a lot more going on and timing (when to have money) is really crucial

item.name: Infiltration
item.comment: Rather light game, not to bad, but nothing to get really excited about either

item.name: Innovation
item.comment: Don't know about this one; we had of lot of issues of how to interprete the text on the cards

item.name: Invaders
item.comment:
The game had a sort of Android: Netrunner revisited - light feeling: typical game that you need to play with the same person a couple of times to completely master it and see all the possibilities. But the text and symbols are clearer then in AN and near the end of the game things become clear.
However your first game will take a while as you just have to figure out what your cards exactly do. The text on the cards is also printed very small, so if you have to pick a card to destroy, you'll have to ask what every card does. Not a bad game, but if I'll have to pick out a game out of Revolver, Revolver 2 or Invaders, my first pick will always be Revolver 2 and this one will always be last I'm afraid (maybe also because I'm not into the space theme).

item.name: La Isla
item.comment: Much lighter and more luck dependant game then I'm used from Feld, but then again is a game in the small box - series of Alea. I think that a house rule were you get 4 (or 5 hive you have the special power that gives you 1 more card) and discard a card make this a better game.

item.name: Isla Dorada
item.comment: Good family game

item.name: Island Fortress
item.comment:
Not so good with 2 as you can avoid each other; Game can have a runaway leader- problem if someone can fullfil his favour cards early and win the petition (more) easy or doesn't have any problems taking jade anymore.
The things I wrote above were based on the JKLM-online version (called Huang-Di at that time). Bought this game for myself, just as I was curious to see what the game has become. It felt quite similar at what the game was back in 2009. But with coming out so many games out these days, it has a hard time withstanding the test of time. It's not a bad game, but it's not a great game either. However here in Europe it's a very expensive game, and it's simply just not worth the money they are asking for it, especially if you take into account that the boards you get are very very flimsy!

item.name: Isle of Skye: From Chieftain to King
item.comment: After Cornwall the second game with tile placement that I actually enjoy. If this continues, tile placement will become my favourite gaming mechanism :-) But here it's off course because the fun is setting the prices and trying to guess which tile has which value for the others.

item.name: Isle of Skye: From Chieftain to King – Brettspiel Adventskalender Promo Tiles
Istanbul
item.comment:
We took the suggested starting set-up. And you really feel that the routes are optimized in this start-set-up and you hardly need the fountain as you rarely are in trouble when moving. Hopefully a random set-up will be more challenging.
Update: played with random set-up with only 2 players. This seems to be the way to go for this game!

item.name: Istanbul: Kebab Shop Mini Expansion
item.comment: It makes the Fountain-spot more useful.

item.name: Istanbul: Mokka & Smeergeld
item.comment: Gives extra things you can focus on and doesn't increase the game length too much, which is all positive. The only thing I haven't figured out yet, is if the guild cards are balanced enough?

item.name: It Happens..
item.comment: This is a quick,light game, with still some dept in it. But off course: it's with dice, so you have to live with the fact that you can be lucky or not. Liked my one play so far.

item.name: Ivor the Engine
item.comment: It's a light family game. Not that I mind that, but this one was a bit short for me, it almost felt like a filler game. It reminds me a bit of 'Witches' from Martin Wallace: walk around and make the best of your cards.

item.name: JAB: Realtime Boxing
item.comment: Strange game, not really my thing, but very original I must say

item.name: Jackal & High
item.comment: Where it went according to me wrong for this game, was the choice for D8 instead of normal D6. Even if you get 3 rolls with your final die, the chances to roll that 1 number you need are just too small, making this a pure luckfest.

item.name: Jäger und Sammler
item.comment: Not a lot of (easy) rules, easy to play, not so easy to win; Good game

item.name: Jäger und Späher
item.comment: I'm wondering why no other publishers are picking up these great games like Kashgar or this Jäger + Späher, as they are language independent a lot of people would like to have them in there own language. I guess the license costs from Kosmos are too high?

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment: Quite Light, but entertaining

item.name: Jambo
item.comment: Very good 2-player game

item.name: Java
item.comment: After 5 years, I finally got to play this. Should have played this much earlier as it is really a good game. A true classic!

item.name: Jerusalem
item.comment: Not really new exciting majority game, but everything works just great together. If you like majority games, I certainly recommend this one

item.name: Johari
item.comment: With 4 it definitely takes too long for what it is. Lighter game for 2 or 3.

item.name: Jungle Ascent
item.comment: Very light, but fun and quick game to play

item.name: Junta: Viva el Presidente!
item.comment: How the hell this became number 1 on the Essen Fairplay - list??? In our one play, I didn't buy any dice, didn't use a single action card, just drew/got money and bought a building and I also draw a card with a point on and I had won :s

item.name: K2
item.comment:
Good game, but don't understand the hype about this one;
With 5: use the extra player - option that you can be on the same plateau!

item.name: K2: Broad Peak
item.comment: Nice to have as well an easier as a more difficult board.

item.name: K2: Lawina
item.comment: Ok expansion

item.name: Kaas Kasteel
item.comment: Best kid game ever

item.name: Kahuna
item.comment: There is clearly a sort of runaway-leader problem for this game: if your opponent can get 6 out of 11 islands, the only thing he has to focus on is defending his position. And if you can't attack him fast enough, he can even start focussing on attacking your islands. The main issue is that is very hard to take over an island. IF and only IF you have almost the majority over an island (let's say is 3 - 2 on an island with 5 connections) your opponent controls, you still need 3 cards to take over majority: 2 to remove the bridge and 1 to put 1 bridge of your own to take over control. That means that from the 4 possible cards (as each island appears 2 times), you need 3 to realize this! Off course, if you can succeed, you'll do some serious damage as he will lose 2 connections extra, which opens probably possibilities for some more damage.

item.name: Kairo
item.comment: This game surprised me in apositive way. After reading the typical Queen-Games-not-so-long rulebook, I thought 'how can this be any fun?'. But I must say that it's harder then it looks and requires some good planning during the game. I think the only disadvantage is that the shining number of this game is 4 players, as it's probably the only number you will have a very crowded market and possibilities to cut of your fellow players.

item.name: Kaispeicher
item.comment: Adds more strategy to the game, but also extends the playing time. I hoped for some randomness from this expansion, but again all cards come out :s

item.name: Kalua
item.comment: The game lasts way too long for what it is. It's also too aggresive for my taste as in fact your goal is to screw your opponents as much as possible.

item.name: Kamisado
item.comment: easy rules, hard to play

item.name: Kanban: Automotive Revolution
item.comment:
Well, Vinhos and CO2, weren't light and this one certainly ain't either. My brain went banana's after Surya's explanation and the first round I didn't have a clue of what I was doing :s
But I liked it :-)

item.name: Kardinaal & Koning
item.comment: quite dry, but OK game

item.name: Kardinaal & Koning: Vatikaan
item.comment: Don't think I'll ever add this again

item.name: Karesansui
item.comment:
Typical 6 for me: ask me to play this and I'll play it without hesitation, but I'll never pick it myself out of my collection when choosing a game.
What I don't like about this game is the fact that the game can end when the black rock comes out of the bag.

item.name: Karesansui: Weeds
item.comment: Nasty little things those weeds :-)

item.name: Karnag
item.comment: If you listen to rules, things seems easier to get done then they are in reality. Putting down does menhirs is a fucking hard task and encircling Ker Ys is far from obvious:s Very good game! Only minus point is the movement of the creatures, that's not always clear how they should move.

item.name: Karnag: The Congregations
item.comment: Don't seem to add that much; only 1 play but some seems to be easier then others

item.name: Karnag: The Congregations – Kaoterioù
item.comment: Same rating as 'The Congregations';

item.name: Karuba
item.comment: Nice acquaintance with the family line of Haba :-)

item.name: Käse Würfeln
item.comment: Ok dice game, but after all not that exciting or new. Takes a bit too long for what it is.

item.name: Kashgar: Händler der Seidenstraße
item.comment: How good can you make a game that plays very smoothly with so little rules? The answer is: Kashgar! Incomprehensible that no other publishing company sees the quality of this game and is willing to make an edition in his language: Come on ZMan, WGG, 999 Games,... this will do excellent! It's strongly language dependant, so most people would like to have this in their mother language

item.name: Kathedraal (De)
item.comment:
I don't like the base game where you always have the same 4 craftsmen in every round. I think the frustration can be too big as you can go for converting metal, but be unlucky when the master builders are drawn.
I like it a lot more with the extra craftsmen from one of the expanions, as then you don't know what will come, so you (and the rest) have to play more opportunistic.

item.name: Kathedraal (De) - Nieuwe Ambachtslui
item.originalname: The Pillars of the Earth: New Craftsmen
item.comment: It's nice that you have some randomisation of the craftsmen

item.name: De Kathedraal: Het Kaartspel
item.originalname: Die Säulen der Erde: das Kartenspiel
item.comment: 'Strange' trick-taking - cardgame

item.name: Keltis
item.comment: Good for inbetween or the end the evening

item.name: Keltis: Das Kartenspiel
item.comment: Nice spin off from the boardgame

item.name: Keltis: Das Orakel
item.comment: You have a little less luck dependance of the drawing of the cards in comparence with Keltis and you can choose different strategies

item.name: Keltis: Das Würfelspiel
item.comment: OK dice game, but maybe a tad too long for what it is.

item.name: Keltis: Der Weg der Steine Mitbringspiel
item.comment: It's quick and easy; just OK

item.name: Keltis: Neue Wege, Neue Ziele
item.comment: Never take a big jump in a colour if you play with this map!

item.name: Kemet
item.comment:
It certainly has similarities with Cyclades, but I think I prefer this one more as there our more ways to score points and going to war is just one of them.
One advice when playing this: if you've lost some troops on a fight away from home base, just withdraw and retroop, as otherwise your opponents can score too easily

item.name: Kenya
item.comment: I always like games where you have to guess who is having what, so I liked playing this. Nothing really new here, but all works together very nicely!

item.name: Key Market
item.comment: Dry, quite heavy strategic game. It's very cuththroat, you'll have to play constantly at your limits.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment: No so difficult to explain/understand, but not so easy to see all the flows and things you need. Certainly the best 'Key'-game I played so far!

item.name: Keyflower: Key Celeste
item.comment: Don't like this kind of 'bully'-features

item.name: Keyflower: The Farmers
item.comment: This expansion offers extra possibilities to score, which is Always nice, but in general the base game is solid enough that it doesn't really need this expansion

item.name: Keyflower: The Merchants
item.comment: Exactly the same feeling as with the Farmers-expansion: not a bad expansion, but certainly not a must add-on

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: Good games can withstand the test of time. It's only in 2014 I could get my hands on a copy and I'm glad I did, as it is my kind of game.

item.name: Khan
item.comment: Good, not too heavy game

item.name: Khan: the Golden Yurts
item.comment: If you place it wel, it can make a golden connection for you

item.name: King of New York
item.comment: I expected this to be just a clone of King of Tokyo, but all the changes they made (buildings who become units who can attack you and especially 3 new actions instead of the 1, 2 and 3 of KoT) feel like real improvements who make this without any doubt the better version of the 2.

item.name: King of New York: Improvised Weapons
King of New York: Monster Idol
King of Tokyo
item.comment: This is a game you have to play just for the fun of it

item.name: King of Tokyo Promo Cards
item.comment: There are some nice cards in this pack

item.name: King of Tokyo: Halloween
item.comment: This feels like an expansion just to make an expansion as it will sell because the base game is very popular. No added value at all.

item.name: King of Tokyo: Power Up!
item.comment: The Pandakaï is a very cool firgure, but te Power-Up expansion I personally find rather lame. It's a card you get by accident imho. If you need extra life, then you could go for a power-up card as a bonus, but I can't imagine you would go for 3 hearts if you still have 10 lives. So it's something that happens to you as an extra, not something you would play for.

item.name: King's Pouch
item.comment: Well, there seems to be something very wrong with this game, at least with 2 (my only playing experience). The player with the most points becomes starting player, which makes that he can pick as first the best building there is. And so he will score more points and stay first player and will always have first pick. And some buildings are clearly stronger then others, so this makes a huge difference!

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment: Definitly a game of Donald X. Vaccarino: fast, not too difficult, just enough complexity. Easier then Dominion

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Capitol
item.comment: Doesn't add that much: you can get nice points from building around one, but normally you can get more from the scoring cards.

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Caves
item.comment: This is an excellent mini-expansion, as it largers the strategic level a lot as you can maneuver with your settlements near a cave. Just make sure you built next to a cave as early as possible!

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Crossroads
item.comment: The extra wooden pieces are nice, but the very best location is the Crossraods itself!

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Nomads
item.comment: The extra randomness with extra 4 tiles with special abilities OK, Nomad tiles OK, but best module for me are the 3 new scoring cards. As they score immediately after your turn, they give you a (direct) goal during the game as well

item.name: Kingdom Builder: The Island
item.comment: Not much added value;

item.name: Kingdom of Solomon
item.comment: Very good worker placement game. Especially like the idea of some very powerfull places, but you have to give up all your remaining action spaces. Also nice: in our first game everybody tried a different strategy and they all seemed to be feasible!

item.name: Kingdom of Solomon Promo: Levite Camp
item.comment: OK extra, but not necessary

item.name: Kings of Air and Steam
item.comment:
It's basically a pick-up-and-delivery game. The picking-up is a bit more complicated then normally because you have to land exactly on the factory and you do this by playing cards from whom some have diamonds on them and you can't play more diamonds then your limit or you lose that turn.
De delivery is in fact a 2-step delivery: first your zeppelin has to deliver from the factory to a depot of yours (which ain't that hard as you can build them anywere (as long as you have the money)) and then you have to use your train to deliver the goods from your depot to a city who wants that good. This last part feels very similar to the mechanism used in Railroad Tycoon/Railways of the World.
+ Lots of material: After punching out all parts I can barely close my box + All works together fine - Rather high price (in Europe) - There are 3 configurations in the rulebook: 2-3 players, 3-5 players and 6-7 players. With less then the maximum number of each configuration, there won't be much interference between the players. We played with 4 and certainly in the beginning of the game everybody stayed more or less in 'his/her' corner of the board. - Playing time: almost 2 hours for 4 (all new) players I found a bit too long. 90 minutes would have been excellent.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: Playing time is too long

item.name: Kingsburg: To Forge a Realm
item.comment: It's not good that some variable rows are better then others, the same for the characters

item.name: Kingsport Festival
item.comment:
A game with the core mechanism of Kingsburg from the same designers. So how does it compare to Kingsburg?
Well, the positive is that gaming time seems to more under control in Kingsport Festival. Our first game took 100 minutes with all 4 new players (but all played Kingsburg before) and some time loss due to getting drinks, that's as good as the 90 minutes the box promises. The gaming time is my biggest complaint about Kingsburg as it can take too long for what it is, so that seems to be fixed in Kingsport Festival.
But then the negative. In Kingsburg there was a reward/token that let you manipulate your dice by 1. That made you had more control to manipulate dice. Here you have almost none. The purple spells aren't that flexible as those tokens. An other big minus point is that this game contains more Ameritrash as it adds events, so this game contains definitely more chaos. And the Festivalcard is a total crapshoot as there is hardly any chance to look at it AND prepare for it. The artwork is also very dark (probably OK for the Cthulhu-lovers) and the text is small, very small. Especially on the cards it's a shame they spoil half of the card with flavour text nobody is gonna read, while you need a lot of light and good sight to be able to read the actual text that matters.
For me it's clear: Kingsburg stays in the collection, this one can go.

item.name: Die kleinen Zauberlehrlinge
item.comment: It's a pity they didn't use the mechanism of The Magical Labyrinth. Now it's way to easy for adults (too little traps)

item.name: Kohle & Kolonie
item.comment:
The rulebook is apparently a mess, but I had the luck that someone who had played it 3 times before, could explain the rules.
And in fact it seemed not that hard to explain the rules, as there are only 5 different sort of actions you can chose from and there are 10 phases in a round, but most of them are quite straightforward, only the merging of mines requires some explanation.
However, this is the kind of game where it's very hard to do well with only 15 actions (and possibly some bonus actions at a cost of 4 VP). You have to make up a plan and stick by it.
To be short: this is the kind of strategy-game I like: squize the maximum out of a minimum of actions :D

item.name: Kolejka
item.comment:
Rating based on 1 play with 5 players. I like some chaos in a game, but this game was way too chaotic for me. With 5 - and so 15 possible cards played - everything can change too dramaticly.
With 3, my rating might go up, as you probaly have more controll

item.name: Kolonisten van Amerika (De)
item.originalname: Catan Histories: Settlers of America – Trails to Rails
item.comment: By far the best Settlers - stand-alone I've played so far; Really like the mechanics, but the long playing time is a bummer for me; If it could be reduced to 90 minutes, I would rate this game a 9.

item.name: Kolonisten van Catan
item.comment: The game that started everything for me

item.name: Kolonisten van Catan (De): Steden & Ridders
item.comment: Don't like this expansion as it changes the game too much; If you lose your city on the first turn the barbarians arrive, it's very hard to win

item.name: Kolonisten van Catan - Het Kaartspel
item.conditiontext: We played it once, but my girlfriend doesn't like it

item.name: Kolonisten van de Prehistorie (De)
item.originalname: The Settlers of the Stone Age

item.name: Kolonsiten van Catan (De) - Uitbreiding 5 - 6
item.comment: The intermediate rounds make that the game takes longer, so no more then 5 players for me.

item.name: Koningsburcht (De)
item.comment: OK Game, nothing special, but you have enough things you can focus on and short playing time

item.name: De Koningsburcht: Winterkaarten
item.originalname: A Castle for All Seasons: Winter Cards
item.comment: I'm not really that crazy about event crads, but these one makes a rather harder game, which prevents from everything being built and all places being taken, which can happen on the summerboard more easily.

item.name: Koopmanshuis, Het
item.comment: Lighter then I'm used from Stefan Feld; OK game but replayabilty ain't that good

item.name: Korrigans
item.comment:
I like heavy games, like ZhanGuo, but I certainly can also enjoy this kind of lighter family games, with very nice components and artwork.
You just have to make the best of it, there's a certain level of strategy in it (don't leave the bonus rocks for your opponents! and should you take the gold - the points - or the animals for more flexibility?), but off course you need a bit of luck with the hidden chits.

item.name: Korsar
item.comment: Nice, quick card game

item.name: Koryŏ
item.comment: Quite basic idea (1 card with a 1,...9 with a 9, which are worth as much points as there are cards), but there special powers work very well together. It plays also quite fast, which is also a big plus of this game.

item.name: Kosmonauts
item.comment:
Really well invented gameplay-mechanics with a nice short playing time. However playing this game will always give me a headache as I don't have any spacial awareness and planning my moves is really hard for me :(
When I played this, I always pointed out what I would do, so that I would be able to put my fuel down correctly, so everybody could always just see what my plans were :D

item.name: Kraftwagen
item.comment: I like the game and the flow, but I wonder if engines aren't too powerful in comparison to car body, as an engine can also be used for your racing car and car bodies don't have an other purpose?

item.name: Kraków 1325 AD
item.comment: Not a great first impression, but have to play it again

item.name: Kroko Togo
item.comment: Maybe it's better with more, but with 3 it's hardly a competition when there is a (almost) full display, so the winner is decided when there are almost no cards left. It would be nicer if you have competition from the start of the game until the end.

item.name: Krosmaster: Arena
item.comment:
This game caught my attention when it was a Kickstarter (I love beautiful looking games an I like the board, the components and miniatures a lot), but was turned off by the high price. So I was glad that I could try it at the Essen fair of 2013.
I must say that the game itself was a sort of turn-off for me. I had the feeling that the game was rather playing itself, then I was playing a game where I had to make some hard decisions.
But to be honest, I probably didn't have the full experience. One of my characters had 'dodge' and an other one 'lock' as special ability, and when I asked what that meant, the demo-lady just told me that they didn't explain that at the fair, but that it doesn't change the game a lot :s
But still, even if there would be a bit more strategic in that way, 50 euro was a bit too expensive for my taste for a game that didn't gave me a good playing experience after all.

item.name: Kumbu: Dubbelzijdig Kaartspel
item.comment: How lame is this? It seems they made doubled sided cards and then just re-implemented some existing games like Perudo with it. Just what everybody was waiting for...or NOT!

item.name: Kung Fu
item.comment: Tried this without having any high expectations, but it is in fact quite good. Ideal for taking with you on a holiday if you want a fast-paced game for 2.

item.name: Kwatro
item.comment: It's like Qwirkle, but even a little more complex as you have 3 dimensions (shape, color and number), but less colors (only 4). Games like Qwirkle are however not my favorite style of games.

item.name: Ladies & Gentlemen
item.comment:
This is a very original game with a very recognizable (but I admit, stereotype :D) theme: the men has to earn money so that his woman can buy (expescive) clothes.
It is very light to play and you probably should play this more to have fun and a laugh, then as a real competitive game.
The only thing that 'bothers' me for the moment is the men-part to get money, which is by flipping over tokens. It's a bit random and I can't imagine how you have to organize this if there are 4 or 5 men? You probably have to really sit at an other table so that everybody can reach all tokens :s
2nd play was with Coutisane. Didn't like that 'trick' to make this work with odd number of players. My suggestion is to play this with an even number and with 4 or 6.

item.name: The Ladies of Troyes
item.comment: I was expecting the most from the activity boards on the rampage, but that didn't seemed to do not that much during our 1 game (maybe just not an attractive offer?). The most refreshing I found the new activity cards, as they gave a feeling you had to search for a new strategy. Also the purple die is a simple and nice feature, as you're sure of at least 1 die.

item.name: Lady Alice
item.comment: Good deduction game. The scoring element is renewing and makes it that you just don't have to find te solution (you probably can even win without have everything correct), but the way to come to the solution is very classic for a deduction game.

item.name: Lakota
item.comment: Nice that you can make a game with only 60 wooden bars and a round board. Unfortunately, this ain't the type of game that sets my heart on fire.

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment: I think this must be Queen Games most tactical game so far; Liked my first play; has the potential to become an 8.

item.name: Lancaster: Henry V – The Power of the King
item.comment: Extra possibilities, great. However, they seem to force you towards the conflict with France, so we have to wait and see, before making a final judgement.

item.name: Lancaster: Reward Tiles
item.comment: Not so 'wow'-addition.

item.name: Lancaster: The New Laws
item.comment: There is no need to have this, but it's nice yo have some variation

item.name: Langfinger
item.comment: Not bad, but not really exciting either

item.name: Lap Dance
item.comment: The low rating (5.85 on 17/05/2015) is truly deserved. To summarize it up: where is the fun?

item.name: Lap Dance Kickstarter Stretch Rewards and 5th Player Expansion
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Las Vegas Boulevard
item.comment: Lots of modules who add some extra twists to a game that is excellent by itself.

item.name: Las Vegas: The Slot Machine
item.comment: With less players it makes there is more dilution of the dice, so it ain't that interesting, but it probably is with more players.

item.name: Last Train to Wensleydale
item.comment: My first play left me bedazzeled; For me it's certainly a game to start the evening with, not to end with; Had a second play: enjoyed this game a lot more, as I knew what I had to do

item.name: Last Will
item.comment: Lighter then I expected from a game of Suchy, but still very good!

item.name: Last Will: Getting Sacked
item.comment: It adds some extra stuff/possibilities to the game, without changing the core game, which is by itself already very good. That's what's makes a good expansion for me personally. I guess the most 'drastic' change is that you get a job and have to make sure you get fired :D

item.name: Last Will: Plan Order Board
item.comment: An expansion you can do without

item.name: Leaders of Small World
item.comment: Not a lot of added value

item.name: League of Six
item.comment: One 3-player game, probably shines more with 4 or 5; But liked my one game: very strategic - but uberdry - game

item.name: Leaping Lemmings
item.comment: This is a game were you can screw eachother a lot, so only to play with people who can take that

item.name: Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy
item.comment: Only 1 unfinished game, but there are some nice gaming mechanisms in here and a typical game were you wanna do A, B, C AND D, but only have 2 action disks :D

item.name: Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy – Extra Mansion Cards
item.comment: OK that the mansions also have an extra feauture, but why have the cards be so big?

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment:
This game reminded me a lot of Ascension. It's also a deckbuilding game with 2 'currencies', one for fighting, one for recruiting. However in Ascension those currencies are sort of equel, as cards you recruit or also worth some points. In Legendary you wanna concentrate on good fighting cards as defeating villains or the mastermind is the only way to score points.
I think that the replayability of Legendary is greater then that of Ascension, as your deck of heroes, villains and the mastermind is different every time. But the consequence is that set-up and clean-up of Legendary will take longer as you have to create each deck at the start of your game and sort out all the cards at the end of the game.
Good thing is that there are really a lot of cards in the core set, so that you can create a lot of different sets.
Just as with Ascension turns are quick, so playing time is short enough. The extra 'semi-co-operative aspect (like in CO2) is a nice additional feature.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game – Dark City
item.comment: lots of extra cards and some new abilities on cards like 'versatile', 'bribe' or 'teleport'. If you own the core set + an expansion you will have endless combinations and replayability.

item.name: Legendary: Fantastic Four
item.comment:
I had great fun with the combination 'Mole Man' + the Scheme 'Midtown Bank Robbery', so it's great how a Mastermind can combine excellent with a scheme from the base game.
However they should stop with inventing new terms like 'burrow' with every expansion. Because you have to look up in the rules what it means every time (but with all expansions that's for now 3 possible rulesets) or they should provide them on a player aid. If they continue like this, you'll be more busy looking up stuff then actual playing the game and that would ruin this game, that has as big advantage his smooth playing.

item.name: Legendary: Guardians of the Galaxy
item.comment: They really have to start thinking about including an overview - card in the next expansion that explains all those different features :s

item.name: Legendary: Paint the Town Red
item.comment: More cards, but unfortunately also more new abilities like 'Feast' on the cards :((

item.name: Legendary: Secret Wars – Volume 1
item.comment: A lot of extra cards, but also a lot f money :s And again some extra features! It's very sad they didn't include an overview with all the specials (like focus, wall-crawl,...) from all the expansions so far. Hopefully in Secret Wars 2!

item.name: Legendary: Villains – Fear Itself
item.comment: It 'integrates' with 'Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game', but only if you converte certain terms into others. That's not good for a fast play :s

item.name: De Legenden van Andor
item.comment:
Just 1 play and it was like a co-operative game should be: you have the idea you can win, but you lose close to the finish. So far, so good.
This game won a lot of prices and even was the 2013 'Spiel des Jahres - Kennerspiel des Jahres' Winner. And while I can see this is a good game, I wonder why? I mean, what is really new about it? Scenario's: seen before. Beating up monster to prevent them invading a castle: seen before. Develop your hero to make him stronger: seen before. Do other stuff in the meanwhile: seen before.
The only really new thing I can think about is that every monster you slash brings you 1 day closer to the end of the game. But is it that that makes it win so many prizes? Off course the nice artwork of Menzel probably works. But what worries me the most about this game is the replayability from just the base game. You probably just have to buy all forecoming expansions to keep this game interesting, because once you've done all existing scenario's (and the base game only has 5 :s), the will be not a lot challenge left.

item.name: Lemming Maffia
item.comment: Like it a lot; Good fun

item.name: Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment: Feeling after one game: OK game, but nothing spectacular

item.name: Let's Take a Hike
item.comment: OK card game, but not with 5.

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment:
All new to this game? Well restrict the number of players to a maximum of 3!!!!
I played just 1 game so far with 4 all new. The beginning of the game was fun, as your deck-building and looking out for good combo's. But the last part of the game was really boring: everybody just cycled through his deck, nobody was interested in the new cards anymore and the game was at least 30 minutes too long to stay fun.
Wanna replay to get a better idea, but then with a maximum of 3 players.
Updated 18/06/2014: Played with 2. Much better as downtime is far less off course and I never got bored this game. Still, once you are satisfied with your deck, you just keep cycling through it until you reach the end goal.
Still, after 2 games, I don't understand the hype/very high rating of this game. For me this is an OK game to have, but not a must have.

item.name: Libertalia
item.comment: I liked this game. But when you play this, don't expect a Vasco da Gama, just take the ride of a family game where there can be a little chaos as the characters are chosen from the different players. But as everybody gets at the start of a round the same characters, you can make some sort of estimation of what is possible.

item.name: Liberté
item.comment:
Rating based on 1 - very, very frustrating - play (with 5). It rarely happens that I just want a game to end, but in this game I already had this feeling in round 2.;
It's very hard to see which color is winning and even if you see it, you still need to have cards with that color in your hand. I also think it's bad that the markers you place in the war zone with canons stay in play after a scoring. In our game one player put 5 markes in round 2 there and ,kaching, 12 points - and the victory - for him.

item.name: Liguria
item.comment: It's a typical Queen Game: 8 pages of rules, not that hard to play, neither explain with just enough choices to keep it interesting. But also: nothing really new under the sun.

item.name: Limes
item.comment: For me personally this - pure abstract - game misses a soul, it misses fun. Can be good as a solo-game I think.

item.name: Limes: Startcards Set A
item.comment: I love this expansion, as I hate the fact that you could just copy your adversary

item.name: Linus, der kleine Magier
item.comment:
Just another twist on memory, with also a good portion of luck involved (when you have to chose and no info about that kind of toy is known, it's a simple matter of luck). 100% childern's game, no fun to play as an adult.
Played it with a 7 year-old child and she seemed to enjoy it.

item.name: Little Devils
item.comment: Not good with 3 or 4, but great fun with 5 and especially 6

item.name: Livingstone
item.comment: good game, probably best with 3 or 4

item.name: Loch Ness
item.comment: Surprisingly good (as I knew it had some low ratings) in its category of light, family game. It's an outguess your opponents game, which is a genre I like

item.name: Locomotive Werks
item.comment: This game has a MEGA-runaway leader problem. The player with the most money is able to buy new technology first, so puts the other players who want to get some more profit from there older technology into more trouble, so they are never able to catch up.

item.name: La Loire
item.comment:
Only played the game introducing the base mechanics. Only that however, I found it rather to be repetitive. I hope the cards and circus will intdruce the salt and pepper to this game. Therefore I won't give it a rating yet.
Update 14/12/2012: Played the full game. The cards definitely spice up the game and you can go for certain combo's and see how they work. What I however dislike is the way to get them. The way the circus moves around, you just have to be lucky that you can reach it, or can manipulate it from your own. If you're able to do that early in the game and your opponents don't, that can make a hugue difference!
What I also dislike is the gaming time of a full game. That's main due to the fact that half of the 'decisions' you make in the game aren't really decisions because they are the only thing you can do (often with your messanger) or just the obvious to do buy wine/cheese cheap if you don't have it yet). Only when you're in Orléans/Nantes you have to make some real decisions or if you're able to reach the circus.
Conclusion: Not a bad game, but if I wanna play a game of this length, I'll doubt I'll chose this one.
Update 30/12/2012: Apparently we played the way to move the circus wrong. With the correct rule, the position of the circus is more stable, but it can still be annoying if it justs move before you arrive. Still find this game dull to play.

item.name: London
item.comment: Great game! Don't neglect your money-engine mid-game, as brown cards become scarce near the end!

item.name: Long Shot
item.comment: You really get the feeling you're on the horse track

item.name: Longhorn
item.comment:
+ Very easy to explain + Plays very quick + Despite the easy rules, it's not the obvious to play well
- Played 4 times and the player who fells behind, never seems to have a chance of getting back into the game - Don't know if I love the sheriff: if you're opponent can move back each time, then you're screwed. My advice: stay away from the tile with the sheriff-token on!

item.name: Loony Quest
item.comment: Loony Quest = arcade games transformed into a boardgame. Not bad, even amusing to do from time to time, but I think replayability of this one is rather low. Off course, you can make tons of expansions for this game :s

item.name: Looping Louie
item.comment: Fun entertainment; just a bit pity that you lose a chicken if you hit your paddle to hard

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: One - exciting - play and I must say it was a nice acquaintance with the LCG-genre.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Duel
item.comment: Not to bad, but a bit boring; You don't feel like you're fighting a duel

item.name: Lords of Scotland
item.comment: Good card game!

item.name: Lords of Vegas
item.comment:
My first gaming experience with this game was really too frustrating: as I was aiming for just 2 colors (OK, maybe that was not the best strategy after all), but with big casinos, I couldn't afford to lose my purple casino to Wouter. I paid 7!!! times to reroll and become casino-boss and failed 7! times.
This game will go into a dark corner of my collection and MAYBE when my memory has faded out this experience, it will be on the gaming table again.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: Worker placement game in a Quest forfilling setting. Nothing quite innovating, but everything works very well together!

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep: Rapid Expansion Promo Card
Lords of Waterdeep: Scoundrels of Skullport
item.comment: Very good expansion, especially the Skullport-module: will the minus-points be less then the benefit you gain from taking the spot at Skullport?

item.name: Lords of Xidit
item.comment:
Everybody programs his actions and then tries to pick-up (= recruit units) or deliver (= fight monsters). The trying is due to the fact that if someone takes the last unit or fights the monster before you, you will have nothing and wasted at least 2 actions (1 movement and 1 recruiting/fighting action).
What you should take into account (and I neglected completely during our game :s), is that you know the next location of the 'future' monster or recruiting place. So if you think someone will empty a recruiting tile or fight a monster, it's smart to go over there if you're in the neighbourhood.

item.name: Lords of Xidit: Bonus Titans Promo
item.comment: Added value is almost nothing

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: Make sure to play your carsd in time as the end of a round comes faster then you think :s

item.name: Lost Legacy: The Starship
item.comment: Love Letter in space with some extra's (the investigation) and made expandable

item.name: Lost Legends
item.comment:
This is the second game I play of Mike Elliott. The first was Thunderstone (with some expansions and also Thunderstone Advance). I really enjoy Thunderstone, but have 1 big issue with the game: the playing time. More often then not the combination of cards will make that the game is sort of stuck. What Thunderstone misses is streamlined gameplay.
I have exactly the same issue with Lost Legends. The first part, the 7 Wonders-drafting of equipment is just fine. But then comes the combat with monsters and then this go awefully wrong. My main issue is the getting of monsters. Why make things so complicated: look at the monster, study if you can defeat it, if not pass it to an opponent IF someone has a free slot for a monster. Then study the central monster, see if you can defeat it. If not, draw a monster from the deck. Again study it. If you don't like it, again give it to an opponent IF there is one with an open slot. And finally draw a new monster and hope you have won the lottery (by whom I mean you finally get a monster you can defeat). This is not only hard to explain, it makes thing drag on far too long!

item.name: Lost Legends: Forest of the Damned (Queenie 2)
Lost Temple
item.comment: No wow-feeling as the core mechanism is really the same as that from Machiavelli; Still this is a good game, excellent to play with the family

item.name: Lost Temple: The Mandarin
item.comment: I don't think I wanna play this with 9, so for me it's a nice bonus, but I don't need it at all.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Very fast filler, but good enough

item.name: Luchador! Mexican Wrestling Dice
item.comment:
25 euro for a very little box with little material in it! The dice are clearly from China: they weigh almost nothing and aren't engraved, so after a while, the pictures on it won't be visible anymore.
The game itself: boring! You throw dice and that's it: no choices to make, just compare results and do the maximum damage you can.
And why create 6 different character figures that all do exactly the same? Just add the 3 special moves onto the overview card and save yourself 6 cards.

item.name: Luna
item.comment: Another great game by Stefan Feld!

item.name: Lungarno
item.comment: pure abstract tile laying game that is not so exciting to play; nice components though

item.name: M.U.L.E. The Board Game
item.comment: Well there are some fucked-up cards in those event decks, like there is no crystalite production and you have to discard all the crystalite you have :s Apparently you can play without the events (or the event parts on the production cards), but you sort of need them to make sure you don't have a runaway leader problem.

item.name: Macao
item.comment: This is a very good game

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: This is fun to play, but I don't see why it is such a the hype

item.name: Machi Koro Haven
item.comment: Only 1 play, but it didn't seem to prolong the gaming time, which surprised me a bit. Now you have more variety, which is always good. But off course, as it sells well, they will make too many expansions.

item.name: Madame Ching
item.comment:
Mechanically, this works perfect. The only thing I missed a bit in my 1 play, was a 'soul'. Most of the time 'nothing' happens: everybody moves a square and takes a new navigation card and that's it.
Edit 05/07/2014:I wrote the stuff above after one play and rated this game a 6. Then I played it again with 3 and it was an exciting, fast game, with end scores very close together. So I increased my rating to 7. But now I played it for the first time with 4 and in fact the stuff mentioned above applied again, so decreased rating to 6.5.
I guess that if this game is fun or not depends if 1 player is lucky (as well with encounter cards as navigation cards of the 'right' colour) or that luck is spread out evenly.

item.name: Madeira
item.comment:
I normally like the meatier stuff from WYG? and Madeira is no exception. It's what you can expect: lots of rules and no idea of what to do the first time you play.
This game however will suffer from AP a lot even if you're experienced players, because you really have to count if you for example will have enough bread and if you're in all the places you wanna be.
So my advice: only play this with the 'right' people ;-)

item.name: Madeira Erweiterung: Der Erntehelfer
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Madeira: The Ambassadors
item.comment: We always like variation :-)

item.name: Maestro Leonardo: Codex Leonardi – II
item.comment: Wasn't used a lot in our game

item.name: Maestro Leonardo: Codex Leonardi – III
item.comment: Makes the council area more important, which is a good thing

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: This is one really great game. It takes a while to play (which probably improves when you know what all the different locations are and symbols mean), but it doens't become boring for a second, on the condition you play this with people who don't think everything trough, but just play along. However I'm afraid that because of the complexity it will also be the kind of game you'll play once a year (therefore I'll rate it only an 8 instead of a 9) and in fact that is really a pity for such a excellent game.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: Krang Character Expansion
item.comment: As Jan played with him during our 1 game we introduced him, I can't really evaluate him, but basically it's just an extra hero in this expansion and nothing more.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: Shades of Tezla Expansion
item.comment: The faction-tokens are nice, but making the green harder doesn't seem like a good plan :s

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
item.comment: We always love new stuff we can add, but those extra monsters are a real pain in the ass and 'ouch' if you draw them in the beginning when you're still building things up :s

item.name: Magical Athlete
item.comment: Really enjoyed myself while playing this one

item.name: Het Magische Labyrint
item.comment: If you put in all the walls, man this is though

item.name: Das magische Labyrinth: Erweiterung
item.comment: The magic items don't add a lot, but the magic walls are great

item.name: Magnum Opus
item.comment:
When I try a game for the first time, I look at what is the best number of players according to BGG, which was at the moment I looked 4. However this is a deckbuilder and for deckbuilders my credo is always 'less is better'! So 2 is definitely my best number for this game.
The game itself: there is some luck involved as you roll a die, but in general I like the gaming mechanism.

item.name: Magnum Sal
item.comment: Good game, nothing special

item.name: Magnum Sal: Muria
item.comment: No added value this expansion

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
Maharani
item.comment: I think that in it's genre (puzzle games like Ubongo (but without the time pressure)), this is a good game. Only, it's not my favorite genre. If you really wanna play well at this game you have to consider each tile in each quadrant and so you can have some serious downtime if everybody does that.

item.name: Maharani: Two-Colored Center Column Tiles
item.comment: Simple but nice varaition

item.name: Mai-Star
item.comment:
If you wanna play this game, study the cards in advance and explain before playing which possible cards our in the deck. I advice this, because there are some very powerful cards in there that let you discard you're entire hand (= Monk) (which finishes the round immediately) or even worse, that let's you play all you're hand cards (= Shogun) :s
So if you see a player advertising in the same colour all the time, you can imagine he's saving for a big one and you should all try to stop him/her!

item.name: Mamma Mia!
item.comment: Quite a chatoc sort of memory card game, ideal to play when feeling tired :D

item.name: Mamma Mia! Plus
item.comment: Chaos!

item.name: Mamma Mia: Double Ingredients
item.comment: There are no scampi's in this expansion, so not very handy to use mith the Mamma Mia! Plus - edition I own :s

item.name: Mammoth Hunters
item.comment:
A game in The Alea-serie I didn't have/played yet, but as it it language dependent, I waited until I could have a copy in English for a low price.
I knew in advance that the average rating of this one was low, but that for instance also the case for 'Um Ru(h)m und Ehre', which is a game I like and Weisbloom and Moon or 2 authors which have a good reputation for me personally in the family game-branch.
This game however seems to deserve his low rating. It takes quite some time to play for what it is (which is a timing game were you wanna play your powerful cards at the right time (which is when the supply of stones is low on the dark side and your opponents are also low on stones to counteract your move) and all the things you do before are insecure) and it misses fire while you're playing it. This will be for me 1 of these games that I won't mind playing of someone would ask for it, but I'll never chose it out of my 800+ games collection to be the game to play.

item.name: Mammut
item.comment: It's a neat idea: take what you want. You want to find the balance between taking enough, but don't leaving too much for your opponent. This is more a family game that is OK to play if you're more into gamers' games

item.name: MammuZ
item.comment: Perudo meets Bugs

item.name: Mangrovia
item.comment:
Not totally convinced after 1 play. The luck in drawing cards seems a bit too high, especially in landscape-type. Going for amulets also seems to be dominant.
Edit: 2nd play with 5: much better, far more tense. I think you should avoid 2 or 3 player-games as you then have to place 2 bowls. Still think amulets is the way to go.

item.name: Manhattan
item.comment: You can be screwed by the cards at some poitns, but beside that this is a good game: quick, easy to play, but not see easy to win

item.name: The Manhattan Project
item.comment: Good worker placemnet game with a flavor of Ameritrash as you can bomb the buildings of your opponents. However as the only consequence is that you have to repair them, but don't lose them or something like that, I can perfectly live with that. Plus in this game are the very quick turns.

item.name: The Manhattan Project: Nations Expansion
item.comment: I had Japan as a Nation in our first game I added this and found a rather stupid one as I have used 0 times (and won!), while Fré's Nation (France) was a really helpfull won, so I don't think they are balanced enough.

item.name: The Manhattan Project: Second Stage
item.comment: The best addition is for me the 'Personalities' as it makes retrieving your people at the right moment quite important.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: Great risk management game!

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment: I can see the quality of this game: the searching for clues in different rooms and solving mini-puzzles to get them, even the fighting with a monster, it are all quiete nice ideas, but what ruines it for me is the 'Ameritrash'-factor of constant rolling the dice and checking a certain number on your charts. That made it too repetitive for me, but also for my fellow players.

item.name: Marco Polo: Die neuen Charaktere
item.comment: Excellent addition.

item.name: Mare Polare
item.comment: Good games for kids alone, too easy as an adult, for an adult there is no challenge and you just have to hope that you don't fall into the water

item.name: Mars Needs Mechanics
item.comment: Without Kickstarter, this game would never have been published. And in fact that would have been a good thing, as this game isn't worth cutting down any trees to produce this. There is NO added value at all to other games in this genre, it's simply buy as low as you can and sell as high as you can. If the 'new' part has to come from the objects you can acquire, then they shouldn't have bothered. In the blurb here they dare to write "players will utilize unique game mechanisms". The person who wrote this has to really make a wake-up call and should be banned from BGG because he doens't have a clue of what already exists in the boardgame-world

item.name: Martinique
item.comment: Strange game

item.name: Martinique Mini Expansion
item.comment: This must be the most lame mini-expansion ever made. The tiles with 4 on really don't add anything to the gameplay at all. Only the special Joker tile adds something diferent to the game.

item.name: Mascarade
item.comment: OK Machiavelli spin-off

item.name: Massilia
item.comment: The heart of the game is buy low, sell high. But in this game there is more to it, as you wanna sell high to get more money to invest, but maybe you wanna sell low as it's worth 3 points for each good. Also, selling is harder then it looks, as you have to get the right customer at your market stalls.

item.name: Massilia: Bacchus
item.comment: Very handy

item.name: Massilia: The Thief
item.comment: Makes the game harder (which is in the beginning certainly not necessary :s)

item.name: Master of Economy
item.comment:
No wow feeling about this one: a lot of (little) rules/ phases (where are those player aids when you need them?) and a long gaming time; Nothing new that I haven't seen before in an economic game before;
If we played correct there is something broken also in the game: if a player/company can put down all of his markers at once during the trade phase, turn order is very important, and you almost have no ways to change that (1 lousy telephone/turn).

item.name: Masters Gallery
item.comment: What's the difference with Modern Art? Wasn't that already a card game?

item.name: Mauna Kea
item.comment:
I'm not a fan of tile-laying games, unless it involves lava coming into play (like with the excellent "The Downfall of Pompeii"). Here the lava is rather 'polite' as it follows certain patterns and you don't have to make any choice at all, which is a bit of a pity imho.
The game itself: immediately play the advanced version if all players are used to playing games. Just accept that not all of your meeples will come out alive (as in other Lava-games :D) and concentrate on saving a few, without being to greedy on taking away those artefacts.
Positive is that it's easy to explain and to play and that it plays fast. But imho it's not a game that stands out and should be in your collection unless you regularly plays with family gamers.

item.name: Maus au Chocolat
item.comment: Simple, but not so exciting card game

item.name: Meander
item.comment: Something quick to end the evening

item.name: Medici
item.comment: Just OK auction game, the worst in the auction - trilogy

item.name: Medieval Academy
item.comment: OK majority game that uses the drafting mechanism from 7 Wonders, Among the Stars... There are a lot of variants, maybe they'll spice things up?

item.name: Mercante
item.comment: The big games of the Tempest-line of AEG didn't get a real good rating at the start, so they weren't relly high on my priority list to play. But as a costumer of mine wanted to try Mercante, I prepared and played this recently. And I must say that I was surprised in a positive way by this game. It's not that hard to explain or grasp, plays rather quick an is tense until the end to determine the winner. It will probably each time depend on details on whom will win.

item.name: Merchants of the Middle Ages
item.comment: One play so far, just a good game, nothing exciting

item.name: Merkator
item.comment: A more 'lighter' game then the Harvest-trilogy

item.name: Mermaid Rain
item.comment: I had a lot of fun playing this game

item.name: Metropolis
item.comment: Had some high expectations of this one, which weren't forfilled after my 1 play. I thought I had to build up an engine, but the game is over before you engine can run :s

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment: It's a pity for the VERY ugly board, because this is a fun, quick auction game

item.name: Mice and Mystics
item.comment:
Positive: very, very beautiful artwork! Also a very good tutorial video on the website of Plaid Had Games. If you lose your lifepoints, you're captured and not death. You can still re-enter the game if your companions can clear the room.
Negative: quality of the components: cards are clearly China print and get wear by just lookig at them. There are some unique mechanisms in this game (like the shuffeling of cards to determin player order of the flipping of tiles), but overall it gives me the feeling of 'been there, done that': You slaughter some minions (which is not really hard in the beginning of the game), level up if you can and crawl yourself through the dungeon/castle to reach some endpoint our fight some boss. So if you already have some co-operative games and are looking for a game that will offers you something really new, I'm afraid this game won't do it for you.

item.name: Mice and Mystics: Tattered Threads of Reason
Midgard
item.comment: tokens are really important :s

item.name: MIL (1049)
item.comment:
After first full play Surya thinks that this games has the problem of 'the rich getting richer'. As I was the rich :D I didn't have that feeling, future plays will tell if he's right or not.
What I really like about this game is the mechanism where your knights die if you take to many places with time counters on it.
One minus point: the complexity to make someone vassal or conquer land

item.name: Milestones
item.comment: I understand why they say 3 is the best number to play this game: with 4 there is far too much AP :s

item.name: The Mines of Zavandor
item.comment: It's a pity they assosciated this with Zavandor: this game is much lighter - more accessible - and a lot faster to play!

item.name: Mirror, Mirror
item.comment: What annoys me the most about this game that you do your best to figure out a move so that you can see 1 of your opponent letters, but your opponent automatically sees your letter also for free. So you also have to look for a position that he can't eliminate your piece. Therefore I found this boring to play.

item.name: Mississippi Queen
item.comment: Normally I'm not into race games, but this one I enjoyed, mainly because it doensn't take that long to play

item.name: Moddervarkens
item.comment: This is just good, silly fun that takes the exact right amount of time for what it is

item.name: Moeraki: Kemu
item.comment: Totally my kind of game. Very good abstract.

item.name: Mombasa
item.comment:
Rating based on 1 3-player game, which is clearly NOT the ideal number to play this game with. If 2 players find eachother in expanding a company, there's nothing you can do and if you end up with worthless shares, you will 100% lose. However I can see the quality of this game, but I believe 4 will be the only good number to play this game with.
Edit 29/11/2015: played a second game with 4 players. Still not convinced of this game. If you're (one of)the player(s) missing out on the track from whom the company is expanded like hell, you're sure to lose. I knew that it was pointless to try and boost a company on my own from previous game, so I bought almost every card with a share of that company on. But even with a maximized diamond-track I was till 30 points behind the player who had 9 shares of the Cairo-company who was worth 11 gold/share. It's simply impossible to compensate. Therefore I lowered my rating by 1 (7 -> 6)

item.name: Mondo
item.comment: A game on time I like :D

item.name: Mondo Micro
item.comment: Ideal if you wanna teach a new player the game, otherwise quite unusefull.

item.name: Mondo Sapiens
item.comment:
Compared to Mondo:
+ More variety with the 4 different boards + More complex when adding all the stuff on a difficult board
- Mondo is more suitable for players who are not familiar with the principle - The adding of the buildings for the expert level seems only interesting with 4 as you can have some competition; with 2 and 2 different buildings, they don't seem to be worth the effort of for example having to search for bor in the same forest.

item.name: Money
item.comment: Follow the advice from the rules: play 3 rounds to determine the winner. OK Filler

item.name: Monopoly Deal Card Game
item.comment: What an annoying game this is! How this has an average of 6.29 (19/04/2015) beats me. This game has everything to dislike: randomness will determine the winner, take-that-action - cards, but especially broken action cards that let you steal a complete wet, which is 1/3 of the points you need!

item.name: Monster City Planners
item.comment: OK card game with very ugly artwork. The fact the a card can let you score and can be used to built/destroy something on the board is nice. Can be chaotic however

item.name: Monster-Falle
item.comment: Good dexterity game

item.name: Montego Bay
item.comment: With 4 this game will probably be to chaotic, with 2 it's really hard as you have to outguess 3! times what your opponent will do and plan 3 times; So I think 3 is the best number for this game

item.name: Mord im Arosa
item.comment: Just fun to play, maybe a bit too long?

item.name: Morels
item.comment: Nice, fun card game that plays quick and is easy to explain.

item.name: Mousquetaires du Roy
item.comment: Is a good semi-co-operative game where everything works well together as it should,but if you own already for example Shadows over Camelot, I don't know if you need to own this one too, as I don't see anything new to it. Maybe the releasedate is one year too late?

item.name: Mow
item.comment: Frustrating first game as I didn't have any special cards and almost all the time mid numbers :s

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: My favorite 2-player game

item.name: Mr. Jack in New York
item.comment: Mr Jack for experts; you'll have a better chance as Jack of winning though

item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket
item.comment: I liked may 1 play so far, it has the feeling of Mr. Jack, but still feels different enough. Off course, if Filip is right, that it is impossible to win as Mr. Jack, then there is definitely something wrong with the game, but that I can't judge after 1 play.

item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket: Goodies
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Mr. Jack: The Carriage
item.comment: Something nice, but not really necessary

item.name: Mundus Novus
item.comment: One play where 1 player got almost all of the caravels and then it it is just waiting until his scores goes over 75

item.name: MUNERA: Familia Gladiatoria
item.comment: Will rate, after playing with te correct rules

item.name: Murano: The Christmas Tree
item.comment:
PnP;
Nice addition. In the first game I introduced him the winner focussed on this mini-expansion and got 12 points from it, which helped her win.

item.name: Mush! Mush!: Snow Tails 2
item.comment: Very, very similar to Snow Tails

item.name: Mutant Meeples
item.comment: Original gameplay (I didn't play Ricochet Robots before), but something you wanna play when thinking is still clear :)

item.name: My First Carcassonne
item.comment: Good way to introduce your kids the principles of Carcassonne

item.name: My Village
item.comment:
I like Village, so I was eager to play this. Only one play (with 2) and that's what I feel for the moment:
++ plays more smoothly and is therefore quicker then My Village ++ There are enough ways to manipulate the dice, something I find important in more strategic dice games like My Village. + I like the new concept of the story points which aren't safe unless you invest some actions in it. With 2 players that rat comes fast, very fast +- Almost everything costs time. It makes your villagers will die quite fast and you'll need to invest in the school-action. Were in Village I have the feeling I can pace down the rate at which my villagers die, here I don't have this feeling. Off course, as they die quite fast, the game is also finished more quickly. - Only 1 minus as I'm not sure yet, but travelling seems to be an easier way to get points then the other options. - If you've played Village a couple of times, you won't have a wow-feeling of this one as a lot of the mechanisms feel similar. But I must admit that the implemenation of the dice mechism is very cool. -- In My Village every action is always available (as long as you have a villager that is). One of the things I like in Village is just the fact that every action is only available a limited number of times and you have to decide an order of chosing your actions. This increases the AP-level, but is one of the main things I enjoy in Village and I'm missing in My Village.

item.name: Mykerinos
item.comment: If you like a strategic game, that plays in less then an hour, Mykerinos is your game; Downside: it's one of those games where there is silence during the most part of the game

item.name: Mykerinos: The Nile
item.comment: Don't know about this one; It makes the game more complicated as it's less clear how the regions are divided; In my one play so far I entirely ignored the Nile and I've won :D

item.name: Myrmes
item.comment: Good, but very mechanic, dry, game, as we're used from Ystari :D

item.name: Myrmes: Colony Tiles
item.comment: Nice idea that you can customize, but only 4 tiles is a bit less, especially with 4

item.name: Het Mysterie van de Abdij
item.comment: I prefer the newer mystery-game of Days of Wonder - Mystery Express - above this one

item.name: Mysterium
item.comment:
Never thought that I would like a game were a Dixit-element is involved :-) But then again I like deduction games.
After reading the rules I thought the role of the ghost would be the best for me, but after 1 play I'm not so convinced of that :s

item.name: Mythotopia
item.comment: Very nice gaming mechanisms, as we're used from Martin Wallace. Has a lot of direct player interaction as you can attack each other. Will probably suffer from pick-on-the-leader (which will make they will attack your cities if you're in the lead).

item.name: Nacht der Magier
item.comment: Fun

item.name: Nations
item.comment: Quick smooth (except for those little rules here and there) civilization game without direct player conflict

item.name: Nations Promo Pack 2014: Inspiration
item.comment: We always like extra variety :-)

item.name: Nations: Dynasties
item.comment: I'm always in for expansiosn that add extra variety, but 20 euro (Essen-price) is a lot of money for 6 player boards and a deck of cards :s

item.name: Nations: Grand Duchy of Finland promo card
Nations: The Dice Game
item.comment: Felt like: 'we have a popular board game, let's make a dice version that will sell as it has 'Nations' in the name'. Not that it is a bad game, but if the dice don't roll what you need, you're screwed (like in most dice games). Luckily the playing time is indeed at most 30 minutes, so that's ideal for this kind of games.

item.name: Nauticus
item.comment:
Well, this is definitely harder to play as it seems. Not something you wanna play with your family game playing friends NOR with players who suffer from AP!
In our 1 play I was always short on Talers, workers, or both. You really have to be careful to the temptation of buying too much in 1 action.

item.name: Nautilus
item.comment:
I was happily surprised by this game. It didn't has a high rating and if you read the rules it seems a bit dull, but in fact it was quite exciting to play. Turns and even rounds are fast and probably it will be tense until the last round for who will win.
The only minuspoint is that in the 3rd round the player who goes second exactly knows which special card his opponent has as there are only 6.
Ideal 2-player if you want to take a game with you while travelling or just want a 20 minute-game.

item.name: Navegador
item.comment: Liked my very first play a lot! It's not that difficult and its quick (which can't be said of most of Mac Gerdts games :s)

item.name: Navegador: Pirates & Diplomats
item.comment: Doesn't seem to add much to the game. In our 1 game we used them nobody took one. Not so unlogic as you have to give up taking a privilige token and have to activate them all the time again.

item.name: Nefertiti
item.comment: It's a combination of worker placement/bidding and set collection + only 4 pages of rules. All things I like :-)

item.name: Nefertiti Expansion
item.comment: Extra variety, Always good :-)

item.name: Neptun
item.comment: It's more of a family game, with a little bit of depth into it, but a certain luck factor (in this game especially when you have to chose your 4th and 5th card), a short ruleset and and enjoyable playing time. All things you could expect from as well Queen as Dirk Henn :-)
