item.name: Neptun: Queenie 1
item.comment: OK addition, but adds length to the game as you have 3 extra rounds of picking an ability card. But an nice compensation for being last in turn order at the start of the game.

item.name: Neptun: Queenie 2
item.comment: Slows down the game after the first round because for picking a contract, people also wanna check if the good is still available at that city

item.name: Neptun: Queenie 3
item.comment: Something you would like to aim for, certainly when picking contracts in the second round as you wanna finish a row of column, but off course you need the luck to be able to pick the city you're missing.

item.name: New Dawn
item.comment:
Only 1 incomplete play, so will rate after a full game.
Edit 16/05/2015: Played a full game. The problem with this game is that if you fail to conquer a facility, you're punished twice as you wasted an action and on top of that you will have 1 resource less as you couldn't put away a base.

item.name: New Dawn: Exodai
item.comment: Good race for defending

item.name: New Dawn: Stretch Rewards
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: New Dawn: U-Cannon
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: The New Era
item.comment: I'm not a fan of the extra confrontation aspect in comparison with 51st State. Plus is the serious upgrade of components, minus is that the rules/symbols on cards still aren't clear. You would expect that with 2nd verion they should have resolved this problem :s

item.name: The New Era: Spiel 2011 Promo Pack
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: New Haven
item.comment: Low score + tile laying = low expectations. Bot it was harder then I thought after reading the rules. Off course - certainly near the end - you need some luck with the buildings and resource tiles you get.

item.name: New Haven: Charters
item.comment: The one that gives an extra 2 points for having most charters seems a bit too much

item.name: The New Science
item.comment: I like the science theme and the idea is nice, but I had 2 issues with my first play of this game. The first is that it became a bit too repetitive near the end. The game takes too long for the limited actions you have, to stay interesting till the end. The 2nd thing is an unbalanced hapiness-deck. Some cards are obviously more powerfull then others in both ways (to screw an other player or as a benefit for yourself). I had a card by whom I could place an energy cube on a spot already taken by an other player. With only 1 good publish-spot (with 4 players), that card is way too powerfull. The other players didn't have a chance, as I could publish for full points EVERY turn.

item.name: The New Science: Fantasy Scientists
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: New York 1901
item.comment: This is a pure family game, which is easy to explain (only 2 possible actions) with fast turns and where the bonus-cards can make all the difference!

item.name: New York 1901: Flatiron
item.comment: Some variety is good, but why does the Spielbox-version only contains half of the material :'(?

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: When Surya first explained the game I thought this wouldn't be my cup of tea. But in fact I quite enjoyed it: it's fast, easy to grasp and battles are just 1 dice roll which is a hit or not. So you need a certain luck, but you can improve your odds by buying the more expensive troopers like Lava Leapers.

item.name: Nicht zu fassen
item.comment: Good kids game, but more for the younger ones, who will be fascinated by the wolf

item.name: Nieuw Amsterdam
item.comment: Good game, but make sure to have corn :s

item.name: Nightfall
item.comment: Deck building game, but more for experts: harder to get then Dominion or Ascension

item.name: Nightfall: "Shadow Seven" Promo
item.comment: I think this card is overpowered if it's in a Private archieve

item.name: Nightfall: Lisaveta Florescu
item.comment: Same rating as the base game

item.name: Nightfall: Martial Law
item.comment: The Feeding of your chain is a nice extra feature

item.name: Nightfall: Zombie Horde Promo
item.comment: This can be very powerfull, but also very weak if your other minions get destroyed before you can attack.

item.name: Ninjato
item.comment: one play and liked it a lot: quick action, some luck ( = tension), but with enough interesting descissions you can make. This had easily could have been a HiG-game.

item.name: Nippon
item.comment:
Well, WYG? does it again. A solid gamers game that is well developed.
How things work are - for once - quite clear in this game: get knowledge to get factories, which you can improve to get more goods with a single run. Get coal to produce goods with your factory. Use this goods to either forfill contracts or to get influence. Built trains to add influence in a region were you already have influence or add ships to score more points when scoring 1st or 2nd.
The hard part in this game comes from the consolidate action, were you have to balance taking an extra action with a colour you don't have yet and starting with 3.000 Yen less, or to simply consolidate. But the hardest part from the consolidate-action is the fact that you will probably get an emperor reward and immediately have to decide were to put it. This implicates that in fact you have to know upfront (right from the start of the game)on which things you will focus and put over there a 4x or 5x multiplier.
The game also progresses much faster then you would imagine if you see those 30 meeples (with 4 players) at the start of the game. As in the beginning most of the players are sort of taking the same actions, those extra workers come in quite fast and before you know it, it's scoring time!

item.name: No Merci
item.comment: OK filler cardgame

item.name: Noah
item.comment: Played 2 incomplete games as the gamle always seemed to drag on: nobody can empty his/her hands and you avoid going to boats that possibly can be finished off, so people have to take back their cards all the time :s. Maybe we are playing this game too seriously??

item.name: Noblemen
item.comment: On a blog (De Tafel Plakt) someone called this 'The euro of 2012', 'the only euro of 2012 you need to have'. This is certainly a good game, but I like Tzolk'in or CO2 more and Western Town and Asgard are equally good. So not 'the euro of2012' for me, but still a good game!

item.name: Norderwind
item.comment:
Teuber clearly has something with reaching 10 points :-)
See this as a light family game in the genre as, well, Settlers of Catan, and you'll have a nice time playing this. You need some luck drawing the right tile at the right moment and a good memory to remember which tile is where also helps :-)
Plus for the nice looking components!

item.name: Norenberc
item.comment: Tense & good

item.name: Norenberc: Bonus Townsmen Essen 2010
item.comment: Just gave it the same rating as the base game; Nice to have (for more randomisation), but you don't miss a lot if you don't have it

item.name: Nuns on the Run
item.comment: These must be the worst written ruleset I've ever read. Played it once and with 5 we all had the same feeling: when will somebody win so that we can stop playing this game

item.name: OctoDice
item.comment: Very nice reworked AquaSphere, which gives you enough nice options to chose from end the same feeling as in AquaSphere (but is off course a lot easier).

item.name: Octopus' Garden
item.comment: Nice little game, as well in gameplay as in artwork

item.name: Octopus' Garden: Parrot Fish
item.comment: The more variety, the better :)

item.name: OddVille
item.comment: Nice game, easy to explain, with enough interesting choices during play. Lame tie-breaker :s

item.name: Odin's Ravens
item.comment: Good game, but it can be a bit frustrating at some time if you keep drawing the wrong cards

item.name: Offerings
item.comment: Good auction/developping game

item.name: Oh My Goods!
item.comment: It had the same buzz as it's predecessor Port Royal, but I find this one to be more of a hassle and not so exciting as Port Royal.

item.name: Oklahoma Boomers
item.comment: Same feeling as Limes from the same author: OK abstract game, but no wow-feeling here

item.name: Old Men of the Forest
item.comment: I'm quite surprised about the low rating about this game, as I found it to be fun to play.

item.name: Oliver, l'ours gourmand
item.comment: This is indeed 'Gewoon geweldig' :-)

item.name: Olympicards
item.comment: Rather simple card game, with some tactics involved. Fun filler

item.name: Olympos
item.comment:
One play so far and I found it to be a very frustrating gaming experience. The problem for me with this game is that if someone takes that one resource you need to acquire that development/wonder, there is really no alternative, you can't just buy something else, because of the strict building costs. So you have to reconquer or go to an other region with that resource, which costs you time and by the time you have an other turn, someone else could have taken away that or an other resource need, so you have to do that again.
From my one play so far, I also believe that you can't win this if you don't have military power and I hate games where you can't win without that one thing. Hopefully further play will prove me wrong.
Second play: confirms my thought that you can't win this game without military power. The player without was slaughtered in this game.
3rd game: everybody understood the importance of military, which made of a more tight, less aggresive game.

item.name: Olympos: Expansionnism
item.comment: A little bit more variety. If you aim for it, it can give you a lot of points at the end.

item.name: Olympos: Oikoumene
item.comment: I always love expansions who bring variety to something that is fixed!

item.name: Olympus
item.comment: Good, but play this only with players who can handle (direct) confrontation; AP (=Analysis Paralysis) can be high; Correction after 2nd play: AP IS high

item.name: Onward to Venus
item.comment:
Had some high expectations of this one, but my 1 play so far was a bit disappointing. The game has for me the same randomness as 'The Witches: A Discworld Game', but were that game is a light family game with a nice short playing time, it doesn't bother me, while this one is longer and tries to be more, I think?
The most random thing that bothers me the most is the outcome of the tiles. Let's say you want to take over a majority of someone, if there doesn't appear a mine or a tension-tile, you just won't be able to do that.

item.name: Opera
item.comment: Nothing quite knew as mechanics, but everthing works very well together

item.name: Ora et Labora
item.comment: Very heavy game. Which I a find a minus point in this game is that you don't have a clear overview of the remaining buildings (cost + function), like you have in Le Havre. That there are buildings and you can use those of your opponents by paying them is the only similarity with Le Havre. This game feels totally different (which is good). I like the mechanism with the 'rondel' to get resources. But this is definitly a game you just wanna play with hardcore gamers as there are probably tons of combo's and layers you can only find out after a couple of plays. Steap learning curve.

item.name: Ora et Labora: Loamy Landscape
item.comment: It's a good building, not too powerfull, but very usefull (especially in the beginning of the game).

item.name: Orcs Orcs Orcs
item.comment:
The game reminded me a lot of Castle Panic, not only because of the Tower 'defending' mechanism, but also because of the fact that it are also Orcs who invade the tower. Apparently Orcs like invading towers :-)
The game itself. Well, like HiG is for me a brand which stands for a certain game type, Queen is that also. So in fact I can just say it's a typical Queen game :-). This means it's more of a family game and some luck is involved. Good thing is they added 3 modules in the base game, which can spice things up a bit. This they should do for all of there games imho.

item.name: Orcs Orcs Orcs: Mini-Expansion 1
item.comment: Don't like the 'steal spell'-cards, but the Manna Bomb is OK.

item.name: Orcs Orcs Orcs: Reinforcements (Expansion 1)
item.comment: More modules = more variety = always a good thing!

item.name: Oregon
item.comment: Good game, but you have to accept that luck can be with you, or not

item.name: Origin
item.comment: I like the gaming princilpe, it's easy to explain, but has more depth then you would think from reading the rules. My only worry with this game is, that it's not only important how good you play, but also how good the player at your right is. If he/she gives too many good locations as a 'gift', that can influence the outcome. But with equally skilled players, this can be a good game.

item.name: Origin: Ranger Die
item.comment: It's good that there is something available for empty green spaces.

item.name: Orléans
item.comment: The most strategic game from DLP Games so far, but still clearly in the medium-category. Looking for some combo's and then trying to maximise them is the way to go. A pity they didn't do anything more with the money. From my 1 play so far it seemed to be nothing more then just points.

item.name: Orléans: Die Reise nach Tours
item.comment: Already a nice challenge :s

item.name: Orléans: Tavern & Depot
item.comment: The depot seems nice, but it is hard to get a lot of extra's from that. The tavern can be handy, especially with 4 players

item.name: Orongo
item.comment: I think I can start quoting myself if it concerns new Knizia-games: not bod, I'll gladly play it if someone asks, but again nothing special, no need to own.

item.name: Out of Gears
item.comment: Typical 'outguess-your-opponents' - kind of game, a genre I like. Nothing special here, just a game where everything works together fine. At least if you limit the number of players to 4, max. 5, because otherwise the chaos would just be too big :s

item.name: Outpost
item.comment: This game seems to have a serious runaway leader - problem. that, or I played incredibally well (only 1 play so far) :D

item.name: P.I.
item.comment: I like deduction games and this is a good and quick one. Hint: don't start with all your investigations at once, you'll need them later :s

item.name: Packet Row
item.comment:
Considering all the games I've played so far from Henrik Berg & Åse Berg, they clearly aim at medium weight games with not a lot of rules and play quickly. Considering that, they succeeded with Packet Row. It's not a Rattus, neither an Oregon however. It's a very opportunistic game where you just have to try to make the most about every situation. For me it's the kind of game that I wouldn't mind playing, but I doubt I will pick it out my game collection as first when choosing which game to play.
What annoyed me about this game is it's huge overproduction. The 4 boards could have clearly left out, which made this game could have come in a small box for a smaller price.

item.name: Pagode
item.comment: The art of playing this game is not creating opportunities for your opponent :-)

item.name: Palais Royal
item.comment:
The problem I had with my one play of this game is the downtime: once I did my move, it took 10 or even 15 minutes before I could play again. And it's no use to start planning your next move, because you have to wait to see how the board is at the start of your next turn :s;
Update 05/06/2011: Played it for a second time after several years, this time with fast players and enjoyed this game a lot more. So the rating with depend on which kind of players I'm playing with;

item.name: Palastgeflüster
item.comment: Filip told me that he has had a game were there were 3 consecutive turns that someone can finish with 6 different characters, while imho it's far better to have less characters and make your opponents accumulate a lot, forcing them to play a double. Statistically, this makes far more sense.

item.name: De Paleizen van Carrara
item.comment: Another great game with a HIG-difficulty - level: easy rules, not so hard to explain, but with just enough strategy into it so that everybody can enjoy it. Great!

item.name: Palenque
item.comment: Good majority game. Pure abstract, so you have to love this kind of games.

item.name: Palmyra
item.comment: 'Tile Placement' = not my favorite game mechanism, part 123.514 (just imagining a number :D). I think the highest rating I gave for a game with tile Placement is 7 or so. This one however I thought to be really boring while playing and even frustrating at some point as you can really not draw what you're seeking for and someone can have a terrific tile for a certain place.

item.name: Panamax
item.comment: This is a sort of 18XX with boats on the Panama-canal. This is some heavy shit to play. My major concern with this game is that the player who is left alone, by whom I mean that no other players put containers on his boats, is screwed, as you really need the movements of your ships by other players as you have Mutual interests. So 3 players is probably a horrible number for this game as 2 players can help eachother and the 3rd is left alone.

item.name: Pandemic Legacy: Season 1
item.comment: Only played the first month (twice :s), but this was really, really fun. If course this game can only be something for you if you have a group of players whom you will meet on regular basis and who know Pandemic well enough. But if you have such a group, don't hesitate and just play Pandemic Legacy!

item.name: Pandemic: Contagion
item.comment: Nice components, but rather dull to play as your path-of-how-to-play seems a bit predetermined: upgrade your level of taking cards and infection rate and then start to infect

item.name: Pandemic: The Cure
item.comment: Good dice version of Pandemic.

item.name: Panic Station
item.comment: This game sold very well and was sold out almost immediately. This made I had some high expectations when I could finally play this. My first play however was a very big disappointment. From the mimics of Kelly when she got her first cards and her being keen to trade with other people, it was from the start clear who was the host. However if you don't have any ammo or don't get new petrol-cards, you can block it once when she tries to infect you, but the second time you're infected. Will try it once with 5 or 6 players, but don't think this is a keeper.

item.name: Panic Station: Survival Kit Mini Expansion
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Paniek in de Wei
item.comment: Chess with sheep :D

item.name: Panthalos
item.comment: Good game, but not outstanding. A good thing seems to be that there are multiple paths to score points.

item.name: Pantheon
item.comment: Yet an other good game by Tummelhofer! Rating is for a game with 3 or 4 players, with 2 it's only just OK.

item.name: Pantheon: Neue Untermieter
item.comment: Same rating as base game

item.name: Parade
item.comment: Nice, but you have to love making calculations (or counting if you want)

item.name: Parfum
item.comment:
A game from the designers of Fresco, that was something I had to have. But it also created some high expectations and I'm afraid that those aren't met by Parfum. Therefore it's too simple, pure family game, with not enough options.
Not that it is a bad game, a 'typical 7' (which is for me a game I don't mind owning or playing, but ain't necessary to have). I think the problem is that while Fresco had from the start 3 modules that spice things up, Parfum doesn't have those, which makes it can't become something more then a family game.
Maybe Queen Games is planning to release an expansion with modules (and later on the obligate Big Box :s) or extra Queenies, but then I think they made a mistake by not already including some extra's to spice things up, as for now, there ain't no reason for those who want a bit more challenge in their games to buy this.

item.name: Parfum: Secret Essences
item.comment: This seems a no brainer, why shouldn't you take a die you can keep for the entire game, even if you can't use it immediately?

item.name: Paris Connection
item.comment: 1 play and absolutely not convinced. The set-up takes longer then actually playing the game. I think the problem is with the 5 trains as a maximum you can put on the board in 1 turn, this is too much for me and I think 3 would be better. 5 makes that you can reach Marseille in only 4 turns. And if you have a lot of trains in a certain colour, why shouldn't you finsih the game by going to Marseille and increasing the value of your company even more?

item.name: Party Animals
item.comment: I can see why some people would like this, but I'm not one of them

item.name: Pasha
item.comment: OK dice game

item.name: Le Passe-Trappe
item.comment: This is a game that you can play in a bar or something like that.

item.name: Pastiche
item.comment: This is a good family game that I'll play anytime. It's a pity it's overproduced: the gameboard is very nice but not necessary at all, nor are the easels. They probably could have made the same game that would cost only 30 euro

item.name: Pastiche: Expansion Pack #1
item.comment: Same rating as base game

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment: It's easy to explain, short to play, but oh so hard to do well. Excellent 2-player game!

item.name: PAX
item.comment: good card game

item.name: PAX: Nocturnus
item.comment: I gues these cards are designed to give Rome a betetr chance of winning, but off coarse if you wanna try that strategy, it all depends on when you get which cards.

item.name: Pay Dirt
item.comment:
This game is for me a typical 7: I'm not unhappy I have this game in my collection, but it wouldn't be in my collection, I wouldn't be unhappy either.
Everything works well together and you can personalise your mine, which is nice.

item.name: Pay Dirt: Spectral Mini-Expansion
item.comment: Nice if you have all that Spectral equipment :-)

item.name: Pay Dirt: The Last Frontier Mini Expansion
item.comment: Maybe OK if from the start of the game you have a personnel that lets you remove wear, otherwise not the interessting

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment: Upgraded my score from 7.5 to 8 because of the expansions who offer that litlle extra the game needed

item.name: Peloponnes Erweiterung
item.comment: The Sea tiles are nice, but don't add that much

item.name: Peloponnes: Athens-Mini Expansion
item.comment: Smallest expansion, but for me the best of the 3 as it's a hard choice to make, but a great alternative if your short in cash

item.name: Peloponnes: Goat Expansion
item.comment: The Trade didn't do that much in our game, but the Goats were really nice. Thematically however is converting goats into stone rather weird :D

item.name: Peloponnes: Hellas Expansion
item.comment: Nice to have an extra round (but also extra supply round :s) and new starting tiles

item.name: Peloponnes: Sacrum Expansion
item.comment: Nice extrta feature, because it even becomes virtually possible to play without grain.

item.name: Peloponnes: Trade Expansion
item.comment: Especially if playing with the Goat-expansion, having some extra variation is very nice

item.name: Peloponnes: Victoria Expansion
item.comment: Quite handy this little expansion as it can save from not being able to buy a tile, as missing out on a tile is often lethal in this game.

item.name: Pergamemnon
item.comment:
Well, I like Peloponnes, Porto Carthago & Pax, so Pergamemnon was (together with Pax) a blind buy at Essen 2011 as I liked the authors previous games.
This one however really doesn't work for me. The rules are absolutely not clear, the fighting system is imho too complicated and you definitely get a stronger gets stronger and weaker gets weaker effect.

item.name: Pergamon
item.comment: Good game that probably shines the most with 4 (only played with 3 so far)

item.name: Le Petit Poucet
item.comment: Ideal to play when everybody is tired after some heavy games and you wanna have a laugh picking on eachother because he or she turned over the wrong tile :D

item.name: Le Petit Prince: Fabrique-moi une planète
item.originalname: The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet
item.comment: Nice 'little' game. Figuring out in which order you let people chose a tile can be a real brainburner though :s

item.name: Phantom
item.comment: Very beautiful artwork and very nice way to create a gamebox also! I really like the games from Ludonaute. Again, this is a very good 2-player game I certainly wanna have when it becomes available.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment:
Good game, but in my one play I encountered 2 problems: long gaming time (start the gaming event with this game, don't end with it) and mattheus-effect: the richer get richer, the poorer are lucky if they can get a lesser card;
Second play: The problems in the first game, weren't there anymore: not a runaway-leader - problem anymore and I found it estonishing that one player only had an income of 3 cards the hole time, but still was second. Therefore upgraded my rating (6.5 -> 7).

item.name: Pi mal Pflaumen
item.comment:
1 play with 3 and I must state immediately that I'm pretty sure this is the worst number to play this game with. 1 player will have the watchdog and as long he/she has that, the stealing will be between the other 2, which makes the game has a very high take-that - feeling with 3.
After Kraftwagen this card game is yet a disappointment from Matthias Cramer.
Edit 06/12/2015: Played a second game with 5 this time. Felt as frustrating as the first game, so lowered rating even further.

item.name: Pick & Pack
item.comment: Can be a real brainteaser

item.name: Piece o' Cake
item.comment: It's quick and light

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Builders Duel
The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
item.comment:
Best part for me are the extra craftsmen as you have a good randomisation. Altough I'm interested at playing it with 5.
With 2 or 3 I would recommend to not use the extra board.

item.name: Piña Pirata
item.comment: Game that replaces the colours of Uno with (nicely drawn) pirates. The tiles add a lot of chaos :s

item.name: Pinguïn Party
item.comment: OK Filler

item.name: Piranhas
item.comment: Definitely a game only to play in the right mood.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment: Rating after one play: as the rules were not clear at all, we had to look up a lot of things, which wasn't really fun :(

item.name: Piraten & Kooplui
item.comment: it takes too long to play; very bad player aid (in Dutch), in the Dutch version there are translation errors on some of the cards; a lot of things to explain and too much little rules that are had to forget.

item.name: Piraten kapern
item.comment: This is the kind of game that when you start playing you have to realize that you just need some luck (and guts sometime) with the dice and card you draw. If you can live with that, this can be just fun to play.

item.name: Pittige Pepers
item.comment: Good cardgame, but nothing that new or refreshing; plays fast though.

item.name: Planes
item.comment:
Only played the base game (as suggested in the rules), but that was quite dull to play. Maybe the reverse side will be more challenging.
What I don't understand is: if you're cards are by definition not language independent, why not use full text that is clear for everybody then half text, half icons that aren't clear by themselves???
Update after second play: the reverse side and the expert rules provide a better game, but it stays a very chaotic game, where you can't start analysing things before it is you turn.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment: Too much money for a good, but complex resource management game; the components are great, but not that great that I'm willing to pay > 50 euro for it

item.name: Polizei-Alarm!
item.comment: Reminds me of 'Der Unendliche Fluss', not my style of game (when being the policeman).

item.name: Pollen
item.comment: Quick, easy to explain and easy to carry with you with just enough depth in it.

item.name: Polterfass
item.comment: Fun, fast filler with an outguess-your-opponent - element (something I like). Those dice gonna haunt you, but at least 1 player will be having a good time if that happens :D

item.name: Pony Express
item.comment: 100% pure family game, to play with the right people

item.name: De Poorters van Nieuwstad
item.comment:
Announcing that you will make "the perfect game" had the advantage that you had some buzz about this game before it was even published yet. The clear disadvantage of putting 'perfect' into your announcement is that you create some huge expections and that those expectations can backfire like a boomerang in your face if they aren't met.
I think this is happening with this game as more and more negative reviews are coming out. Deservedly? Well, certainly regarding to the subtitle "perfect". Just by looking at the artwork, you know it's not perfect. It's more 'perfectly' ugly imho. If you wanna make a perfect game, they should have started with hiring a - more expensive - better graphic designer like Franz Vohwinkel or Michael Menzel. They have published a few games where those people made the illustrations, certainly they can see the difference with this ugly artwork for themselves?
So the game itself? It's Puerto Rico meets Le Havre where they glued in some extra mechanics like action/event cards and a co-operative mechanism in the form of the blue buildings. I'm not opposed of recycling good game mechanisms, Yedo is a excellent example of how this can result in a very, very good game, but here it's not polished enough, it feels like they just had thrown in some stuff and mixed it together. What personally bothered me the most where the action/event deck, that is totally out of balance imho (there are cards that give just like that 3 or even 4 points, that's 10 or even 13% of the points you need to finish the game!) and the co-operative element of the blue buildings. There is 1 blue building that gives 17 points for only 10 wood and 10 money, that's far far too little in price (are rather in points) in comparison to other buildings and it screwed my gaming experience totally, as in our game, 2 players just decided amongst thereselves to built 2 blue buildings and left out the other 2 players and there is nothing you can do about it :-(
The Puerto Rico meets Le Havre part is the best part of the game, but I have questions about some characters like the 'woodcutter' who becomes totally useless (except if you just want 1 wood) onces all the foresttiles are gone (which is quite fast in a 4-player game). The inspiration was also gone when deciding which privilege to give as 3 characters just give 1 florin.
For me this is the kind of game that I wouldn't mind playing of someone really wants to, but I won't pick it myself, or even don't need to own it.

item.name: Port Royal
item.comment: Press Your Luck, 1 of my favorite mechanisms :D

item.name: Port Royal: Ein Auftrag geht noch...
item.comment: More variety + extra scoring possibilities = all I like in an expansion

item.name: Porta Nigra
item.comment: Apparently one of the designers is retired, but his brain is clearly still fine, as they keep making excellent designs. As most of there games it's a very mechanic game and theme is a pure paste on. But if you mind that, you will have a great time playing this!

item.name: Porto Carthago
item.comment: Real tense, really good!

item.name: Poseidon
item.comment:
2nd 18xx-based game I played after Baltimore & Ohio. Plus in comparison with B&O is the reduced playing time and it's also easier to play.
Minus for me is the limit of bying just one share in the merchant round at a time (there is almost no risk of a take-over, so why not put all the available extra shares on the market when you get the opportunity?). If you have enough money you MUST start an other nation/company as you can never gain as much money from that one share as from starting a nation that gives you at least 3 shares of it. For that I like the stock-mechanics from B&O more then that of Poseidon.

item.name: Poseidon's Kingdom
item.comment: One play and I wasn't blown away from this. I uses the simplified level-up building system from Antics!, but where in Antics! starting your game with building up an efficient ant-hill, here it seems to be better to go for those dice as fast as possible and score the big points. I don't mind owning this game, but I wouldn't be sad if I didn't own it after playing this.

item.name: Poseidon: The Gods
item.comment: Gives so nice possibilities, certainly near the end went sailing is no longer an interesting option

item.name: Potato Man
item.comment: There seems to be more in it then you first think after reading the rules.

item.name: Power Grid: BGG Promo Card Set
item.comment: Can be good to have on an expensive map

item.name: Power Grid: Taxes
item.comment:
In the beginning the promo-cards FF made for Power Grid gave a nice twist/extra to the game, but the latest additions jus feel like 'making a promo-card just to have a promo-card and we don't care if it's any good'.
The only thing this card do is slow down your game as it takes money out of the game and everybody will invest as much as possible before paying the taxes just to minimize there losses.

item.name: Power Grid: Theme Park
item.comment: Good if you're a bit stuck in a corner waiting for the next 'Stufe'

item.name: Praetor
item.comment:
Why did I rate this game - for the moment - a 1? Well, I like to follow the BGG description of giving ratings and a 1 is a game you think is 'clearly broken'. In this game however it's just 1 single tile, the Temple of Mercury, that just screws up the entire game imho. I've written why in this post: http://boardgamegeek.com/article/15850362
Without this tile or a house rule (which I haven't tried out yet), I think I would rate this somewhere between 7 - 8. My only concerns then would be that it takes a tad too long for what it is and that the extra scoring from the coloured squares at the corners of the city tiles, don't add a lot to the playing experience, but increase the level of AP a lot.
The big plus about this worker placement game is the use of the dice as workers and how they get older and even retire after a while. That's a clever mechanism.

item.name: Prêt-à-Porter
item.comment: Very hard, but very good.

item.name: Priests of Ra
item.comment: It really feels the same as Ra. There is no need to have this one if you already have Ra.

item.name: Primordial Soup
item.comment: My first play was with 3 players and I tought this was an OK game (initial rating: 7); But this really shines with more (2nd play was with 5) when it gets really crowdy on the board (an you can eat the amoebas of your opponents :D)

item.name: Primordial Soup: Freshly Spiced
item.comment: Excellent with 5!; Same rating as the base game, haven't tried the extra genes yet

item.name: Princes of the Dragon Throne
item.comment:
deckbuilding + majority, 2 things I really like. Still chances are very big this will not be played a lot or even never again with all those games out there.
The reason is the long playing time. With 4 newbies it took us almost 2,5 hours. This can probably reduced to the 2 hours mentioned on the box with experienced players, but it's still too long for this game for my taste. And you don't won't to reduce the number of players either, as the majority part will be screwed then.

item.name: Principato
item.comment: Quick, not so difficult game

item.name: Prohis
item.comment: See this as a nice, short family game were the fun comes from the tension of getting caught or not and you will have a nice time playing this.

item.name: Pronken met Andermans Veren
item.comment: The problem for Friedemann Friese is that every new game he makes is compared wit Power Grid and he's just not been able to create such an excellent game again. But from the most recent ones he made, this is probably 1 of the best. You could call this game: deckbuilding - the boardgame version, but in a good way :-)

item.name: Prophecy
item.comment: My introduction to Epic Fantasy Games; Not bad, but a pity for the long playing time, even when the goal is to reach just 2 artefacts.

item.name: Prosperity
item.comment:
Prosperity is a so called 'dry' game. This seems to be typical for Ystari-games and normally I don't have a problem with this. However this game (only 1 play so far) just felt dull. On others players turn you do a certain scoring (which ain't that exciting) and then you just wait. There's no point in planning ahead, because the tile you're aiming for probably will be gone when it's your turn. The tile distribution is an other problem I had with this game: some tiles just seem to be better then others. That means that you have to be lucky to draw a good one on your turn or have the luck that your opponent simply can't afford it.
All considered this felt like a multiplayer solitaire, but not an exciting one I'm afraid.

item.name: Province
item.comment: Very nice to se what you can do with only a minimum on game components. My only worry is: what about replayability?

item.name: Puerto Rico: Expansion I – New Buildings
item.comment: When you've played Puerto Rico a lot, it's probably fun that you can randomize the buildings, but the game doesn't need this expansion

item.name: Puerto Rico: Limited Anniversary Edition
item.comment: Nice artwork!

item.name: Push a Monster
item.comment: As an adult you just feel that a monster will drop off, but there's nothing you can do, except try that it is a little monster

item.name: Pyramid
item.comment: Only 1 play, but I think it's easier to win as the Mummy-player

item.name: Pyramidion
item.comment:
The main element in this game reminds me a bit of Taj Mahal: you get 9 cards (or 10 if you have a torturer on Thebes) and you have to play them in a smart way for ALL 8 locations. So don't start a bidding-war with a player over 1 location, or you'll both be screwed (especially the 1 who loses it :)).
I wonder why they didn't include an actual gameboard? The locations are fixed, so there is no reason to have just lose tiles. And with a gameboard you could have sorted out all resources and cards nicely. I guess production costs are lower now, but it's a pity for the game itself.
As this rating is based on an unfinished game (see gameplay for why), so it could change after a complete game.

item.name: Qin
item.comment: A filler game, as you might expect, as it seems to be the only thing Knizia is making these days. However, from his most recent releases, this is definitely one of his best.

item.name: Qin: Toad and Dragon Turtle Game Boards
item.comment: Feels like more of the same as there are no additional extra rules or so.

item.name: Quarantine
item.comment: Good tile laying game of the same level of Carcassonne, but with higher replayability as you'll have different special rooms each time.

item.name: Quarantine: First Aid Expansion
item.comment: This seems to be literally cut off from one of the sheets with tiles. Imho I think they just took 2 off to give/sell as a promotion. Rather lame way of working!

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: Very original idea with dice. Very good game, just one minor concern: in my first 2 games, it seemed that the starting player (with 2 players) has an advantage, as he can often score as first so he can cull dice as first. 1 Minus point: quality of the dice, the printing want last long I think :s

item.name: Quarriors! Light vs. Dark
item.comment: The game/feature too much. The cow has been milked completely. Only 6 creatures when you need 6? That's telling people: this is in fact (just) an expansion!

item.name: Quarriors! Quarmageddon
item.comment: Extra variety, but a half point more for - finally - a convenient storage box!

item.name: Quarriors! Quarmageddon Multiplying Mischievous Imp Promo Card
Quarriors! Quartifacts
item.comment: Just gave this a neutral rating. That's because I haven't played with the Quests yet, and that essentialy the main feature of this expansion. I am however afraid that this will elongate the gaming time, and that's not quite what I am looking for as a like that gaming time as it is for the moment.

item.name: Quarriors! Quaxos Promo Cards
item.comment: They were for free, so OK to get, but not so special you should buy them.

item.name: Quarriors! Quest of the Qladiator
item.comment: In my first game, there were only of cards from this new expansion and just 1 had bene bought, so can't judge the new 'lock'-mechanism yet.

item.name: Quarriors! Rise of the Demons
item.comment: The corrupted dice with associated cards are a nice addition

item.name: Québec
item.comment:
This is a game you have to play a couple of times to fully understand the cascade-system. The artwork is maby functional, but not so pretty :s
Best with 4 or 5.

item.name: Québec: Hitchcock à Québec
item.comment: No need to have this.

item.name: Queen's Architect
item.comment: A bit of a more difficult game from Queen. Not bad, but once your engine runs, it becomes just a tad too repetitive.

item.name: Qwinto
item.comment: The more tactical version of Qwixx

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: It feels like a sort of remake of Ingenious

item.name: Qwixx
item.comment: Quick, light dice filler game

item.name: Qwixx Mixx
item.comment: Variant A is fun, B rather a crapshoot

item.name: Qwixx: Big Points
item.comment: Fun, but Qwixx Mixx is better

item.name: Qwixx: Het Kaartspel
item.comment: I'm puzzled why they call this the 'more strategic' version of Qwixx? In 'normal' Qwixx you know that there is a Gauss-curve when throwing dice, so not making a big jump over the 7, that's what I call a strategic decision. Here cards come at random. I guess you can start with counting cards and memorizing what has been played, but where is the quick fun game in that?

item.name: Ra: The Dice Game
item.comment: Just OK Game

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: Too many cards; you should probably play this at least 10 times to have a clue how you can build up a good 'engine'

item.name: Ragami
item.comment: It's a typical OK game. Nothing really bad, but also nothing to get really excited about. OK, if somebody wants to play this, but why chose this game out of hundreds of others?

item.name: Railways of Europe
item.comment: Only one play, who had the same problem as my one play with the base game: runaway leader

item.name: Railways of North America
item.comment: The first expansion map I'm not fond of

item.name: Railways of the Western U.S.
item.comment: The rotors and fuel depots are nice, but the best component is for me the map itself: man, this is a hard map!

item.name: Railways of the World: Event Deck
item.comment: It's the kind of expansion that you wouldn't mind playing with one of your Railroad Tycoon/Railways of the World - games, but you also wouldn't mind playing without this expansion

item.name: Railways of the World: Mines
item.comment: I think urbanization is a better way to go.

item.name: Railways of the World: The Card Game
item.comment: Good card game, but they ask too much money for what it is

item.name: Railways of the World: The Card Game Expansion
item.comment: Doens't add that much, but you can make the game longer by just adding the extra rails and cities

item.name: Railways Through Time
item.comment: The idea is a bit crazy, but it works, it gives you more flexebility, but it's harder to so which player can deliver which cubes

item.name: Rallyman
item.comment: Rating after one play. Found the game totally boring, never had any fun feeling when playing this. Most of the time there is only one way to go and then you just hope for the best with the dice/cards. Being last in this game is a very big disadvantage as other can make the track harder for you, so you'll have a bigger chance of having a worse time, so you'll be last again,...

item.name: Rampage
item.comment: This is de kind of chaos game that's fun to do once in a while, but that's it. Not my style of game. But especially with the great components, I can see why a lot of people will love this.

item.name: Rapa Nui
item.comment: Rather light game (as you can expect from Wrede), but a good one. To play with the right player group or at the end of a game session.

item.name: Raptor
item.comment: One of the better asymmetric 2-players I've played so far.

item.name: Rattlebones
item.comment:
It has been a while, but this game as a core game mechanism I haven't seen before: customize your dice. Off course in the end, you are still rolling dice, so you need some luck with your rolls. It stays in the category of family gaming, but luckily doesn't take too long to play.
Just a sidenote: on the box in mentioned 'Printed in the USA with Pride'. Really? The quality of the printing is really bad. Colours are flat and the board has the tendency to curl. This is awful quality, even the better Chinese like Panda produce better quality, so I hope this ain't the best the USA can do on printing :s

item.name: Rattus Cartus
item.comment:
1) It doesn't feel like Rattus at all, imho it's a cardgame for which they want to increase sales and therefore attach a well selling game title to it
2) My 1 play with 3 was rather flat. Probably best with 5 I think as you then would have the most competition. off course, it would maybe go really fast if everybody would pick extra cards as a bonus. So have to try it first!

item.name: Rattus: Africanus
item.comment: Is this the expansion too much? For me it is. Piep Piper was good as you can randomize your characters. I don't have the need to play this game with 5 or 6 and the Islam-class doasn't add much.

item.name: Rattus: Arabian Traders
item.comment: I don't feel the need to play Rattus with 5 or 6, so for me this ain't a must have expansion; however the 'Toll Keeper' is a very nice character if you play with 'Rattus: Mercatus'!

item.name: Rattus: Judge Promo Card
item.comment: Quite tricky this one: for sure you have one safe cube, but you also lose one!

item.name: Rattus: Mercatus
item.comment: Good expansion as the introduction of goods and money really is an asset for the game, but off course only if you add enough class cards that let you manipulate this in a certain way.

item.name: Rattus: Pied Piper
item.comment: It's good to have better alternatives for the witch who is often not taken in our games

item.name: Rattus: Spiel 2010 Bonus Cards
item.comment: Count Dracula seems quite powerfull; 4 extra points is a lot!

item.name: Rattus: Spiel 2011 Bonus Cards
item.comment: No need at all to own/use this.

item.name: Red7
item.comment: Light amusing card game with enough strategy in it

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment: Boring with a capital B

item.name: Régents
item.comment: Good, easy to explain majority game

item.name: Regenwormen Barbecue
item.comment: I was expecting 'Regenwormen' with a little twist, but I was pleasantly surprised that it was 'Regenwormen' with a big twist. It feels different enough to justify owning both

item.name: Relic Runners
item.comment: It's what you can expect from DoW: a family game with a certain depth. The stategy part for Relic Runnes comes in the carefull planning of a Relic Run, you really have to plan 1 or even 2 moves ahead to make sure that none of your opponents grasps the relic you're after for before your nose :s

item.name: Renaissance Man
item.comment:
The basic idea is neat, with the pyramid structure and chosing which actions you will disable, but it somehow seems a bit to luck based. Ok, you can always go for the Renaissance Man, but if you have the luck to get the card with the right icons at the bottom, it's much more easier AND most important you have an action at the level above.
I think that this game would be a lot smoother if there was some flexibility in having the right icons at the bottom of the cards.

item.name: Revolver
item.comment: Good 2-player game

item.name: Revolver 2: Last Stand at Malpaso
item.comment: The Poker 'prelude' doesn't add too much, but all in it seems like a little smoother version of Revolver. If you wanna pick just one, I would say go for this one.

item.name: Revolver Uitbreiding 1.1: Hinderlaag Langs Gunshot Trail
item.originalname: Revolver Expansion 1.1: Ambush on Gunshot Trail
item.comment: The ambush is a powerfull something for Colonel McReady

item.name: Revolver Uitbreiding 1.2: De Jacht is Geopend
item.originalname: Revolver Expansion 1.2: Hunt the Man Down
item.comment: It's not so obvious to go for the prison, it's a bit a poisened gift. Very nice feature!

item.name: Revolver: Brady Logan Promo Card
item.comment: Same rating as base game

item.name: Revolver: Elias Hooker Promo Card
item.comment: Same rating as base game

item.name: Rhino Hero
item.comment: Riff Raff with cards :-)

item.name: Rialto
item.comment: Clearly a lighter Feld, but not all that obvious to play if you wanna win :s Just like Strasbourg, I think this one is better with more players.

item.name: Richelieu
item.comment:
Positive: Short ruleset, easy to explain, plays quick and has some stretegy involved. I like games where you (can) put your ships facedown like Morgenland :D
Negative: It's the kind of game that doesn't make me feel neither warm nor cold. It doens't work with 3: if 2 go for Richelieu/Opposition and the 3rd doesn't, he loses anyway. So only play this game with 4!

item.name: Riff Raff
item.comment: A pity it's so expensice (but seen the components totally understandable!), because this is 1 very fun dexterity game!

item.name: RinglDing
item.comment: Real kids game I quite enjoyed playing myself :)

item.name: Ringo Flamingo
item.comment: Fun, but I'd prefer Crazy Coconuts (by far) or Flying Kiwi's

item.name: Risk: The Lord of the Rings
River Dragons
item.comment: Nice family game, but I think 4 players is the minimum to have a good game

item.name: The Road to Canterbury
item.comment: Very original theme en good quick game.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment:
4th edition of this game orginally from 1999 and you sort of feel that this game dates from the late 90's: poor graphic design, poor quality of the chits, tiles who are too small to store things proparely and what's whith the plastic sheet for drawing roads and bridges? As for value for money, I sort of have the same feeling as with 'The Great Zimbabwe': too expensive for what you actually.
The game itself: a game with a quite hard learning curve it seems to be. Becomes also a bit repetitive near the end as you are again getting trunks, boards,... for converting into the stuff you need. It's certainly not a bad game, but I'm wondering if I will ever play this again?

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island
item.originalname: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment:
When you play a game of Ignacy Trzewiczek there seems to be 2 certitudes: 1) you'll get a rulebook that will give you a headache with lots of little rules here and there and without any player aid to help you. 2) Lots and lots of different symbols, but I must admit that in this game they seem to be logic.
When I'm writing this (16/08/20103), Robinson Crusoe has an average rating of 8.08 and is number 2 in the BGG-hotness. And just like with 'Legends of Andor', I'm wondering, 'Why'? This is mainly a game where you have to turn over cards and tokens and undergo what is written on the card/token. It's not bad a s a co-operative game, but I guess I'm sort of fed-up with co-operative play. They are almost more of the same. If you own Pandemic, Yggdrasil and Defenders of the Realm, you can consider that you'll have all co-operative games you need (and if you want something semi - co-operative, get Shadows over Camelot).

item.name: Rockwell
item.comment: only 1 play so far and a typical 3-player problem: 2 cluster together and excavate tile after tile, while the other stays behind. Also: only 2 trading spaces makes that the player who is left out overthere really has a hard time. I think the only shining number for this game is 4 players.

item.name: Rockwell: Explosion Cards
item.comment: This is too hard: if you've spent $ 2000 (in a 3-player - game) for an upgrade and lose it immediately; or even worse image you've spent $ 5000 for a level 4), that's really to painful.

item.name: Rockwell: Diamond Cards
item.comment: Saves you some trade actions.

item.name: Rogue Agent
item.comment:
I liked Get Nuts, but very disliked Panic Station. So what would it be? Well, I'm afraid this tends more towards Panic Station.
Only 1 play, the Agent-variant (I shudder at the thought of playing the Android-version, in which you have a lot of Ameritrash direct conflict, something I dislike very, very much) and I found it to be very boring. The only 12 actions you take seem to take for ages and at the end you just need some good dice rolls. I won our game because I just had more luck of throwing the stars when attacking criminals.
What certainly didn't help was that Stefaan (who even played it once before!) had to constantly look up questions that arise while playing. And while you can say that dismantling a bomb is a sort of mini game in the game, it just adds a lot more rules to the game, that you have to check while playing.
I've noticed there are some payer aids here on BGG, it's a riddle why they aren't included standard in the game for such a game with so many rules.

item.name: Rokoko
item.comment:
I liked what father and Son Malz made of Edo and I love the designs of M. Cramer (Glen More, Lancaster and especially Helvetia), so this game was a no brainer: just buy!
Finally played it having some high expectations. Was this such a great game? To be honest, no, therefore there is nothing really refreshing in here, nothing we haven't seen before in an other game. Is it still a good game that I'll gladly play most of the times? Definitely yes! This game plays very smooth and is very tense to play as you always have to hope that the item you are aiming for still will be available if it's your turn. I like deck-building a lot and collecting resources is my thing, so what' not to like for me :-)

item.name: Rokoko: Fancy Dresses Promo
item.comment: More variety, what's not to like :)

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment: It's more straightforward then it's card game predecessor, but still not my cup of tea.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: OK dice game, but there are better

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Iron Age
item.comment: 'Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age' is simple quite fast dice game of 'Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization'; This version has been made unnecessary complex, which makes that playing time, but certainly the downtime is far too much in this game.

item.name: Rolling Freight
item.comment:
Sort of classic tran game like Railroad Tycoon, but with implementation of dice. As you only need 1 specific color for purchasing a contract, there is almost no 'faulure-because-of-bad-luck' - in this game, nice implementation of dice.
What turns me a bit of is the - imho - ugly artwork that doens't seems to be that functional is you still have te search where you can deliver those good cubes.

item.name: Rondo
item.comment: One of the better fillers of Knizia, but it stays a filler after all and the question is if you wanna spent so much money on just another filler?

item.name: Room 25
item.comment: This game has the advantage of being really quick, so if you're death quite early, you probably won't have to wait that long for your turn. Original game mechanism!

item.name: Roundhouse Kick
item.comment:
This must be one if the lesser interesting games I've played so far. I was glad our game was over and had to keep myself awake during play.
First you got to be lucky with the card you draw. If it's not one that gives you extra dice, you're already screwed, because with extra dice you have more chance of hitting on monsters and if you can slay a monster you get extra cards, which will give you more possibilities,...
And if you're behind, your chances of even staying further behind are big, because you will have to start the next round, but probably you won't have a good card, so you'll just make it easier for your opponents to slay the monsters, so that they will have even more cards...:s

item.name: Royals
item.comment:
Well, 1 thing is for sure: Peter Hawes likes majorities :-)
As a game itself I like this (as I like majorities as a game mechanism). My only 'complaint' about this game is that it feels like Triassic Terror revisited and rethemed.
If you already own that one, then it doens't feel like you also need to own this. but if you don't own Triassic Terror yet and like majorities, this (cheaper) game is a good one to have in your collection.

item.name: Rozenkoning
item.comment: Pure abstract, felt a bit like a variation off chess, but then different :D.

item.name: Ruhrschifffahrt 1769-1890
item.comment:
One play where we played some things wrong, but corrected them during gameplay. For the price they asked (and certainly are now asking here in the BGG market) the quality components & value for what you get is clearly very low. And the artwork ain't that great either (was there really no other way to put the scutcheon then as a watermark INTO the name?).
The game itself: good, but not that good that I would pay 70 euro for it. It's a sort of race to get things delivered first at certain locations to unlock certain actions/bonusmarkers (as for instance the bonusmarkers for warehouses and for leftover money are limited to 2), hopefully in combination with a high value dice. However there is no hiding in this game: there are only 12 rounds, so if you wanna go for the warehouses bonus, you have to start building right away or you won't have finished before the end of the game, so it will be clear to anybody that that will be your main target. My feelings after 1 play is that it could be a bit more streamlined, that some parts really feel mechanic.
But if Davy wants to play it again, I'll be glad to join ;-)

item.name: Russian Railroads
item.comment: This is by far the best Essen 2013-release I've played so far. For a HiG is quite complex and you really have to stay focussed on certain paths. I'm glad the Dutch version will be available soon :)

item.name: Russian Railroads: German Railroads
item.comment: Excellent new twist for an already excellent game.

item.name: Russian Railroads: Mini-Expansion
item.comment: More variety is excellent, but I'm wandering if the one that let's you activate 2 extra question marks if you reach it with your industry marker ain't too powerful?

item.name: Saboteur: De Uitbreiding
item.comment: Don't know about this one yet: I certainly like this scoring system a lot more. But my main issue is the longer gaming time this expansion seems to bring along. For me Saboteur is a quick, fun game for whom 30 minutes is perfect. 60 minutes is too long for this kind of game.

item.name: Safranito
item.comment: You have to play this with people who just wanna have fun while playing

item.name: Sail to India
item.comment: Sail to India is a school example of how to make a good game with only 23 cards and 60 cubes and a compact ruleset as a bonus.

item.name: Saint Malo
item.comment: Light dice game in the genre of Veags, but this one has less interaction then Vegas (but a little bit more strategy).

item.name: Saint Petersburg (second edition)
item.comment: - The artwork: why the hell did they change the pretty artwork? - Why not include all the extra's (like the new society) when doing a reprint? + The Market: It seems to be a valid extra to score points (and get some income)

item.name: Saint Petersburg (second edition): Emergency Storehouse Expansion
item.comment: Very handy at certain moments

item.name: Saint Petersburg (second edition): The Exclusive Spieleschmiede Expansion
item.comment: OK add-on

item.name: Sake & Samurai
item.comment:
If you want to make a party game, why make it so complicated?
One play, found it boring. If the group of ghosts gets to big, they win easily.

item.name: Salmon Run
item.comment: Quite light, but quick, racing game. If you play a boardgame from time to time, neglact the advice from the rulebook to only use 5 boards with a 'E' (= easy), that's more for people who have never played a boardgame before, but is far too easy imho.

item.name: Salmon Run: The Fisherman Board
item.comment: I always like extra features :D

item.name: Salmon Run: The Fork/Cataract Falls Board
Samurai: The Card Game
item.comment: Quick, Ok version of Samurai

item.name: Sanssouci
item.comment: Ok abstract puzzle-optimization - game. A game I'd like to play from time to time, but no big wow-feeling after 1 play of the standard game.

item.name: Santa Cruz
item.comment:
While Hawaii was a HIG+, Santa Cruz is rather a HIG- cencerning complexity (where Stone Age is my midpoint) making it a fast an easy game, perfect to play with non-gamers.
I especially like the 2nd round where you chose your set and scoring cards and everything is open, which is a more tactical round.
After playing this a couple of times, I must say there is more to it then you think, it's not just putting some pieces on the board. Raised score from 7 -> 8

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: One play, don't have a clue on how you can win this one :s

item.name: Santiago de Cuba
item.comment: One play, but at a moment I was rather tired: it felt kind of repetitive and with 4 layers, it seemed I always was in the same area to make a choice. I think it will be better with 3, rating might go up then.

item.name: Santy Anno
item.comment: The main part of the game exists of calculating if everybody is in the right chair, which makes it quite boring for me

item.name: Sapiens
item.comment: Tile Placement, it will never be my favorite gaming mechanism and this game won't change that. What is also a fact, that is there are no double tiles in this game. They made that a separate mini-expansion, but while you're playing the game, that simply feels as a miss, so by creating that mini-expansion, they fucked up there own base game. Therefore I also deducted 1 point from my rating. I simply hate it when they take parts from the base game, that should be part of the base game, for the simple reason as being able to create a mini-expansion.

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: If you play this game, you need A. Time and B. People who don't mind to do a lot of calculations. As you don't get change and you get cards of (very) different nominations, a lot of math is needed to optimize your moves.

item.name: Schatz der Kobolde
item.comment: Everbody likes the magic crystal :)

item.name: Scheffeln
item.comment: It's not as bad as I thought when looking at the average rating of 5.54 (25/08/2015), but it ain't great neither. What it certainly is, is a lot of chaos, so if you don't like that, just stay away of this game. Otherwise, just give it a try :-)

item.name: Scheffeln: Run-expansion
item.comment: Brings even more chaos to an already chaotic game.

item.name: Schotten-Totten
item.comment: OK and nice

item.name: Schweinebande
item.comment: Amusing game with a little bit of strategy and a good dose of luck, ideal as a light family game.

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment: It really depends on the skills of the players if this game is fun or not

item.name: Scoville
item.comment:
When I first read the rules, I already had the impression: 'nothing new here'. Unfortunately, that impression was confirmed by my first play. The plantation thing is somewhat new, but basically the colour mixing has been used in other games as Fresco or Experiment and in it's heart it's a resource collection game where you always aim to get the most valuable resources and convert them in as many points as possible, as seen in so many other games before.
Not that there is anything bad about this game, absolutely not (otherwise I wouldn't give this a 7)! It just reminded me of Eric W. Martin's statement 'new games are for new gamers', because if you play boardgames for about 5 years, you'll probably just have the feeling of 'been there, done that'.
Components wise: the coins could have been a bit bigger and the 'red' is typically 'Chinese red' :s

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: The different dice for each season and dice features themselves are very nice/innovating. For the rest it's looking for good combo's in your Power Cards.

item.name: Seasons: Crystal Titan Promo
item.comment: If if you can't use it's special power, 9 points for 1 fire (with 2 players), that's not bad :-)

item.name: Seasons: Enchanted Kingdom
item.comment: Good expansion, a must have if you've mastered the base game.

item.name: Seasons: Igramul the Banisher
item.comment: Nasty one if it is in the drafting :s

item.name: Seasons: Path of Destiny
item.comment: I like the extra Power cards that come with this set much more then those from 'Enchanted Kingdom'.

item.name: Le Secret de Monte Cristo
item.comment: Very simple rules, but damn hard to master

item.name: Seeland
Seenot im Rettungsboot
item.comment: Good game, but you should be with at least 4

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: Good co-operative

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: The Card Game
item.comment: It's more a sort of memory game with the Shadows over Camelot theme pasted on it. You won't feel going on a quest when playing this.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: The Card Game – Merlin & Morgan Promo cards
Shadows over the Empire
item.comment:
Well, I hope we did something wrong, because my 1 game so far wasn't that great: it lasted only 2 rounds. In the first round I did 1 action: influence another character. In the 2nd I did 3: influence 2 characters and used 1 ability. And then the game was finished :(
Reason: All the face-downed characters touching my corner weren't accessible for me and the abilities of the characters around my leader weren't useful to change anything about that (no swap or something like that) :s
Edit: second play on 8/11, and again the same problem, finished after round 2. Instead of playing this game, you can just shuffle cards, read them and determine the winner in advance based on who has the best cards around his leader. Clearly a broken game!

item.name: Shakespeare
item.comment: ++ The game itself. I love this kind of (semi-)heavy games where you wanna do X actions, but can only do X-2. ++Very beautiful artwork - the number of characters and secret objectives is rather low. I always like some variety, even if that means that not all the cads will come into play. - The game is susceptible for AP

item.name: Shakespeare: Prospero
item.comment: Can be very nice in combination with the right actor or actrice

item.name: Shanghaien
item.comment: Nice light 2-player where the dice can like you...or not :D

item.name: Shark
item.comment: Game that tries to be strategic (and uses some elements of Acquire), but has far too much luck involved to be strategic or even tactical.

item.name: Shave a Sheep
item.comment: Can be fun if you're in the right mood

item.name: Sheepdogs of Pendleton Hill
item.comment: Good game, but not a game that will cause you to have wet dreams or something like that.

item.name: Sheepland
item.comment: Very nice looking game (with beautiful sheep meeples), but in fact a pure abstract game.

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment: 100% bluffing- game. I can see why people like this, but it is totally not my cup-of-tea and rated it therefore low.

item.name: Sherwood Forest
item.comment: Rating based on one 3-player basic game; the game for 'professionals' will probably be better

item.name: Ships
item.comment: (Finally) A more heavier game of Martin Wallace. Timing of retrieving your cubes is very crucial in this game.

item.name: Shitenno
item.comment: Same mechanism as in San Marco, a mechanism I like

item.name: Shitenno: Geisha Promo Card
item.comment: Not so special addition.

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: Now I have an idea of the game flow, I have to play it again to make a final judgement. However from my 1 play so far it feels of a game with a lot of possible frustration coming from the cube tower :s

item.name: Show Manager
item.comment: Good set-collection game where luck kan be quite important.

item.name: Siberia
item.comment: It seems a simple game, but it requires some good planning and timing if you wanna have a chance of winning

item.name: Siberia: The Card Game
item.comment: Not bad, it feels indeed like Siberia, but it's nothing more then a - good - filler.

item.name: Sifaka
item.comment: This game had drawn my attention because of the beautiful cover. It had some nice mechanics, but there is too much AP in this game certainly if the player before you places his card on the spot you were aiming for.

item.name: Signorie
item.comment:
This one feels totally like a WYG?-game, by whom I mean that after reading the rules, you have a general feeling of 'how-the-hell-do-you-have-to-play-this-if-I-wanna-win?' :-)
It's a very abstract game, with totally pasted theme and apart from the box art, I'm not that keen on the art inside the box.
But the main question is off course: is this a good game, and answer is for sure 'yes'. You wanna do X-moves, but can only do X-2 and in this game is the order in which you chose your dice and perform your actions of extreme high importance.

item.name: Singapore
item.comment: Descent tile-laying game, nothing special, but it works.

item.name: Singapore: Essen 2011 bonus tiles
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Sint Petersburg - Uitbreiding
item.originalname: Saint Petersburg: New Society & Banquet Expansion

item.name: Skittykitts
item.comment: Typically pure Ameritrash game with super annoying cards as 'Your character can't win', totally not my type of game. There are also ridiculous low cards in the basic game.

item.name: Skull
item.comment: What the hell were they thinking when then gave this game a prize: this is a very, very bad version of Perudo.

item.name: Sky Traders
item.comment:
I'm rating this a 3 because a 3 on BGG means 'Likely want play this again, but could be convinced'. The convincing would be done within the second if someone could find a way to play this game within 2 hours or less.
If I would have to rate this game for it's mechanics, I would give this game an 8 or even a 8.5. I really like them and it's a quite refreshing way for a pick-up-and-deliver game in combination with a fluctuating picemarket. I also really like that you can go for risky goods as Grog or Sludge, but that there is a risk connected to doing that, by certain Ill Wind - cards.
But what turns me off completely is the playing time. Our first game with 4, WITH THE SHORT VARIANT, took almost 4 hours. And it can't stay interesting for 4 hours, then it really becomes to repetitive.
I think this problem could been easily fixed if FFG of the designer would have created a double sided victory point track, where the backside would have a simliar structure (as I like the basic idea that the last points or more expensive to buy), but you would only need 30 points for a win (with nu sludge in your cargo). I don't understand that neither the designer, neither FFG saw this big issue with this game and could come up with such an idea. Really a pity and I hope some who is good with a computer (or even better FFG thereselves) can create something like that and post it here.

item.name: Skyline
item.comment: Light dice game, where imho the one who will finish the game by putting down a level 6 - building will most likely win.

item.name: Slavika
item.comment: If you read the mechanics, you think you have an interesting game, but I found my 1 play rather dull, it takes too long for what it is.

item.name: Slavika: Zmora
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: Not so many rules and fun to play; Because of the difference in combination between race/special power you have a lot of variety, which is grate

item.name: Small World Realms
item.comment: Rating based on just 1 scenario played, but I'm always a fan of extra randomness to increase the replayability :)

item.name: Small World Underground
item.comment: The relics/popular places and the idea of the river are neat, but they are a bit too much similarities with Small World itself for some races (extra victory point if you own certain regions). They could easily add the relics/popular places and new ideas for races/special powers as an expansion to Small World.

item.name: Small World: A Spider's Web
item.comment: I think my start to have enough variety from now on...

item.name: Small World: Be Not Afraid...
item.comment: Half point more for the storage tray :)

item.name: Small World: Cursed!
item.comment: Not something you 'must have', but it's nice in general to have extra tiles; therefore I gave it the same score as the base game

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
item.comment: Not something you 'must have', but it's nice in general to have extra tiles; therefore I gave it the same score as the base game

item.name: Small World: Necromancer Island
item.comment: Gives a different feeling while playing: you don't want to slash your opponents as much as before :D

item.name: Small World: Tales and Legends
item.comment: It adds a nice twist to the game as some regions can become interesting for everyone or can screw you up big time, but you know one round in advance what's coming

item.name: Small World: Tunnels
item.comment: The idea is nice: you can combine your both stand-alone games Small World & Small World Underground. But set-up takes a long time, it is mess taking the right tokens and sorting out everything after the game is also anoying.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment: It doesn't take too long to play and is very easy to explain, and that's good, otherwise it would outstay it's welcome. However, the focus seems to be more on destroying eachother Minions then on building up something together.

item.name: Smash Up: Awesome Level 9000
item.comment: The extra VP-tokens are nice, so you don't have to write down scores anymore, and also the base-cards with extra large text are a good thing. And off course the extra factions give more variety to your base game. So all inn, a very good expansion, whom could have been cheaper imho if they didn't made such a unnecessary hugue box, which you don't need at all as you can put everything in the box of your base game.

item.name: Smash Up: The Obligatory Cthulhu Set
item.comment: More of the same

item.name: Sneaks & Snitches
item.comment: I like games where you have to outguess your opponents

item.name: Snow Tails
item.comment: Played it twice and 2 times the same problem: runaway leader!! Someone gets out of the pack and has a clear path, while the others are blocking eachother.

item.name: Snowdonia
item.comment:
Let me start by saying that the rating has still a hugue potential to increase. However my first play of this game was really dramatic (see logged play of 10/11/2012). But the mechanics are interesting. It's the kind of game where you have to set 1 or 2 goals and then stick by them and just go for it. It'snice to see that you can win without having a 3rd meeple.
Edit 05/07/2014: Had a 2nd play and increased rating after having a nice time playing this game :)

item.name: Snowdonia: Britannia Bridge
item.comment: Quite confusing the you can built track into a station :s

item.name: Snowdonia: Engine No1 L.A.D.A.S (Lost) Promo Card
item.comment: Very nice as you can have a train without having to invest in bars and the Journeyman-actions are also worth some points

item.name: Snowdonia: Essen 2012 Promo Cards
item.comment: The Ivor -train can be very helpful in those games were there is a lot of fog

item.name: Snowdonia: Jungfraubahn & Mount Washington
item.comment: Only played the Mount Washington-scenario so far. I like that one as it sets things upside down.

item.name: Snowdonia: The Daffodil Line
item.comment: Nice scenario which will result in high scores as almost everybody will collect those daffodils

item.name: Snowdonia: The Necropolis Railway & Neuhauser Bockerlbahn
item.comment: Only played the Necropolis-line so far, which is an enjoyable scenario.

item.name: Snuffie Hup
item.comment:
Don't know how the mechanism of the jumping of Snuffie just works, but sometimes he already jumps after 2 carrots and then you have a very, very short game were when playing with 4 not even every player had a chance to spin the wheel.
They also could have skipped all the point-stuff, because basically: the player who catches Snuffie = the winner.

item.name: Sobek
item.comment: Nice, not a lot of rules, not to hard, but enough interesting choices. Everything you can expect from a game from GameWorks :)

item.name: Sorry! Schuivers
item.comment: Simple deterity game which doesn't take so long to play, but isn't so intriging as Crokinole

item.name: SOS Titanic
item.comment: Like Augustus is bing revisited, this is Patience revisited. So this is a great game to play solo :D

item.name: Space Cadets
item.comment:
This seems hard! We played at easy and mission 1 and after only 5 turns our core exploded :s
If you don't like cooperative games because 1 player is to bossy, this is your game, you won't have the time to interfer with others!

item.name: Space Cadets Promo Pack
item.comment: Some extra variety,especially in the crystals, which is always nice.

item.name: Space Maze
item.comment: Far too chaotic for my taste and then I only played a 2-player game :s

item.name: Spectaculum
item.comment: A recent Knizia (which, apart from Qin, has become a synonym for fillers that are rip-offs of previous game and are not worthwile playing and certainly not owning) + low rating, made of low expectations. Most of us however were pleasantly surprised by this game that is still a filler (typically a small ruleset and short playing time), but in whom you have the feeling that your decissions matter. But to make things clear: we immediately played by the 'more strategic'-variant, were you can draw 4 markers instead of just 3.

item.name: Specter Ops
item.comment: Scotland Yard or Letters From Whitechapel with some extra's. But the extra's really do add something meaningful: the vehicle really helps if the hunters realise they were in the wrong sector and the different characters help for replayability of this game.

item.name: Speculation
item.comment:
If you wanna have a chance at winning this game, you have to obey 2 laws:
1) Like in real life when dealing with stock: buy low, sell high 2) Control your greed: if you've bought a share at rank 6, 7 or 8, it's better to cash in as it reaches rank 2 or 3, as you will have made a nice profit and the potential of going higher comes with a big risk of going down again.
If you wanna play this game, you have to be very opportunistic. If that's nothing for you, then this game is probably nothing for you. Shares can go up fast, but also go down very fast, nothing's for sure in this game and you have to make the best of the situation when you can trade.

item.name: Speculation Queenie 1: New Action and Movement Tiles
item.comment: More action tiles, that's what we want :)

item.name: Speculation Queenie 2: 7th and 8th Players
item.comment:
Are there really people who wanna play this with 7 or 8? :s
Concerning the minus-cards: they add strategy to the game, as you can use it when you have 2 shares you don't wanna see rise, but they also add extra gaming time to the game, as shares can move back again.

item.name: Speculation Queenie 3: Action and Movement Dice
