item.comment: Makes the game quicker, but adds more randomness

item.name: Speedcatch Doraemon
item.comment: It's the same game as a cardgame we call 'stronten', with the only difference you have to grab a Doraemon figure instead of hitting a deck with cards.

item.name: Spellbound
item.comment:
The artwork and components are really delightful. A pity that the hat pieces are in wood instead of resin, now they just doens't seem to fit into the bigger picture.
The game itself: 2 solo-plays only so far. Lost 1 and won one (but close to losing). All mechanics work well together. Putting as many good cards (= allies) into your deck, seems to be the key to win.

item.name: Spiegel Spukschloss
item.comment: 1 play with 4 adults. It came down to it that I had all the luck that my symbol was turned over by the others and I could collect them all as first. Rembering which ghost is the real ghost ain't that difficult for adults.

item.name: Spinderella
item.comment: I can totally understand why this is Kinderspiel des Jahres 2015 as it is an Original game concept how the spiders work. Also fun to play as an adult.

item.name: Spinnengift und Krötenschleim
item.comment: Good variation on the memory-mechanic, but imho a bit too long, there's no challenge anymore at the end of the game. For our 2-player game I removed 2 ghosts and that works fine.

item.name: Spinnentwist
item.comment:
This is in fact a pure abstract 2-player game. Plus is that's is easy to explain and doesn't take long. It's harder then it seems to play.
Minus is that you won't be on fire while playing this. It's like chess , but with spiders in a spiderweb

item.name: Splendor
item.comment: This game has it all: very easy rules to explain, turns are fast, enough strategy (don't just take things as a chicken without a head, but look at what your opponents are doing!) and it's one of these games where you wanna play rightaway an other game after your first game. Excellent job!

item.name: Spokentrap
item.comment: Memory game, even fun to play as an adult, if you use the 'expert' rules (if you trow a ghost you can swap two ghosts OR swap colors)

item.name: Spokenval
item.comment: Makes it for the adults even harder

item.name: Spookies
item.comment: This is off course very, very light and very luck dependent, but as it is press-your-luck, something I like very much, and it doesn't take long to play, so I'll gladly play this again.

item.name: Spookies extension 1: Dice Joker
item.comment: Can save your day :-)

item.name: Spookies extension 2: Spooky Ghost
item.comment: Completely unnecessary

item.name: Spot the difference lotto
item.comment: A 1 'defies description of a game' is totally in its place for this 'game'

item.name: Spyrium
item.comment: If you designed a game like Caylus, I can imagine it's hard to make something new, as everybody will compare your new design with Caylus. William Attia certainly took his time before he releasing something new after Caylus Magna Carta. And for me it was worth it. It's not the 'new Caylus'. But you feel that the design is polished, there seem to be no overpowered cards or combo's and it feels like is more then enough playtested to just work as it should be. The putting down meeples between cards is a nice feature, feels a bit similar to the mechanic used in Hermagor. The entire game you'll have to make interesting choices (wait an other turn hoping to have a greater return/cheaper price with the risk that someone else grabs it?) an that's the type of game I like to play.

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: Don't understand the hype. Isn't this just a deckbuilder, number 100.000 in the row? What's so special about it? I don't see it anyway.

item.name: Star Realms: Gambit Set
item.comment: The Gambit-addition is OK, but the Merc Cruisers seem to cheap for 5 combat and activation of an alley of your choice.

item.name: Star Realms: Mercenary Garrison Promo Card
Star Wars: Het kaartspel
item.comment:
3rd LCG I've played (after Lord of the Rings and Android: Netrunner). They all - for me - have the same problem: complex ruleset with some easy to forget little rules, unclear situations when you play certain cards and only enjoyable if you have a gaming partner who is willing to play with you this game time after time.
If I'm rating this game a 7, it's more because I see the potential this game has if you play this a lot with an evenly skilled player, rather then I'm expressing the willingness to play this.

item.name: Starfighter
item.comment: Not my type of game I'm afraid.

item.name: Starship Merchants
item.comment:
Plus: There is more depth into this game then you can imagine after reading the rules. Carefull timing/planning of doing what and when at each location is very crucial in this game.
Minus: With 4 the gaming time is too long (> 2 hours with only 1 slow player at the table; all new), 3 is probably the shining number with this one. Also: if someone clears the destination card you're after, that can be very painfull :s

item.name: Startup Fever
item.comment:
The base game is a very dull game which reminded me a bit of Game of Goose as you trow some dice, if you're lucky you get some more income then the rest, just because you have luck and then you buy some cubes. As you can only have 1 big guy (why also making this confusing that they counts for all your companies so you have to be ignorant all the time to not forget to count them??) of each kind, once you have these you take money making cubes in the beginning and point taking cubes at the end of the game. That is the base game.
So what did they do to 'spice' things up? They made cards by whom you can bully each other. What you get as a basically dull game with tons of chaos that takes way too long and a random winner.
My conclusion: NEVER again!!!!!

item.name: Die Staufer
item.comment:
HiG + Steding = this should be good and it certainly is!
It has the same level of complexity as Russian Railroads, but is not that difficult to explain.

item.name: Steam Park
item.comment:
+ Very nice material + You have to make some interesting choices during the game + Theme is strongly present
- Simultaneous dice rolling: it will never be my favourite game mechanism in a game that should be strategic - I don't think that it's a good idea that some bonus cards are more then once into the deck. Let's say you have 1 that gives money for the number of stands you have and you decide to invest in it. After a while you decide you have enough stands to cash the bonus card in. If you then later in the game can get hold of the double copy, you just get (lots) of money 'for free' as you don't 'have to work for it' anymore.

item.name: Steam Park: Essen Special Cards
item.comment: The idea of the bonus card is nice, but (as in the base game) I don't like doubles like this (see comments base game)

item.name: Steam Time
item.comment: One of this games that stayed on under the radar and that's completely undeserved. You're under a lot of pressure right from the start to start collecting VP (I mean esteem off course) and building some kind of engine that you have to rebuild each time as those crystals keep on disappearing. Thank you Ellen for pointing out this game to me!

item.name: Steam Works
item.comment:
After some disappointing games like City Hall or OK games (like Scoville), finally TMG has put again a game on the market that's worth owning. But it also comes (in Europe) with a high selling price.
There is only 1 very big minus about this game: the rulebook. 1 component is even missing (you can find an updated rulebook in the files section), but the rules are unclear on a lot of things. After reading the rules you have the feeling that you can built further on existing devices, but that ain't the case as it would make the Upgrader useless. What ain't clear either from the rules is if you have 2 electrical components connected in series, you activate both when you put your mechanic an the electrical source or just the orthogonal adjacent ones? Our gut feeling says both, but it would have been nice that the rules were clear on that.

item.name: Steam: Map Expansion #4
item.comment: Only played South-Africa so far, which is a very, very difficult map

item.name: Steampunk Rally
item.comment: I don't like racing games, but I can enjoy games which involves racing, but has a lot more going on (like Jamaica). In this game, the fun part is that you are building your own racing device which requires a lot of managing and makes the arcing part feels only of secondary importance :D

item.name: Sticheln
item.comment: There is probably a certain tactic you can use, but a good hand to start with, helps a lot

item.name: Stone Age: Casino
item.comment: This is even for me in a dice game a bit too random :s

item.name: Stone Age: Style is the Goal
item.comment:
As I find Stone Age a great game, I had some high expectations about this one. They weren't quite forfilled, but I think it's also due to the fact that we were playing with 5. I think it will be better with 3 or 4.
I think it's to easy to get a card (or even 2) using the ornaments/jewelery.

item.name: Stoom: Rails, Roem en Rijkdom
item.comment: Compared to Railroad Tycoon the reduced playing time and scores close together (no runaway leader) are positive, but the almost fixed choice of actions is negative

item.name: Strasbourg
item.comment: Like this game very, very much; Easy rules, but hard to win make the best games

item.name: Stronghold
item.comment:
This game always intrigued me, but at the time it was released, I hardly played 2-player games (and lets be honest, this is just a 2-player game!) as I always played with couples and rulebooks of 24 pages also turned me off at that moment.
But know I'm glad I got to know this game thanks to Wim and a second edition will certainly be in my collection when it releases this Essen :-)

item.name: A Study in Emerald
item.comment:
+ Very Original game. It's clearly something different then other games I've played before. If you would ask me to compare it with an other game, I couldn't name 1. + It requires a very unique way of thinking as you want to score more points then all other players in your group, but have to make sure that the player becoming last isn't in your team. That's a real mind fuck :s
- Explaining the rules is a tough job. I'm really glad that for my first game I had an explanation from some experienced players/explainers (Myriam & Surya gave demo's of this game at Essen 2013). - 5 different graphical artist?? Not a good idea!

item.name: Subdivision
item.comment: Lesson learned: scoring maximum from tiles connected to the road is important!

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment: Very short and easy rules, but quite hard to play as getting the right amount of money can really be a pain in the ass most of the times and you constant have to chose which tiles to go for. Also a very neat idea of the downgrading when you pass a red line on the scoring track.

item.name: Suburbia 5★
item.comment: I have to check, but I think there are more tiles with this expansion -> longer gaming time, womething I dislike. You also can't neglect the *'s, it's also an aspect I don't like in expansions when they add something you can't ignore.

item.name: Suburbia: Con Tiles
item.comment: Extra tiles, good, but off course only helpful if a lot of them come out and you can make combo's

item.name: Suburbia: Essen SPIEL Expansion
item.comment: I think this is more a gimminck then an expansion you can built a strategy on as it's far from obvious to get the required combo :s

item.name: Such a Thing?
item.comment: Not my kind of game at all

item.name: Sugar Gliders
item.comment: Not a bad game, that is quick to explain and to play, but it's a sort of Pinguïn revisited, so nothing new here.

item.name: Sumeria
item.comment: Rating after one play. Didn't like the game because if you're start player to often, you're screwed

item.name: Summoner Wars: Khexhu
item.comment: Good ability, the regeneration

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment:
Big plus: easy rules, easy to explain and to play. Turns are quick and the goal is obvious for everybody. Nice idea of turning defeated units into magical points.
Minus: lots of text on the cards and as they lay so you can read yours, you don't have a clue of what the cards of your opponent do, unless you ask him all the time. That can prolong the playing time.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Sairook
item.comment: As he is quite expensive to summon, I have my doubts on how good his power is?

item.name: Sun Tzu
item.comment: Outguessing your opponents is something I like to do.

item.name: Sun, Sea & Sand
item.comment: Nice

item.name: Sunrise City
item.comment: From all the (few) city tile - building games I played so far, I found this to be one of the better one. I especially like the scoring mechanism for Benchmark tokens.

item.name: Super Motherload
item.comment: Deckbuilding with a board. Not bad, but after 1 (incomplete) play I didn't have the feeling I wanted to pay 40 euro's for it as it wouldn't have an added value to my collection

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment:
Played with some of the challenge rules, but I doubt that this game needs them. The stupid thing with those challenge rules is that the icons, nore text on the board aren't correct anymore, which makes it confusing.
Second play by the basic rules: much better!

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! 5-6 Player Mini Expansion
item.comment: It's a pity that it's only a 5-6 player expansion, with nothing extra and that the other components are just replacements of what they screwed up with the base game :(

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! The Giant Squid Mini Expansion
item.comment: Don't know if adds that much

item.name: Sushi Dice
item.comment: You try to roll the tokens depicted on 1 of the cards and opponents can steal your dice if you and other rolling participant both have a black symbol at the same time. With those blacks symbols, you can also force your opponent to reroll all his dice.

item.name: Sushi Draft
item.comment: + easy to explain + easy and short to play (only 15 minutes) - the fact that the point value of each token within the same group of sushi is not the same, and you draw 1 blind, makes this too luck dependant

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment: Nice little filler game with a far better scoring mechanism then Sushi Draft!

item.name: Sushi Go!: Sojasosse
item.comment: Extra's are always good :-)

item.name: SWAT!
item.comment: Nothing special, a good filler to end the evening; Don't play this with less then 4, it simply ain't fun at all

item.name: Switching Tracks
item.comment: A classical pick-up-and-delivery - game with the twist of the switching of tracks. Not bad, but becomse a bit too repetitive near the end

item.name: Sylla
item.comment: I think this is a game that you can fully enjoy if every player has played this game 3 - 4 times before

item.name: T.I.M.E Stories
item.comment:
I played the first scenario entirely until the end. Most of my thoughts are explained with the description of our runs (it contains tons of spoilers!).
What bothered me in our first case the was was the fact that you can get stuck and there is in fact no way to solve this: if you can't solve the puzzle/riddle, you're simply stuck, there are no possible extra hints (at the costs of T.U. or something like that). We knew there had to be traps, but some of them seemed a bit too harsh. Losing 5 T.U. is simply a lot if you only get 30 T.U. And if they wanna create dead ends, OK for me, but make sure it doesn't cost so much T.U. as the one in case 1. And a last complaint: you should be able to keep more items. In the 3rd and final run going through the first rooms from the previous runs were you know where to find the items you needed seem a bit too artificial.
All above sounds very negative, but in fact I'm quite positive about my first experience with this game (otherwise I wouldn't rate it 7.5 after 1 case) and I'm looking forward to case number 2. The artwork is really gorgeous and I like the puzzle-solving aspect and you are really working together in this one.

item.name: Tahiti
item.comment: Pure pick-up-and-delivery game. But maybe a bit too simple. I think it would be better if the reefs wouldn't be all in the same V-shape at the bottom, because if you're laying them in your neighbourhood, you're not going to lay them so that they bother you, so imho it's to easy to avoid them.

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment: Very good game, but you need to focus on one main aspect (economics or chains of palaces)

item.name: Take 5
item.comment: Fun to end the gaming night

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment: The medium slightly more heavy game. The kind I like :D

item.name: Takenoko: Chibis
item.comment: Expansions that add extra possibilities (also in scoring) are always excellent!

item.name: Talat
item.comment: Its' the kind of game you only wanna play with certain people, in my case fast playing people. 1 play so far and I enjoyed it as everybody had a feeling of 'will just play and will see what becomes'. However, I can see this being a game where everybody wants to think long before making a move and then this is definitely NOT my game.

item.name: Tales & Games: Baba Yaga
item.comment:
This is a typical filler game that combines memory with a speed element. The hard thing for me, as a man only being able to concentrate on 1 thing at a time, is that I can't focus on learning which ingredient is where while the active player is flipping tiles and making sure that I don't hold back the chain of moving the Baba Yaga - figurine :s
It plays really fast and everybody is involved in every turn, so this is a game I wouldn't mind playing from time to time.

item.name: Tales & Games: Little Red Riding Hood
item.comment: Quick Co-operative game with some memory and some push-your-luck. As always very nice implementation of the story with nice components

item.name: Tales & Games: The Grasshopper & the Ant
item.comment: Outguessing your opponents, a mechanism I personally like. And this game uses it in a good way (with nice material).

item.name: Tales & Games: The Hare & the Tortoise
item.comment:
Only 1 play, but that was good fun! The way each animal moves is the result of some very clever game design and there are some intelligent ways to get rid of 'not wanted animals'.
From the first 4 tales, this is by far the best.

item.name: Tales & Games: The Three Little Pigs
item.comment: Fun, light push-your-luck dice game. Excellent implementation of the theme!

item.name: Tales & Games: The Three Little Pigs – Bonus Card
Taluva
item.comment: Easy rules, not so easy to win

item.name: Tammany Hall
item.comment: Plus: not so much rules to explain for being a deep strategy game. However, for really understand the flow, I think this is the kind of game you have to play 5 - 10 times in a short period of time with the same players so that everybody is equally skilled.

item.name: Targi
item.comment: This is one of the very best 2-players games that has been released since years (like Jambo or Mr. Jack or so :D)!

item.name: Tash-Kalar: Arena of Legends
item.comment: I see the quality of the game, but it requires 2D-insight an that's not my strongest point :s

item.name: Tash-Kalar: Arena of Legends – Legendary Summoner Promo
Taverna
item.comment:
Taverna is a tactical game: see what customers are available when it's your turn and take the one that works best for you. It's rare that there ain't one who does something good for you.
The rules could be a bit more clear on how the royal favour and spell works :s

item.name: Templar Queenie 1: The Messages & The Coins
item.comment: Best Queenie for Templar imho, as the coins give you an extra goal were you can aim at.

item.name: Templar Queenie 2: The Secret Letters, The Tapestries & The Lamps
item.comment: Good Queenie, but should have come with a player aid as certainly the family players can't remember which object does what.

item.name: Templar Queenie 3: The Catacombs
item.comment: It's harder then it seems to play on these scrolls, certainly in the expert version. Not recommended to add with pure family gamers

item.name: Templar Queenie 4: The Keys
item.comment: OK addition. This can be your lifesaver, especially near the end, otherwise it's just 3 VP.

item.name: Templar: The Secret Treasures
item.comment:
One of the better Queen Games, but in the more family games section. It's not as 'difficult' as a Lancaster or an Edo. Question is if it will appeal the through family gamer? My first play was at Spiel 2013 with 3 players who clearly weren't used to playing 'the alternative' boardgames before and they true this was a very difficult game. The taking back cards and how to time this (a mechanism I personally like a lot) was something very hard for them to master.
Note after 2nd play: 5 players is just too many as most of the meaningful cards will be constantly blocked.

item.name: Temporum
item.comment:
Same sidenote as with Rattlebones: on the box in mentioned 'Printed in the USA with Pride'. Really? The quality of the printing is really bad. Colours are flat and the board has the tendency to curl. This is awful quality, even the better Chinese like Panda produce better quality, so I hope this ain't the best the USA can do on printing :s
The game itself. No wow-factor here. Collect money and spent it to buy victory points (= move crowns). That's basically it. The timechanging is really artificial. At a certain moment the best cards in each time zone will be real and then nobody will change time anymore.

item.name: Terra Evolution
item.comment: It's a game that plays itself instead that you have to make some choices

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment:
Blind buy as it was totally selling out at Essen 2012. Hopefully it will be worth the money :s
Finally played. Good game? Certainly yes! But > 50 euro good? Personally, I don't think so.

item.name: Terra Mystica: 4 Stadtmarker
item.comment: OK goodie

item.name: Terra Mystica: Bonus Card Shipping Value
item.comment: Only useful in combination with certain factions

item.name: Terra Mystica: Vuur en IJs
item.comment: Another map, more races, other scoring tiles,.. all extra variety we love :-)

item.name: Terra Prime
item.comment: First game I had no clue what to do, which made it a rather anoying game, so I'll rated it a 6.5. Second playI had an idea (which worked :D), so I raised my rating to 7. Might still go up.

item.name: Terraforming Mars
item.comment:
Rating based on a prototype I 'got' from Intrafin. Still needs some polishing as some questions came across while playing.
It's a game where you have to look for combo's between cards, something I like very much. And you can really look for those combo's as you draft 4 cards at the beginning of a round and you chose which 1 you will keep (by paying 3 MC for it).
The points to work - from my point of view - are the playing time (+ 2 hours with 3 experienced players felt for all off us as a bit too long) and downtime can be high as it is a sort of multiplayer solitaire.

item.name: Thebes: The Tomb Raiders
item.comment:
The good thing is that when playing this, you really feel like playing Thebes. But maybe it feels a bit too much like Thebes? The way they introduced the artefacts into the draw pile is done very well and there are some extra 'bells and whistles' in the form of action cards and the musea, but it feels the same as playing the regular Thebes. And personally I prefer the excitement of drawing chits out of a bag :)
For me this card game is an excellent alternative if you don't have the boardgame yet (who is out of print unfortunately), or if you want something more compact to take with you on holiday, but otherwise you don't need to own if you already have the 'real' Thebes.

item.name: The Three Musketeers: The Queen's Pendants
item.comment: Ok semi-co-operative game, but with so many better ones (Shadows over Camelot, Pandemic, Castle Panic or Defenders of the Realm) out there, not one you need to have

item.name: Through the Ages: A New Story of Civilization
item.comment:
A lot of impressions after 1 play:
+ explaining of the rules didn't take that long (but we both played civ games before, so were familiar with concepts as leaders, ages,...) + it's really cutthroat: it feels like you wanna do X things but your stone and/or food and/or science lets you do only X-3 (and if you have enough resources for doing X, you'll probably won't have enough action cubes :s) + Our game (with 2 all new) took 3 hours, but it certainly didn't feel like 3 hours - How often will you play this game? With my cult-of-the-new urge, I'll be happy if I can play this once a year. And preferably you wanna play this with the same player - I say player, because this is a 2-player game at max, unless you like SM, then I can recommend a 4-player game - Exclude all the players in your playing group who suffer from AP, even if it's only a little bit

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Into the Abyss
item.comment: I guess recycling of cards from the first 6 sets is the only thing we can expect in future sets of Thunderstone Advance :-( At least they didn't go full option like in Worlds Collide

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Numenera
item.comment: The Cyphers are nice and can make the difference between winning or losing, but you mainly wanna use them to upgrade your Hero's.

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Root of Corruption
item.comment: Don't feel the need to play this game co-operatively

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Towers of Ruin
item.comment:
Plus: iconography is MUCH better. Functional board and the wilderness side makes it easier to bash up some monsters.
Minus: I was really hoping that this Thunderstone Advance would really be a smoother version of Thunderstone, meaning FASTER. But that certainly wasn't true in our first game (105 minutes for 3 players) :(

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Worlds Collide
item.comment: How hard can you squize the lemon? Very hard according to AEG. Not only contains this set just some cards from the 'first' Thunderstone-series, instead of making this an economic affordable expansion by just putting the cards in a small box together with dividers, no, they have to make this a big box with a board, XP-tokens and basic cards. My advice: give a signal and DON'T BUY THIS!!!

item.name: Thunderstone: Dragonspire
item.comment: Deck-building game like Dominion, but more complex. Great if you're playing with maximum 3 who all know the game, because it takes longer then a game of Dominion.

item.name: Thunderstone: For the Dwarf Promo
item.comment: Good hero

item.name: Thunderstone: Heart of Doom
item.comment: Just more cards.

item.name: Thunderstone: Wrath of the Elements
item.comment: Does traps are really mortal and the Elemental monsters are too/very powerfull :s

item.name: Thurn and Taxis: All Roads Lead to Rome
Thurn and Taxis: Power and Glory
Ticket to Ride
item.comment: A classic family gateway game, that I still enjoy playing after several years

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
item.comment: The Team-play gives a different way of playing using the classic mechanism. Nicely done!

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 2 – India & Switzerland
item.comment: Getting a Manadala-bonus is very hard and only worthwhile if you can get the big points.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 3 – The Heart of Africa
item.comment:
This map is fro me the least interesting so far. The feature of the terrain types ain't that interesting. In the beginning you try to combine it for double points, but near the end you get your 'normal' Ticket to Ride where the main focus is on putting down your trains as fast as possible, before someone blocks the route you are aiming for.
The cluster of colours on the map is quite interesting, but hard at the same time, because you neeed the same colour A LOT in a short period of time and almost have to wait for a reshuffle of the deck before you'll have enough for the second time you'll need that colour.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 4 – Nederland
item.comment:
If you want a map that gives you a totally different 'Ticket-to-Ride'-experience, this map does the job. Especially because the end bonuses are very high for having the most toll-tokens left.
For me personally this is a very difficult map: you're encouraged to built your routes quickly in the hope someone will join you and pay bridge toll to you. But I'm a player who like to collect a lot of train cards and then start building along high value routes.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 5 – United Kingdom & Pennsylvania
item.comment:
This rating is simply based on the overall feeling I had of my 2-player game on the UK-map, which was quite good as I rate it 8.5 :-)
The need for the acquisition of technologies to do things really gives an extra twist to the game that makes that solely the UK-map is worth owning this expansion.
But 2 afterthoughts came into my mind: 1) The technology that lets you draw 3 cards instead of 2 if all the cards you take are blind exists only in 2 copies. This was not a problem in our 2-player game, but I think it's a handicap to not have it in 3+ games? 2) That route of 40 points is maybe a bit to easy. I had the impression that most of the contracts are of low value, so It's hard to catch up just on tickets.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: 10th Anniversary
item.comment: Very nice material and beautiful to look at

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Märklin
item.comment: Best TTR!

item.name: Tier auf Tier
item.comment: The kids version of Riff Raff :-)

item.name: Tikal II: The Lost Temple
item.comment: More of a smooth, but very good family game then Tikal itself

item.name: Time's Up! Academy
item.comment: Books, movies, songs,...not realy my preferred subjects :s So for me the yellow edition is more the enough :D

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment: I like this kind of games, as I have an interest in history. However if you don't, you probably wan't bother for this game. After a while the replayability will become low as you know most of the cards, but off course therefore they made all those expansions :D

item.name: Tiny Epic Galaxies
item.comment: You roll and try to finish the big cards as fast as possible (= aka you need some real luck with the dice rolls). That's it.

item.name: Titania
item.comment: Game where you need a bit of luck, but also need to plan carefully and make sure you don't give gifts to your opponents; (a lot) better with 4 or 3 then with 2

item.name: Titans of Industry
item.comment:
This is a typical Kickstarter which ain't bad, but it wouldn't have been a disaster if it hand't existed either.
There is absolutely nothing new in this game. But it all works and it's tight to keep a balance between money and VP.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment: Near the end downtime is long as everybody is puzzling with his cards

item.name: Toc Toc Woodman: Golden Core and Bark Promo
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Tokaido
item.comment: Rather light family game, which is nice to play with the right group of people. It's sort of set collection, but the souvenirs seems inevitable to have

item.name: Tokaido: Crossroads
item.comment: I like Tokaido, but it's vey light. I hoped this expansions would spice up things a little bit. It does in a certain way, as you have the choice between 2 options on every location, and the cherry tree is in that way my favorite as it creates a second type of location where you can get money, but all thins considered together it doens't increase the difficulty level.

item.name: Tokaido: The New Encounters
item.comment: Same rating as base game.

item.name: Tomahawk
item.comment: Not sure about this one. Normally I like the game concept of closed cards, but here you seem to have only a little control (just by the end you have more information if you count cards), maybe a bit too little.

item.name: Tomorrow
item.comment: If you're into Euro-games like myself, don't even bother trying out this game, as it is a waste of time because this is a 100% Ameritrash-game

item.name: Too Many Cooks
item.comment: Light, but quite fun

item.name: Top 5 Rummy
item.comment:
Surprisingly good (who would think this from a game with rummy in the title :D), but then again the designer is Rüdiger Dorn. Ideal to play with family gamer, but challenging enough for the experienced players.
And because of the fact the tasks are double-sided, replayability will be high I expect. One to add to the collection :-)

item.name: Torres
item.comment: Not my kind of game (I have no 3D - insight :s), but I'll play it if someone asks me for it. Blocking other players off from gaining profit of your effords is quite important in this game.

item.name: Tortuga
item.comment: This is a 100% family game, that has the drawback that there is quite a bit to explain for being a family game. There is a lot of luck involved in this game (hey, it's dice rolling!), especially with your 2 last dice, you need the luck to get what you're after for.

item.name: Toru
item.comment: OK to play from time to time

item.name: Toscana
item.comment: Family game, with a lot more going on then you think

item.name: Tournay
item.comment: Good++

item.name: Trains
item.comment: You can call this Dominion (a game I like a lot :-) with a board :D, but a very good implementation of the board as you can get some really nice points from there and you have to consider spending your money on building tracks are buying some nice extra cards. Also a good feature is that you sort of chose to take 'a curse' (which is Waste in this game) as those Waste-cards are connected to certain actions. But by just passing (hopefully with a lot of Waste in your hand at that moment) you get rid of them.

item.name: Trains and Stations
item.comment:
A dice rolling game from the designer of Quarriors, that was a blind buy for me. This however seems to be of a totally different level. It's much lighter and I got the feeling that a bad dice roll (for instance with 2 mines and 2 ranches) is more unforgiving here then it is in Quarriors.
Also the power cards seemed to be very unbalanced. In our 1 game I got (from the start) a power card that gave me 1 silver and 1 food. As those resources never gotten into play, that was 14 points for me just like that (which made me win off course) and those things shouldn't be in a game.
So if you see this as a light game, with luck involved, that's easy to explain and plays fast, you gonna be OK with this game, but it you're looking for something with more strategy, this is certainly not your game.

item.name: Trains: German/NorthEast USA Map
item.comment: Gives you a little bit of extra variety

item.name: Trains: Map Pack 2 – Europe/Italy/California
item.comment: This map doens't seem so special (only played Europe so far).

item.name: Trains: Rising Sun
item.comment: It's in fact the same, with only the bonus routes as extra and 2 maps who are ideal for 2 players.

item.name: Trajan
item.comment: Stefan feld keeps doing it! First time I played a game with a Mancala - system: fun, but hard.

item.name: Trambahn
item.comment: Good 2-player game that offers enough interesting choices each turn.

item.name: Trango
item.comment: Not my kind of game (don't have the visual insight); Blocking another player automatically means you lose points

item.name: Träxx
item.comment: Not bad, but not as good as Qwixx. It's not as tense as Qwixx as you don't have the sensation of throwing the dice. But still a nice filler.

item.name: Treasure Hunter
item.comment: It's a sort of 7 Wonders light, the kind of game which you can easily get on the table.

item.name: Treasure Hunter Expansion 1: Goblin's Loot
item.comment: Some harder goblins makes those dogs more attractive at certain moments.

item.name: Treasure Hunter: Queenie 1 – Band of Goblins
Triassic Terror
item.comment: If you like area control as a mechanism and you can take the fact that you can lose control because someone eats your dinos, then this is a great game for you. However, don't expect to find some refreshing new game mechanism from this game. But all works great together and the bonus is that the actions even feel thematic right; the theme for once is more then just a paste-on.

item.name: Triassic Terror: Promo Pack
item.comment:
The big bird is nice and should have been included in the base game as all predators are now in plastic :)
Don't think I'll ever use the upgraded Predator-tiles as in my gaming group there is no worry what so ever that they won't be picked :s

item.name: Tribune Expansion
item.comment: Don't know about this expansion (only played with extra expansion board); Didn't had the feeling that the game became any better

item.name: Tricoda
item.comment: Good deduction game. Having enough patience is the key sometimes :D

item.name: Trollhalla
item.comment: Enjoyed my one play so far (with 2), but think it's best with 3. Might become an 8.

item.name: Troyes
item.comment: Had some high expectations from this one, as they sold out very quick and I heared some good things about it; It's a good game, that for sure, but it didn't meet those high expectations I had

item.name: Troyes: Bonus Cards
item.comment: Same rating as base game

item.name: TSCHAK!
item.comment: Fun, fast filler

item.name: Tsuro of the Seas
item.comment: Tsuro + the extra options with the monsters. Ok as a light family/filler game.

item.name: Tuintopia
item.comment:
There are 2 clever ideas in this game, but imho they both lack of a finishing touch.
The first are the rules. They are printed on the same cards as you play with. And they are used as a scoring track. Nicely done, but by doing this the rules are a bit too condensed and aren't that clear at all. They refer to a website for an example, which is fine if you're at home and have access to internet, but won't help you if you're in a boardgame club or something like that. And on the website you'll only find an example of level I, not of level II, which is the most complicated bit.
So the game itself: you play cards which have a demand and an output. For each demand-symbol you can match with an outputsymbol of a neighbouring card or vice versa, you score a point. Again a nice idea, but they are a lot of symbols, so checking your 4 cards angainst all possibilities to see which is the best match, will take some time. And it will even take more time if you play at level II as also shadow/sun and wind/no wind come into play as an extra factor. There also seems to be an imbalance in distribution of the symbols between output and demand. For instance a lot of cards will give an apple as output, but there are almost no cards who demand apples. Thematically this is probably correct (as the cards represent certain parts of a garden), but for actual playing, a better ballance between the distribution of the symbols would have made for a better game and they probably also could have skipped more easily a few symbols.
What this game clearly lacks is some more playtesting, now it's to dull as you really have to wait for your turn.

item.name: Tulipmania 1637
item.comment: It's short and nice

item.name: Turbo Taxi
item.comment: Never again!

item.name: Turmbauer
item.comment: Nice combination of dexterity and tactics; You need 3D-insight so for me to win this, this will be very hard for me to ever win this :s

item.name: Tuscany: Expand the World of Viticulture
item.comment: Great extra stuff!

item.name: Tweeeet
item.comment: Surprising nice filler game from which I liked the team-up part the most. Best game by far I've played from Cwali.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment:
The number 1 of BGG (still on 25/05/2015). Somehow this game never appealed to me. But as Jan wanted to play this and it is number 1, I gave it a try.
So impressions after 1 play: why is this number 1 and gets such a high rating from so many players?
First problem I have with this game that it is even stated in the rules (according to Jan who explained the rules) that you have a better chance of winning with the US then with the USSR. Then again I won with the USSR as a newbie and maybe the USSR-part is just harder to grasp? In Mr. Jack the role as Jack is also harder for new players to play good then the one of detective. If this is the same for this game, I suppose that's something I can live with.
What for me however is too annoying for me is the dice part. The equations to calculate the 'coup'-result reminded me of some Italian games, something I dislike. But just the fact that such a long game can be decided with 1 good or bad dice roll, just makes this not worthy of playing for me. I for example won our game by reaching 20 victory points because I had the luck of rolling a 1 on the space track and so score the 2 points I was missing.
The third part that annoys me in this game is some of the cards. You can try to built up something and 1 card played by your opponent can sometimes just take away the control you needed and you can't do anything against it.
Jan likes the game about the fact that you have to take care that you have to play the cards you get as smart as possible so that the advantages you give to your opponent are as reduced as possible. That is indeed the clue of this game and a mechanism I can't say I have seen in other games. Then again, if you get 8 US-cards as the USSR-player, you won't be that happy with this gaming mechanism :s
Conclusion: the Ameritrash-factor in this game is too high for me.

item.name: Two by Two
item.comment: Fast, kind of light, but enough interesting choices

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment: I like this kind of games, but your partner has to like them too...

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment: This game had a lot of buzz before Spiel 2012 and it deserves it! This is indeed one very cool twist on Worker placement (dynamic worker placement). But it makes that planning has to be done very carefull. I'm normally a fast player, but even I had to take some time to make sure that every worker was on it's place when I wanted it to be. So expect a (very) long playing time when it's your first game!

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar – Mini Expansion 1
item.comment: OK extra

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar – Mini Expansion 2
item.comment: OK extra.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar – Tribes & Prophecies
item.comment:
This expansion consist of 3 modules. the first, material for a 5th player, I'll probably never use as I don't feel the urge to play this game with 5 (3 and 4 are the best imho).
The tribes, they give you a certain advantage and some of them will be used more then others (for example with the Yum Kaax it's nice that you can put down 2 workers for free, very handy when you have no corn left).
The prophecies was the module I was in advance most excited about, as it would create extra possibilities for scoring. They certainly do that, but as you get minus points (and minus 5 seems a lot) for not having certain things, I'm wondering if now you're not forced in doing certain stuff. It was the feeling Jan had in our 1 play so far, he neglected the Prophecies and had -10 points, while I scored +18. That's a big gap to catch up. Future plays will determine if you really can't neglact them or not.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar – Tribes & Prophecies – Mini Expansion 1
Ubongo 3D
item.comment: I just don't like Ubongo

item.name: Ubongo Extreme
item.comment: For me Ubongo is already difficult enough :s

item.name: UGO!
item.comment: Nice twist on trick-taking - games. However, as, especially with less then 4 players, a great part of the cards are not participating, you're enable to count the cards, as you don't have a clue if they are still in someone's hands or just not dealt? So the dose of luck in this game is greater then in for example 'Sticheln'.

item.name: ...und tschüss!
item.comment: When Surya explained the rules, I kinda liked the idea; But when playing it, I found it very frustrating to play; For example you can play 15, 15 & 14, but if your opponent has a triple 15, you have nothing and you've lost all your high cards. It's also hard if you have mediocre cards and can't become the first player to get a card so that you can swap your cards.

item.name: Undermining
item.comment: Fast kind of pick-up-and-deliver - game in combination with the possibility of upgrading you abilities (UMV).

item.name: Der unendliche Fluss
item.comment: Well compared how smooth my wife and Emeline moved the magicians, I definitely suck at this game :s

item.name: Unexpected Treasures
item.comment: Why the f**k did they reprint this game? The way to get the first-player token, which MEGA-important in this game, is just ridiculous: you just randomly draw a player-order token at the start of every turn :s Why not add a card that lets you take a player-order token or a simple rule as 'the player who got the most tokens in the previous round go's last'? It would eliminate a lot of frustration for me I think.

item.name: Unusual Suspects
item.comment: In the rules state this is a party game and that's how you should look at it, it's 100% a party game. OK, but not outstanding.

item.name: Upon a Salty Ocean
item.comment: After 1 play my initial thought there is only one strategy to go for. Read on the Geek some alternatives I wanna check out whom I think can work. So needs a replay before I'll make my final judgement.

item.name: Urban Sprawl
item.comment:
As a Dominant Species - fan I had some high expectations of this one. When I played it, I found it a good for the first 2 hours (dispite the big chaos the event cards can create), but the 3rd hour was a bit too much for me. It was clear that I would win and the gap between me and the rest just became greater and greater;
There is a variant in the rules for a shorter game and maybe that will be perfect for this game.

item.name: Urbania
item.comment: This game has a rather low rating and I wonder why? This is in fact quite good game. It's fast, not so hard to explain, turns are fast and challenging enough. What more do you want? The answer for this game is some beutifull/clear artwork. That is really awefull :s, a pity.

item.name: Urbanization
item.comment:
I can't believe the average rating of this game is only 6.6 (rating on 12/01/2013). Maybe people are expecting a civilization game, which it is not, it's a typical euro-game. But as always: if you're someone who plays regulary, please immediately add all the expansion modules, they really spice up the game!
Queen Games builded up some credit with games as Lancaster, Kingdom Builder and Edo and for me this game can be perfectly in that row. It has the same level of complexity as Lancaster. Clearly different paths to score points (which I always like). The rulebook could be a bit more clearer and the artwork won't blow your socks off (but does it ever with Queen Games?), but this is a more then decent game!

item.name: Utopia
item.comment:
If you wanna play this game, you'll have to except, that there will be some luck involved, as well in the tokens getting out the bag, as in the cards you get. Personally however I could live with the balance luck/strategy in this game, it's about the same level as in a typical HiG-game.
What however didn't feels so 'right' in this game, is the determination of the palyer order: the player who already has the most points, will get first pick on tokens, as well on playing cards. OK, he will lose 2 cards, which can be 'ouch', especially if you're low in cards, but still that doesn't seems to compensate on being first in both phases.

item.name: Valdora
item.comment: A bit more difficult then a true family game (you really need efficient management of your actions), but excellent game to play with people who like medium games: It's really a pitty of the ugly coins you use as money. What happened to the discs of Zooloretto?

item.name: Valdora: Additional Commission
item.comment:
Print & Play;
Maybe to easty to get?

item.name: Valdora: Special board 19
item.comment: Can be usefull to score some extra points.

item.name: Valdora: Special board 20
item.comment: Not so interesting I think

item.name: Valley of the Kings
item.comment:
The pyramid-display is a bit of a fiddley thing with little addition to the gameplay, but the fun part of the game is that you have to entomb your cards to score points, but want those powerful ones to keep as long as possible, without it being too late.
For the rest it's a very classic deckbuilding game, nothing new on that part.

item.name: Vampire der Nacht
item.comment: Very nice components (just a vampire face on the vampire pawn is missing :D) as we're used from DMS. The game itself feels like a Night of the Magicians ripp-off (glowing in the dark, pushing things off), but is still fun to play.

item.name: Vampire Empire
item.comment: First half of my first game was frustrating (see logged gameplay), but the end was exciting. So will see what a next game brings :-)

item.name: Vanuatu
item.comment: Heavy, but very good. Especially the mechanism that you have to have a majority before you can take an action makes not so easy as it seems.

item.name: Vasco da Gama
item.comment: Very good game

item.name: Il Vecchio
item.comment: Good game as you can aspect from Rudiger Dorn, but as a friend of me would call it: 'dry, very dry' :D

item.name: Vegas
item.comment: Light dice game, just fun to play. Best with 4 or 5.

item.name: Vegas Showdown
item.comment: Good auction, but I think it's best with 4, as with 5 in the last rounds there where no slots, lounges nore restaurants available, so it's just waiting for the prices of the premier tiles to drop and go for publishing in the mean while.

item.name: Venezia 2099
item.comment: What can I say? Typical Colovini, it's easy to explain and to play, but you will need a dose of luck of doing well. Certainly the first treasures you buy is more of a blind guess if they will be 6 points or only 1.

item.name: La Venise du Nord
item.comment:
Sébastien Dujardin is the co-author of Troyes and in Troyes they created a nice mechanism for using dice. Here the author wanted to do also something original with dice, but for me this doens't seem to work. That's because you can really depend on the luck of your dice rolls in this game.
It already starts with reaching the tile you want. If you have bad luck, you'll have to move to a tile where you have to take a useless action. Secondly, in our game the craftsmen Myriam got where all for purple cubes. But as Surya had put a dice with a value of 1 on the purple cubes space, she could only get 1 purple cube at a time and she could do nothing at this, until Surya removed his dice from that tile (OK, if she would have rolled a 1 AND got a dice by whom she could reach that tile, then she could have removed it herself, but that's TONS of LUCK she would have needed to do that).

item.name: Venture Forth
item.comment: I liked the first part of the game, where you have to build your party of adventurers and have to think things over to avoid taking too much damage from the creatures. However the second half was rather boring as more parties have a strength of 10 or more, monsters are just a walk in the park. The game lasted too long, maybe less event tokens would help. Now it was boring for the last 45 - 60 minutes.

item.name: Venture Forth: Pandora's Jar Promo
item.comment: Lucky shot

item.name: Het Verboden Eiland
item.comment: I can see this being a great game if you have kids you wanna introduce into co-operative gameplaying, but if you're 'old enough', just play Pandemic

item.name: Der verflixte Zaubertrank
item.comment: As I am poor in games on time, this one doesn't work for me. Can be greats for kids though

item.name: Versailles
item.comment: For me, the game is a bit too static. That's because the way you can walk with your meeples is predetermined. Which means that as you wanna move your meeples in 'crops' between 2 locations to gain as much profit from each location, a lot of the time your moves are predetermined or logic. I would have liked some more freedom, so that some more thinking would be required.

item.name: Der verzauberte Turm
item.comment: Very good introduction of the semi-co-operative mechanic into a childrens game. The child who played along went really crazy when she won as Robin :)

item.name: Die verzauberten Rumpelriesen
item.comment: So simple concept (imps hiding under leaves) that you wonder why nobody else has come up with this idea. Very beautiful artwork and components (as always with DMS) and also fun to play as an adult!

item.name: Via Appia
item.comment:
After some games of some higher difficulty (like Edo or Lancaster), this is clearly again in the 'light' sector. It's not bad and doesn't take long to play, but for me it could use some 'modules' to spice things a little bit up.
Timing at the stone quarry is everything in this game. If you put your stones in and nothing comes out, a lot will fall out for the player comming behind you. So if you notice it won't work, it's probably better to stop after 1 stone.

item.name: Villa Paletti
item.comment: OK Dexterity game

item.name: Village
item.comment: Really great game, where there are probably a lot of strategies/combos you can go for. I say combos, because I think you have to focus on 2 or 3 areas max.

item.name: Village: Customer Expansion
item.comment: More variation, I like it! If you are going for a market-strategy, the one that grants you 1 point for each market tile is the you gotta get!

item.name: Vinhos
item.comment: Good Gamers' Game; It's a pity it's so hard to explain the rules :s

item.name: Viticulture
item.comment:
The second best Kickstarter so far (after City of Iron). I can imagine why people would advise you to play this with 3 or 5, near the end, when people usually have lots of workers, it can be very crowdy on the board and you really want to be first or second. My advice is: immediately add the 'Viticulture: Arboriculture Expansion', as you create extra spaces on your own board where you can put your workers in a usefull way.
I really like this kind of games, as everything is tight and there is always more stuff you wanna do, but just can't. So making good choices and having a good timing is crucial!

item.name: Viticulture: Arboriculture Expansion
item.comment: Excellent expansion as it give you extra possibilities to score; extra good with even number of players as your excess workers can go on your extra board where they can be usefull too you.

item.name: Viticulture: Kickstarter Promotional Cards
item.comment: Ok extra.

item.name: Viva Topo!
item.comment: As an adult you have to make the same though decisions as the children: hope that no one moves the cat and go for the big cheese or play it safe and move that mouse futheraway from the cat/put him into a mouse hole?

item.name: VivaJava: The Coffee Game
item.comment: It's a good game and perfect if you're looking for a game when you're with 6 - 8 players (personally I think that's the only number you wanna play with and 8 is probably the best) that doens't take that long, but for me it doens't meet the big fuzz that was around this game.

item.name: Vlotte Geesten
item.comment: Definitely not my style of game, but I can see why people like this one

item.name: Voll in Fahrt
item.comment: Maybe only with kids this is fine, but as an adult this was too chaotic for me. There is no challenge also: you don't have to memorise something and you hardly have to make a descission as you often only have one good option (if you have any!)

item.name: Völuspá
item.comment: How can i describe this? I can't point out anything that's wrong about this game, simple rules, the power/strength of the tiles are in perfect balance and quick turns. But somehow it did strike me at all. Maybe it's because I'm not a fan of tile-placement games (not a fan of Carcassonne!)?

item.name: Voor de Poorten van Loyang
item.comment: Excellent game, but you have to play it a couple of times to master it

item.name: De Vorsten van Catan
item.comment:
What I remembered from the 'old version' was that there were some overpowered cards. When playing with only the base game, that problem didn't seem to occur.
What still might be an issue is the number of villages. It's even and if 1 player can get 1 more then the other, he will have 4 more resource cards and have a far better chance of winning.

item.name: Vrijdag
item.comment: Not bad, but a bit repetitive near the end. It's a pity you need so much space to play the game, otherwhise it would be ideal to play on the train or while traveling in general.

item.name: De Vulgari Eloquentia
item.comment: Really good: you have a lot of paths that you can follow. But you have to stay focused and can't do a little of everything.

item.name: Waka Waka
item.comment:
As Jambo is my favorite 2-player - game, when I heard there would be a boardgame version, this was a must have for me. But as it would be language dependent, I just waited for the Dutch version to be available. In the meanwhile the rating of this game went dramatically low, so I hadn't high expectations when playing this.
So I finally played it and what is the feeling? Well, it's certainly not Jambo. The reason why is clear : there are no animals or persons by whom you can tease your opponents (even the twon elder that lets you lose a card from an opponent, doesn't make him lose a card and is even good for him as he can swap a card). That's maybe good for those who don'like that element in Jambo, but by eliminating this, they also took away a big part of the tension you have with Jambo.
So is it < 6-rating bad? That is also unfair to this game I believe. In it's category of family game (as they are only a limited number of different characters, Waka Waka is much easier then Jambo) it is a good game: easy rules, short playing time and fast turns where all elements work together just fine. So when I rate 7, I rate this as a game in the category 'family game' and nothing more.
I guess Waka Waka gets his low rating because of the same thing that happened with Dominant Species - The Card Game. Publishers wanna attach a popular game to a new release, and for commercial reasons I understand why they do that, however by doing that you create certain expectations, those games often can't fulfill, as they are just another kind of game as the popular game they are associated with. If Waka Waka would have a 'non-Jambo' - setting, it would therefore probably get a more 'fair' rating.

item.name: Wakanda
item.comment: It's all about being not to greedy and close the pole you're aiming for before your opponent does

item.name: Wallenstein (second edition)
item.comment: As BGG hier says 'similar to: Shogun', I expected this game to have at least some tweaks on certain rules. However, they are COMPLETELY the same (I'm comparing the 2012 edition of Shogun with the 2012 edition of Wallenstein), so the only difference in fact is the map and that you have 2 expansions with Wallenstein you don't get with Shogun. I found this to be disappointing and I can't imagine someone would by Shogun if he has already Wallenstein or even vice versa.

item.name: Walnut Grove
item.comment: This game is tense, maybe too tense. In my 1 play I had the feeling I constantly had to go for damage control (= get food and fire wood) and scoring points (= building up something) is inferior to that. No wow-feeling at all after 1 play.

item.name: Wanzen tanzen
item.comment: Played by the wrong rules (damn you google translate!) so will probably get a rerating.

item.name: Warlock
item.comment: It's a card game for the more heavy gamer. Every card has 4 functionalities, so you have to chose wisely what to do with each card (use as money, as resource, as a special action or built into your city). I liked my one play so far a lot.

item.name: Wars of the Roses: Lancaster vs. York
item.comment: You certainley don't wanna be in the lead in the first 4 rounds :s

item.name: Wat schets je me nou?!
item.comment: The big difference with that other drawing game Identik, here it matters if you are good in drawing or not. Can be fun I guess, but not my cup of tea, that's for sure.

item.name: Water Lily
item.comment: This is a real hidden gem. This is mega-fun to play!

item.name: We Will Wok You
item.comment: Nice light medium game, where timing is crucial because you really don't wanna leave any gifts for your opponents. But at about 1/3 of your turns the games plays itself as you're short of money, so you just have to chose the right row of money.

item.name: Wealth of Nations
item.comment:
When some spectator looked at our game and compared it with Settlers of Catan we all had a laugh, but near the end of the game it certainly felt this game had the same problem as Settlers of Catan with 4 players: 1 player will be cut off from further expansion and is screwed for the rest of the game.
Other complaints about this game: playing time is too long and why couldn't they found an eleganter way to end the game that everbody has to sell his cubes 1 at a time? And why the hell do you wanna play this game with more then 3???

item.name: The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow
item.comment: Good party game if you have a large group

item.name: Western Town
item.comment: Very good worker placement with some original ideas. My fellow players didn't like the indian camp, but I found it to be a nice addition. The only minus with this game is that the iconagraphy isn't all that clear, resulting in players who have to look up what everything is doing and lots of downtime on your first game. But off course, this will resolve itself with more plays.

item.name: Western Town: Expansion
item.comment: Don't like the Telegraph as it is a building to annoy others and there is already enough of that with the indians who can invade your town :s

item.name: Whitewater
item.comment: Definitely not my style of game. The biggest bully probably wins

item.name: Wie heeft het gedaan?
item.comment: Clue meets Memory, but done in a good way and with smart use of the electronic.

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment: Just a fun racing/betting game

item.name: Winter
item.comment: Great expansion! It makes 51st State much more streamlined and clear.

item.name: Winter: Reaction Cards
item.comment: Doens't seem to add that much.

item.name: Wiraqocha
item.comment: One play so far, didn't had a good impression of this game. They try to do something 'strategic' with dice, but the luck you need with the dice rolls is suinificant. If you get knocked off the resources, you are in big trouble, as you can't buy your pawns back and can't do something usefull. That part enoyed me a lot in this game.

item.name: Witch's Brew
item.comment: I can hardly win this game, but I find it fun to play :D

item.name: The Witches of Blackmore
item.comment: 1 play with 3 players, 2 with 4 and I'm not really convinced by this game. However, maybe it's the same as with Little Devils: you need at least 5 players for this game to shine?

item.name: The Witches: A Discworld Game
item.comment: As it's a Martin Wallace and has the Discworld-setting I liked from Ankh-Morpork, I pre-ordered the this game. However, I think, after playing it, replay ability of this one is low. Ankh-Morpork was light, but at least you had the aspect of trying to outguess who has which character. Here, you just move and try to prevent bad things from happening, hoping on good dice rolls and good cards to hopefully correct things if things go wrong.

item.name: Wits & Wagers Family
item.comment: Maybe if it would be in my own language, but otherwise, NEVER AGAIN!

item.name: Wizard
item.comment: Nice card game

item.name: Wizard's Brew
item.comment: This is more a family game, maybe family+, as some smart bidding is required in order to win. As complexity it's of the same level as Pastiche. However, as a family game, I like it (it's with auctions :).

item.name: Wizard's Brew: City Expansion
item.comment: More spells = more variety, Always a good thing. However, certainly as they were physically packed together with the 36 spells from the base game, I'm wondering if they just had'nt 50+ spells at the beginning and just had split off 3 packages to create 3 expansions? This applies also for the 'Mystical' and 'Dark Summoner' expansion.

item.name: Wok Star
item.comment: Played a production copy; For me the game was a bit too long, became a bit too repetitive near the end.

item.name: Wooolf!!
item.comment:
Fun party game where you have to find out who's who by deduction, a genre I like. That's why I bought the game :D
One downside: 5 is the best number to play this game :s

item.name: Workshop of the World
item.comment: Second game, first was Canal Mania, I play from the Ragnar Brothers and I had the same feeling as with Canal Mania: it's OK, it works, but really nothing special. The mid-game of a phase can be a bit tense as that can decide if you can make a large network or not, but the end of a phase often plays itself. Also very dull artwork.

item.name: Wunderland
item.comment:
I can enjoy a lighter family game like Ticket to Ride from time to time, but this one seems to be a bit too light for my tatste. There is only one decision you have to makj during the entire game: if someone is moving to a spot that is closer to one of the numbers you need, how many discs will I put along? Luckily it plays fast and turns are fast.
There is also a golden rule about family games: they have to be attractive in terms af artwork. I understand that they want to be faithfull to the German amusement park 'Wunderland', but this is really, really very ugly artwork. It certainly doesn't invite me to go an visite 'Wunderland' :D

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment: Quick, fun, not to hard and ideal to play with 3

item.name: Yedo
item.comment: There is nothing really new about this game, but everything works excellent together. And lately I can appreciate this kind of games more then those where they were so focussed on creating something new, that they forgot about streamlining the game or something is still broken. Good job!

item.name: Yedo: Sakoku
item.comment: An event-card with a cardboard-token

item.name: Yggdrasil
item.comment: Good 100% co-operative game that finally found something else then 'classic Pandemic'-actions

item.name: Yggdrasil: Asgard
item.comment:
The trance-power seems to make things a bit easier to win. This ain't a bad thing, as I could hardly win this game, without even adding the extra cards from the base game that makes things harder :s
The rule that Hell permanently removes dead vikings didn't seem us to bother a lot, but it made the green rune (that lets you distribute 15 dead vikings amongs all other players) useless.
And off course, it's always nice to have extra gods :D

item.name: Yggdrasil: Vidar Promo
item.comment: Vidar's power seems rather week at first side

item.name: YINSH
item.comment: Second game from the GIPF-serie I play, liked Tzaar more

item.name: Ys
item.comment:
This game reminded me a lot of Aladdin's Dragons (aka Morgenland): (semi- )secret bidding, spells/characters and getting majorities to collect gems/treasures. However, I would prefer Aladdin's Dragons above this one, as Aladdin's Dragons had a much stronger theme (never felt like a broker when playing Ys) and I like the fact that in Aladdin's Dragons you need the treasures to get artifacts (who give you a special power during the game), while in Ys you need gems just to get an other majority.
Maybe the above sounds like I don't like Ys, which ain't the case as (blind) bidding and getting majorities are 2 game mechanisms I like. So if anybody would ask to play this, I would happily do so :-)

item.name: Ys+
item.comment: Not much added value

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment: Quick & easy

item.name: Ystari Box
item.comment:
Played so far:
*Metropolys: New goal cards; Nothing special, I think I even prefer the neighbourhood cards from the expert game; *Yspahan: The Souks. OK *Sylla: caveant consules. The Philospher can be very usefull, the Galdiator is just OK.

item.name: Yunnan
item.comment:
After reading the rules, all individual items is clear, but it's hard to see 'the path to victory'; For instance after reading the rules I thought the Influence - track wouldn't be that important, but in a 5-player game it seemed to be major important, because if 4 players kick back your traders - not always because they want to, but sometimes just because they can -, you will lose a lot, certainly if it would create an underborken chain to Pu'er.
Definitely a game you should play a couple of times to see things clear.

item.name: Yunnan: Tu Di Gong Shrine
item.comment: Simple, but excellent progress building to add to the game.

item.name: Zeitalter der Vernunft
item.comment: When Surya explained this, it reminded me a bit of Liberté, a game of Martin Wallace I disliked playing. This is I liked better, but it certainly won't become my favorite (Walalce-)game, therefore it's it bit too much direct confrontation and is the gaming time too long.

item.name: ZhanGuo
item.comment:
Well, they certainly know how to make a good strategic game at WYG?, that's for sure! Only 1 play with 2 players, from whom I didn't expected too much, as it has majorities in it upto a certain level, but it plays in fact excellent with 2.
Typical game where you have to optimize your moves to a maximum and you won't be able to do all the stuff you want. I like this kind of games :-)

item.name: Zombie 15'
item.comment: The owner of the game described it as 'Escape' meets 'Zombicide'; Never played Zombicide, but it certainly feels like Escape. Which makes it feels like just an other co-operative game to fill the crowd

item.name: Zong Shi
item.comment:
'Traditional' worker placement with the innovative aspect of the different powers of your workers (master/apprentice) in the combination of the time element for you master to finish projects.
From my 1 play so far I think you have to focus on the things you started and don't do a little bit of everything.

item.name: Zooloretto Exotic
item.comment: Doens't add that much and makes things abit unnecessary fidly. Prefer the smaller expansiosn above this one.

item.name: Zooloretto Würfelspiel
item.comment: It's easy, fast to play, easy to explain and it's not just putting some dice in a dumb way on the trucks, you really have to look what your opponents have and plce them tactically. Excellent!

item.name: Zooloretto XXL
item.comment: I like the game idea, but it really extends the playing time way too long!

item.name: Zooloretto: Building Sites
item.comment: Part of a special package I by Rio Grande Games; + brings extra tactical possibilities into the game (and screw your opponents :); - extra 9 tiles seemed to balance out the game: more turns, so more animals in the barns; - only fun when everybody has enough money to rebuild them with their opponents

item.name: Zooloretto: Chamäleon
item.comment: Same rating as Zooloretto: Exotic

item.name: Zooloretto: Christmas Tree
item.comment: Can give you a lot of points if you get the animal you're searching for

item.name: Zooloretto: Familiarisation Area
item.comment: Can be handy to have, it's also tricky to leave an animal there as it can be bought by your opponents for only 1 coin!

item.name: Zooloretto: Goodie-Box
item.comment: For me this was a big disappointment as the only expansion I didn't own yet was 'The Familiarisation' :-((

item.name: Zooloretto: Grizzly
item.comment: Ok, but not something you really wanna aim for

item.name: Zooloretto: Iberian Lynx
item.comment: If you have the money, this can give you at least 2 points (get rid of a single anmial in your barn).

item.name: Zooloretto: Job Boards
item.comment:
Part of a special package II by Rio Grande Games
Nice addition

item.name: Zooloretto: Krake
item.comment: Can give you a lot of money at the right time

item.name: Zooloretto: Polar Bear
item.comment: Part of a special package I by Rio Grande Games; Quite powerfull

item.name: Zooloretto: Rio Grande Games Expansion Pack #1
Zooloretto: Rio Grande Games Expansion Pack #2
Zooloretto: The Gorilla
item.comment:
Part of a special package II by Rio Grande Games
I can't imagine you focus on getting the gorilla; polar bear is much more powerfull

item.name: Zooloretto: The Petting Zoo
item.comment: Part of a special package I by Rio Grande Games

item.name: Zooloretto: Three Additional Buildings
item.comment: Part of a special package I by Rio Grande Games; This expansion is only good if you have a lot of money in the game; best combination is probably with Saving Books

item.name: Zooloretto: Three Extra Enclosures
item.comment: Part of a special package I by Rio Grande Games

item.name: Zoowaboo
item.comment: hmm, liked this one the least from all the children games I played on the BBQ of Prettig Gescoord; Always start with 12 animals instead of 10, it speeds up the game

item.name: Zug um Zug: Deutschland
item.comment: I like this map a lot and also the fact that you can chose to go for short or long tickets

item.name: Zug um Zug: Deutschland – Deutschland 1902
item.comment: When I read the word 'passenger' I thought this expansion would simply recreate the Märklin-edition. But it didn't. It's a for family players a far easier to grasb mechanism. But those passengers make playing for the long term (like I like to do) a lot harder as you need some majorities in order to win.
